description:
TARGET AUDIENCE:  Full-time and collateral-duty hazardous materials coordinators and other specialists who are responsible for sampling the different environmental media.

This one-week class will enable students to perform sampling projects in Level D or supervise contractors performing more complex site characterization. The class will address the fundamentals of chemistry, fate and transport of environmental chemicals, analytical methods, sampling methods for soil and water, geophysics, development of data quality objectives, sampling plans and quality assurance project plans. The students will prepare a brief sampling plan and QAPP and implement the sampling during a field exercise. The class will be taught from BLM technical references and EPA guidance for hazardous waste investigations.

OBJECTIVES:  Upon completion of this class, students will be able to: 

	* assess site physical and chemical parameters

	* determine proper data and sampling needs for site screening and characterization

	* design a field sampling plan

	* evaluate chemical analytical results from site sampling

	* propose to management a course of action for managing the site

	* engage others to effectively get the job done.

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS: Requests for interpreters or other special requirements must be received at the NTC no later than 45 days prior to the start of the class. Form can be accessed at: https://www.ntc.blm.gov/krc/uploads/982/Reasonable_Accommodation_Request_Form.pdf 

Keyword: HazMat, Hazardous Materials, aml, site characterization, reclamation, risk assessment, environmental sampling, CERCLA, abandoned mine lands, policy, risk assessment, 1703-03

TARGET AUDIENCE: Full-time and collateral-duty hazardous materials coordinators, specialists and others involved in service contracting.

This 1-week course details the components of the negotiated procurement process for environmental characterization and clean up contracts and the coordinator's role in this process. Trainees will learn basic governmental contract procedures and how to blend these requirements with the unique needs of hazardous materials management. Trainees will use real field scenarios to discuss COR/PI limitations and authorities and solve potential contracting problems. The course meets the Department of Interior's requirements for COR/PI 40-hour service contracting certification.

OBJECTIVES: Teaches how to engage others to effectively get the job done.  Teaches skills needed to work with the public or monitor user groups.  Interagency and interdisciplinary participants in the class learn how to work together cooperatively.  Qualifies participants to be a Contracting Officer's Representative and Project Inspector.Upon completion of this class, students will be able to:

	* Define the role of the Contracting Officers Representative and Project Inspector (COR/PI) in the procurement process from project planning through post-award monitoring and inspection. 

	* Describe the limitations of the COR/PI authorities needed to prevent assumptions of liabilities. 

	* Inspect a contractor's performance in the field and billing procedures. 

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS: Requests for interpreters or other special requirements must be received at the NTC no later than 45 days prior to the start of the class. Form can be accessed at: https://www.ntc.blm.gov/krc/uploads/982/Reasonable_Accommodation_Request_Form.pdf 

Keyword: Environmental, Contracting, Inspector, Contracting Officers Representative and Project Inspector (COR/PI), hazardous materials, hazmat, aml, abandoned mine lands, contracting, environmental contracting, 1703-04

TARGET AUDIENCE: Department of the Interior personnel who may work around abandoned mine sites in the field. These disciplines may include, but are not limited to:

	* AML Inventory/Closure Personnel
	* Hazardous Materials Personnel
	* Cadastral Surveyors
	* Geologists
	* Biologists

PRE-REQUISITES: You must have completed Basic MSHA Mine Safety Training for Surface and Sub-Surface work prior to attending this class. This course is intended for any Department of the Interior personnel who may work around abandoned mine sites in the field. Covered topics include:

	* Hazard awareness
	* Mining equipment
	* Testing equipment
	* Mapping and terminology

 It also addresses a wide range of hazard types at active, inactive and/or abandoned mines for both surface mines/mills and underground mines.  THIS COURSE IS NOT A SUBSTITUTE FOR MSHA'S BASIC MINE COURSE OR HAZWOPER.  It is a supplemental basic safety course for geologists and other employees that work in and around abandoned mine sites.

COURSE OBJECTIVES: The intent of this training is to:

	* Raise employee awareness of physical, chemical, and other hazards.
	* Minimize the risks of working around abandoned mines by reviewing previous training and learning experiences pertaining to hazard recognition, mitigation, and safe practices and procedures.

 This training will cover the following subject matter:

	* Statutory and Documentation Requirements
	* Entrant's Rights & Responsibilities
	* Preparation for AML Entry
	* Site Hazard Recognition
	* Self-Rescuer Use
	* Mine Gases & Atmosphere
	* Operation and Use of other monitoring/sampling equipment
	* Monitoring Ground/Ground Support Assessment
	* Explosives
	* First Aid

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS: Requests for interpreters or other special requirements must be received at the NTC no later than 45 days prior to the start of the class. Form can be accessed at: https://www.ntc.blm.gov/krc/uploads/982/Reasonable_Accommodation_Request_Form.pdf

Keyword: BLM-TC-1703-05 ??

TARGET AUDIENCE:  Full-time and collateral-duty hazmat coordinators and others involved with sampling programs.

This 1-week course looks at experimental sampling design, applying scientific statistics, sample analysis and report writing. The course is designed for those that are or will be involved in designing a sampling plan for a site, analyzing sample data, and generating reports.

OBJECTIVES: Upon completion of this class, students will be able to:

	* Understand the concepts of environmental sampling.

	* Develop Data Quality Objectives (DQOs).

	* Set sample collection criteria.

	* Interpret the analytical data relative to the DQOs.

	* Prepare a proper report.

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS: Requests for interpreters or other special requirements must be received at the NTC no later than 45 days prior to the start of the class. Form can be accessed at: https://www.ntc.blm.gov/krc/uploads/982/Reasonable_Accommodation_Request_Form.pdf 

Keyword: hazardous materials, hazmat, aml, site characterization, reclamation, risk assessment, environmental sampling, CERCLA, abandoned mine lands, policy, risk assessment, sampling, 1703-15

TARGET AUDIENCE:  Registered users for the AMSCM 2.0 database and/or new users/employees that work in either the Hazardous Materials and Abandoned Mine Land programs, who will be charged with the input, updating, and report generation of the data existing or for creating future projects in AMSCM 2.0.

The WO intends to utilize the Abandoned Mine Site Cleanup Module (AMSCM) to access, analyze and summarize information about HazMat and Abandoned Mine Land sites. By fiscal year 2010, the funding requests for the Central Hazmat Fund (CHF) and the Special Cleanup Fund (SCF), the data for Environmental and Disposal Liability sites, the 5-year AML and HazMat plans, the questions from Congress, and other site information will be pulled from AMSCM. Sites not entered into AMSCM will not be funded. This course is hands-on training for the AMSCM database to ensure the needs of the WO, BLM managers, and field users are met. The training will include which sites should be entered into the database and will also stress the importance of recording timeframes and costs associated with cleanup and remediation. 

OBJECTIVES: Trainees will understand the importance to BLM of using AMSCM to track HazMat and AML site data. Trainees will be able to access AMSCM and enter site data, timeframes and associated site and project costs information into the database and will learn how to attach documentation and photographs to sites. Trainees will also learn how to summarize project cost information, run a Site Summary Report, and access and utilize Site Mapper. 

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS: Requests for interpreters or other special requirements must be received at the NTC no later than 45 days prior to the start of the class. Form can be accessed at: https://www.ntc.blm.gov/krc/uploads/982/Reasonable_Accommodation_Request_Form.pdf 

Keyword: Abandoned Mine Lands, AMSCM, HazMat, AML, Environmental Cleanup, CERCLA, Reclamation,1703-18

TARGET AUDIENCE:  BLM employees who would like to be instructors within their offices/states. BLM employees should be full-time or collateral-duty Hazmat Coordinators and/or have a minimum of 24 hours of OSHA related HazMat training.

This 2-day course is for those who will be teaching First Responder Awareness to other employees. This course teaches content and instructional methods for the First Responder - Awareness Level for field employees.

OBJECTIVES:  By the end of this course each student should be able to provide Awareness Level training in accordance with Bureau policy. 

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS: Requests for interpreters or other special requirements must be received at the NTC no later than 45 days prior to the start of the class. Form can be accessed at: https://www.ntc.blm.gov/krc/uploads/982/Reasonable_Accommodation_Request_Form.pdf 

Keyword: OSHA, Awareness, CERCLA, train the trainer, hazmat, hazardous materials, aml, abandoned mine lands, ISS, instructor seminar, 1703-21

course title: Environmental Site Assessments for Environmental Professionals
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE: BLM employees who are qualified as Environmental Professionals according to 40 CFR Part 312 and involved in ESA completion. You should have three years of full time relevant experience. Relevant experience is defined as performance of ESAs including environmental analysis, investigation, and remediation; understanding of surface and subsurface environmental conditions; knowledge of processes used in evaluations of environmental conditions; ability to develop opinions regarding conditions indicative of a release or threatened release of hazardous substances.

The first two days are taught by ASTM. They teach why the ASTM Environmental Site Assessment Standard Practices for the Phase I Site Assessment and the Transaction Screen Process (E1527-05 and E1528-06) were developed, how to use the standards and how the standards affect the way you do business. 

You will gain an understanding of the "Innocent Landowner Defense" under the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation and Liability Act (CERCLA), and why due diligence is necessary.   The Small Business Liability Relief and Brownfields Revitalization Act of 2002 added two new CERCLA Landowner Liability Protections to the existing Innocent Landowner Defense:

	* Bona Fide Prospective Purchaser

	* Contiguous Property Owner

 The Act also directed USEPA to promulgate a rule containing standards and practices for conducting All Appropriate Inquiries (AAI) for persons seeking to qualify for the three defenses. This new rule was published in the Federal Register on November 1, 2005 and became effective November 1, 2006.  The USEPA has determined that the new ASTM Standard E 1527-05 is in full compliance with the requirements for conducting AAI specified in the recently published EPA rule: Standards for Conducting All Appropriate Inquiries. The last three days cover BLM specific items such as the BLM Manual Handbook H-2000-01 Pre-Acquisition Environmental Site Assessments and the BLM Manual Handbook H-2000-02, Environmental Site Assessments for Disposal of Real Property. In order to pass this class you will need to receive an 80% or better on all assignments and the final exam. 

OBJECTIVES:
- Familiarize students with acquisition and disposal regulatory requirements for ESAs.
- Provide practical discussions, case studies and exercises to allow for the application of course concepts and principles.
- Expose students to different resources that help in the ESA process.

TARGET AUDIENCE:  Any AMSCM user who wants to obtain ad-hoc reports from the AMSCM database. Standard reports may not be adequate for specific needs or data request. Ad-hoc queries can be tailored for specific information 

The Advanced Hyperion for AMSCM class will provide students with the working knowledge about Hyperion ad-hoc query for the AMSCM reporting database. This course will explain the AMSCM database structure. The start of the training will quickly introduce the basics of Hyperion ad-hoc, description of the basic screen and explanation of functionality. Each training exercise will build on more functionality and options. 

OBJECTIVES: Upon completion of the course the user will be able to create, process, and save a Hyperion ad-hoc query. The user should be able to create a highly complex query to retrieve any data stored in the AMSCM database. The formatted results from the query can be saved or copied to other applications: MS Excel, MS Power Point, and MS Word.

Keyword: Hyperion, AMSCM, Abandoned Mine Lands, aml, abandoned mine lands, Reclamation, HazMat, CERCLA, 1703-29

TARGET AUDIENCE: Project Managers, On-Scene Coordinators, Risk Assessment Reviewers, HazMat State Office Program Leads, Full Time and Collateral Duty HazMat Coordinators

This three-day course provides participants with the fundamentals of human health and ecological risk assessment as applied to the Superfund cleanup process. This course is designed to present an introduction to the Superfund risk assessment process to project managers, on-scene coordinators, and risk assessment reviewers working at hazardous waste sites or treatment, storage and disposal facilities. The course assumes little experience with toxicology and risk assessment or knowledge regarding Superfund risk assessment guidance. The course is based on the following EPA documents:

	* Risk Assessment Guidance for Superfund: Volume I - Human Health Evaluation Manual (Parts A, B, C, and D) 

	* Ecological Risk Assessment Guidance for Superfund: Process for Designing and Conducting Ecological Risk Assessments. 

The risk assessment process is presented in an introductory format. The overall goal of the course is for the student to have a good understanding of the risk assessment guidance associated with Superfund. Topics include: baseline risk assessment, preliminary remediation goals; applicable statutes, regulations, and guidance; data collection and evaluation; exposure assessment; toxicity assessment; risk characterization; principles of ecological assessment; ecological risk assessment guidance for Superfund; and ecological data collection methods. Current technical and information resources will also be discussed. Instructional methods include lectures, videos, class discussions, and group exercises. Note: Calculators are highly recommended.

OBJECTIVES: After completing this course, participants will be able to:

	* Describe risk assessment and risk management. 

	* Identify the applicable statutes, regulations, and guidance pertinent to human health and ecological risk assessments under Superfund. 

	* Describe each of the four steps of the risk assessment paradigm. 

	* Describe the eight step process for ecological risk assessment. 

	* Identify and describe similarities and differences between human and ecological risk assessments. 

	* Identify and describe some of the data collection methods specific to ecological risk assessments. 

	* Review a Superfund risk assessment. 

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS: Requests for interpreters or other special requirements must be received at the NTC no later than 45 days prior to the start of the class. Form can be accessed at: https://www.ntc.blm.gov/krc/uploads/982/Reasonable_Accommodation_Request_Form.pdf 

Keyword: HazMat, Hazardous Materials, CERCLA, AMSCAM, Risk Assessment, aml, site characterization, reclamation, risk assessment, environmental sampling, CERCLA, abandoned mine lands, policy, 1703-32

TARGET AUDIENCE: Field, entry-level, and new managers in HAZMAT positions

This course will present an overview of the basic concepts of a screening-level ecological risk assessment (SLERA) developed as part of Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act projects. Fundamentals will cover development of a problem formulation, which includes the discussion of the ecological setting; sources of contaminants; exposure assessment; identification of contaminants of concern; receptor species; conceptual site model; and assessment endpoints, risk-based calculations and risk characterization. Discussion of current methods, benefits, and limitations will be integrated into the course. Additionally, students will gain an understanding of what can be reasonably expected from an Ecological Risk Assessment (ERA), how to communicate project-specific needs with Risk Assessors conducting an ERA, and how the ERA should inform the project management decisions. 

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS: Requests for interpreters or other special requirements must be received at the NTC no later than 45 days prior to the start of the class. Form can be accessed at: https://www.ntc.blm.gov/krc/uploads/982/Reasonable_Accommodation_Request_Form.pdf

course title: Advanced GIS Techniques: ArcGIS Model Builder and Python Scripting
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE: This course is designed for environmental and natural resource professionals who already have a background in GIS, and who want to learn advanced ArcGIS Model Builder and Python techniques to help them automate their workflows for geoprocessing - as well as expand their data analysis capabilities, and begin to automate workflows for ArcMap document management.  YOU SHOULD HAVE INTERMEDIATE TO ADVANCED KNOWLEDGE OF ARCGIS DESKTOP. EXPERIENCE WITH PYTHON SCRIPTING AND MODELBUILDER IS A PLUS, BUT NOT REQUIRED.

Students of this course will explore advanced ArcGIS techniques for geoprocessing, data analysis, and map making. We will work with the ArcGIS 10 geoprocessing framework: ArcToolbox, Model Builder, and Python ArcPy scripting. We will work with some advanced feature class and raster data analysis techniques.  We will work some Python automation techniques for ArcMap document management and map making.

OBJECTIVES: Expected Learning Outcomes are:

	* Use the most current techniques available in the ArcGIS 10 Model Builder software.
	* Use Python scripting language to run ArcGIS geoprocessing workflows.
	* Use Python scripting language to expand the functionality of the ArcGIS field calculator.
	* Expand upon feature class and raster data analysis
	* Python scripting for ArcMap document management

Tuition for BLM students will be paid by the BLM National Training Center.

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS: Requests for interpreters or other special requirements must be received at the NTC no later than 45 days prior to the start of the class. Form can be accessed at: https://www.ntc.blm.gov/krc/uploads/982/Reasonable_Accommodation_Request_Form.pdf

Keyword: 1730-70

TARGET AUDIENCE:  PFC for Professionals is intended for all field staff (new hires and experienced PFC practitioners), who perform riparian/wetland assessments as part of land health standards, range NEPA, or other programmatic efforts. In addition, field managers and supervisors may find the introductory (Monday p.m.) and summary (Friday a.m.) materials especially valuable in work-force planning and in understanding the process by which PFC assessments are integrated into planning, management, implementation, and monitoring programs. 

The PFC for Professionals course uses a combination of small-team coaching, classroom instruction to introduce and study riparian concepts, and field instructions to teach advanced riparian field methods to prepare interdisciplinary teams to conduct PFC assessments. Proper Functioning Condition is an interdisciplinary assessment method that determines condition and trend in riparian areas. Findings from the PFC assessment are used by the interdisciplinary team:

	* to identify management issues, 

	* to identify specific management objectives, 

	* to prioritize management and restoration efforts, 

	* to design management actions to achieve PFC and desired conditions, 

	* to design appropriate monitoring programs including the establishment of properly located designated monitoring areas (DMAs) in riparian areas, and 

	* to implement an informed adaptive management strategy based on monitoring results. Training modules emphasize hands-on exercises and small-team coaching. 

Training modules include:

	* Instructions on performing pre-assessment tasks, such as: a. Sources of pertinent background information and data; b. Techniques for stratification and delineation of stream reaches; and c. Determination of potential natural conditions and identification of altered potential; and 

	* Advanced field methods to quantify or assess each of the 17 lotic (running water) and/or 20 lentic (still water) attributes and processes examined in the PFC assessment method; 

	* A study of various field indicators to determine trend in riparian conditions; 

	* Field practicum with coaching in small, interdisciplinary groups;

	* Instructions on preparing reports to summarize and communicate findings from the assessment; and 

	* Discussion of the integrated riparian management process, which outlines an efficient process for applying PFC assessment information into the development of management goals and objectives, management actions and monitoring program with adaptive management tools. During parts of the course, participants will be divided into smaller groups to learn the skill sets and field methods that are specific to each discipline (i.e., hydrology, vegetation ecology, and geomorphology/soil science).

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS: Requests for interpreters or other special requirements must be received at the NTC no later than 45 days prior to the start of the class. Form can be accessed at: https://www.ntc.blm.gov/krc/uploads/982/Reasonable_Accommodation_Request_Form.pdf

course title: Inspection and Enforcement Certification School-Module 2 Drilling
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE:  THIS MODULE IS LIMITED TO NEWLY HIRED PET POSITIONS ONLY. This course requires attendance and inspection work of ongoing field operations for more than 1/2 the class. You will be required to attend field inspections wearing the proper personnel protective equipment (PPE) during all field trips. Field trips will occur at odd hours throughout the weeks and on weekends. A list of PPE requirements is provided to students prior to each module and includes, but is not limited to: hard hat, hard toed shoes, safety glasses, fire retardant 2112 compliant clothing, and hearing protection. Students must supply their own PPE and must be physically capable of carrying their inspection equipment while bending, stooping, crawling over lines, climbing catwalks, stairwells, etc. Students must be able to perform these tasks in all types of inclement weather. 

Module 2 - Drilling provides instruction on basic drilling principles, federal regulatory responsibilities during the drilling process, enforcement procedures, BOP testing, and engineering calculations used in order to set casing. SUCCESSFUL COMPLETION OF OF MODULE 1 IS MANDATORY BEFORE ACCEPTANCE INTO THIS MODULE. Successful completion of the module fulfills the PET training requirements for a segment of the Inspection Certification program. The Certification School provides a full suite of knowledge, skills, and abilities to perform inspections of petroleum operations on Federal and Indian lands to ensure health, safety, environmental and royalty payment standards are maintained by industry. 

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS: Requests for interpreters or other special requirements must be received at the NTC no later than 45 days prior to the start of the class. Form can be accessed at: https://www.ntc.blm.gov/krc/uploads/982/Reasonable_Accommodation_Request_Form.pdf

description:
TARGET AUDIENCE: All Certified Petroleum Engineering Technicians 

Due to the recent events in the Gulf BLM is conducting mandatory refresher training for all certified PETs on Blow Out Preventer Equipment (BOPE) and casing and cementing inspection requirements in accordance with regulations, approved Application for Permit to Drill and Conditions of Approval (COA). This training will be coordinated and conducted by the NTC and will also serve to satisfy the 5 year WO recertification competency requirements for Drilling Operations for our PETs. The current plan is to conduct the refresher PET training in a two-day session. 

OBJECTIVES:

	* Given BOP/BOPE, determine compliance with Onshore Order #2, the APD and COA, Verbals and Sundries

	* Given an accumulator, determine if the accumulator???s stored fluid volume is adequate to activate the BOPE system according to manufacturer specifications and Onshore Order #2. 

	* Given a BOP/BOPE system being pressure tested, observe the test to ensure compliance with Onshore #2, the APD and COA, Verbals and Sundries.

	* Given an approved APD and a drilling operation, verify that the appropriate casing is being used and cemented correctly (quality and quantity) in accordance Onshore Order #2, the APD and COA, Verbals and Sundries.

This course does not require supervisory approval.

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS: Requests for interpreters or other special requirements must be received at the NTC no later than 45 days prior to the start of the class. Form can be accessed at: https://www.ntc.blm.gov/krc/uploads/982/Reasonable_Accommodation_Request_Form.pdf

description:
This class will provide an in-depth level of professional knowledge for adjudicating field office fluid minerals actions, including examination of the life cycle of a well and the associated field office actions. 

OBJECTIVES: Upon completion of this course, participants will be able to:
1. Associate a sample application with the appropriate case
2. Adjudicate and process a sample NOS in accordance with Onshore Order No. 1
3. Adjudicate and process an Application for Permit to Drill or Reenter (APD)
4. Adjudicate and process sundry notices and reports on wells
5. Process well completion or recompletion reports or logs
6. Process Post Lease actions
7. Adjudicate and process Communitization Agreements
8. Process miscellaneous unit actions
9. Adjudicate and process bond information and bond adequacy reports 

TARGET AUDIENCE: Field Office employees who have at least 6 months experience performing adjudicative actions involved with processing oil and gas activities. Suggested participants include, but are not limited to: land law examiners, conveyance examiners, legal clerks, legal assistants, and others who perform fluid operational adjudication activities.

Keyword: 3100-30

TARGET AUDIENCE:
This is the first module of Course 3800-01. It will be conducted in three modules (A, B, C). Each module is separated by several weeks in-between which the participants return to their home offices.

OBJECTIVES: At the conclusion of this course, the participant will be able to:

	* Prior to mineral examiner certification, with assistance mineral examiner in training candidate will perform mining claim examinations according to Bureau standards.
	* Assess mining claims for the presence of a _discovery_ as defined in the mining laws.
	* Write, or co-write concise, accurate and defensible validity examination reports and surface use determination reports that comply with Bureau standards.
	* Testify as an expert witness in a mining claim validity mock hearing.

SUCCESSFUL COMPLETION OF THIS COURSE REQUIRES THAT PARTICIPANTS COMPLETE ALL CLASSROOM AND FIELDWORK SESSIONS. 
HOMEWORK: There are extensive pre-work and overnight homework reading assignments. In addition there are digital videos that will need to be viewed prior to participation in the class. Participants will also be required to take a written pre-test.

CLASSROOM: There are many full-day classroom sessions requiring the participant to read, analyze, and present findings and conclusions with groups and individually in front of the class. There will also be video to view in the class. Participants are expected to fully participate in all in-class assignments. Participants will be required to sit in the classroom for 60 to 90 minute session, take a short break and then participate in the next 60 to 90 minute session. 

FIELDWORK: This course has extensive fieldwork associated with it that includes walking, hiking, climbing up and down rugged steep terrain. In addition to the surface environments, participants will be required to enter underground operations and surface open pit mines. Access inside these mines requires the participant to climb up and down steeply inclined and vertical ladders. They will also be required to duck, bend and work around mine hazards. All participants will be required to use and wear personal protection equipment such as; hard hats, gloves, safety glasses, hearing protection, safety-toed boots, and more. 

TRANSPORTATION: Participants will be required to travel to field locations in NTC vans or other transportation provided by the NTC. This will require participants to step up into vehicles and maneuver into the appropriate passenger seat and then disembark vehicle multiple times on a single trip. They will also be required to prepare and load personal protection equipment. 

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS: Requests for interpreters or other special requirements must be received at the NTC no later than 45 days prior to the start of the class. Form can be accessed at: https://www.ntc.blm.gov/krc/uploads/982/Reasonable_Accommodation_Request_Form.pdf 

NOTE: ALL PROSPECTIVE PARTICIPANTS IN THE CLASS ARE PLACED ON A WAIT LIST WHEN THEIR SUPERVISOR APPROVES THEIR REGISTRATION. NOTIFICATION OF SELECTION WILL BE SENT OUT APPROXIMATELY 2 MONTHS PRIOR TO THE COURSE START DATE. IF YOU HAVE INTEREST IN THE COURSE PLEASE REVIEW YOUR PARTICIPATION WITH YOUR SUPERVISOR AND REGISTER.

Keyword: BLM-TC-3800-01B, Solid Minerals, Certified Mineral Examiner, Mining, Cost Estimation, Field Work, Mineral Report, Mapping, Sampling, Mining Law, Expert Witness, Resource Estimation

TARGET AUDIENCE:
This is the third module of Course 3800-01. It will be conducted in three modules (A, B, C). Each module is separated by several weeks in-between which the participants return to their home offices.

OBJECTIVES: At the conclusion of this course, the participant will be able to:

	* Prior to mineral examiner certification, with assistance mineral examiner in training candidate will perform mining claim examinations according to Bureau standards.
	* Assess mining claims for the presence of a _discovery_ as defined in the mining laws.
	* Write, or co-write concise, accurate and defensible validity examination reports and surface use determination reports that comply with Bureau standards.
	* Testify as an expert witness in a mining claim validity _mock_ hearing.

SUCCESSFUL COMPLETION OF THIS COURSE REQUIRES THAT PARTICIPANTS COMPLETE ALL CLASSROOM AND FIELDWORK SESSIONS. 
HOMEWORK: There are extensive pre-work and overnight homework reading assignments. In addition there are digital videos that will need to be viewed prior to participation in the class. Participants will also be required to take a written pre-test. 

CLASSROOM: There are many full-day classroom sessions requiring the participant to read, analyze, and present findings and conclusions with groups and individually in front of the class. There will also be video to view in the class. Participants are expected to fully participate in all in-class assignments. Participants will be required to sit in the classroom for 60 to 90 minute session, take a short break and then participate in the next 60 to 90 minute session. 

FIELDWORK: This course has extensive fieldwork associated with it that includes walking, hiking, climbing up and down rugged steep terrain. In addition to the surface environments, participants will be required to enter underground operations and surface open pit mines. Access inside these mines requires the participant to climb up and down steeply inclined and vertical ladders. They will also be required to duck, bend and work around mine hazards. All participants will be required to use and wear personal protection equipment such as; hard hats, gloves, safety glasses, hearing protection, safety-toed boots, and more. 

TRANSPORTATION: Participants will be required to travel to field locations in NTC vans or other transportation provided by the NTC. This will require participants to step up into vehicles and maneuver into the appropriate passenger seat and then disembark vehicle multiple times on a single trip. They will also be required to prepare and load personal protection equipment. 

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS: Requests for interpreters or other special requirements must be received at the NTC no later than 45 days prior to the start of the class. Form can be accessed at: https://www.ntc.blm.gov/krc/uploads/982/Reasonable_Accommodation_Request_Form.pdf 

NOTE: ALL PROSPECTIVE PARTICIPANTS IN THE CLASS ARE PLACED ON A WAIT LIST WHEN THEIR SUPERVISOR APPROVES THEIR REGISTRATION. NOTIFICATION OF SELECTION WILL BE SENT OUT APPROXIMATELY 2 MONTHS PRIOR TO THE COURSE START DATE. IF YOU HAVE INTEREST IN THE COURSE PLEASE REVIEW YOUR PARTICIPATION WITH YOUR SUPERVISOR AND REGISTER.

Mapping, sampling, processing, and economic evaluation of precious metal alluvial placer deposits:

 Participants will be expected to be proficient in building and using simple to moderate Microsoft Excel spreadsheets. NTC pays travel and per diem costs for BLM participants within the target group. Keywords: 3800-04, Solid Minerals, Certified Mineral Examiner, Placers, Mining, Cost Estimation, Field Work, Mineral Report, Mapping, Sampling

Advanced-level course that covers the principles of discovery, marketability, and economic evaluations for industrial minerals and validity examination procedures.

	* Case law and land status.

Key words: 3800-05, Solid Minerals, Certified Mineral Examiner, Mining, Cost Estimation, Field Work, Mineral Report, Mapping, Sampling, Mining Law, Resource Estimation, Industrial Minerals

TARGET AUDIENCE:
Standards and methods for writing and reviewing mineral reports for locatable minerals actions, primarily for mineral patent and mining claim validity.

	* Mining Law update, including recent Solicitor Opinions.
	* Report standards, including logic, clarity, readability, and content.
	* Dealing with confidential information.
	* How to make a report right the first time, without repeated technical reviews.
	* Technical Review Steps.
	* What to do when you disagree with the reviewer.
	* The changing role of the WO Solicitor's Office.
	* Recent case histories.
	* The costs of doing it wrong.
	* What the Solicitor's Office Needs for a Contest.

OBJECTIVES:  At the conclusion of this course, the participant will be able to write and review a mineral report for:

	* Compliance with applicable standards.
	* Conformity with law, policy, and regulation.
	* Technical adequacy.

 Successful completion of this course requires that participants complete all classroom sessions.

CLASSROOM: This is a full-day classroom course requiring the participant to read, analyze, and present findings and conclusions with groups and individually in front of the class. Participants are expected to fully participate in all in-class assignments. Participants will be required to sit in the classroom for 60 to 90 minute session, take a short break and then participate in the next 60 to 90 minute session.

Keywords: 3800-08, Solid Minerals, Mineral Reports, Technical Writing, Mining Law

TARGET AUDIENCE: Federal employees involved in cases relating to mining law.

Case law involving the 1872 Mining Law and its amendments will be presented in case study style and will include cases through the most recent applicable IBLA decisions.

OBJECTIVES: At the end of the course the participant will be familiar with past and current mining law, and will be able to make more informed case-by-case decisions based on the findings presented.

NOTE: Completion of this class alone does not exempt participants from attending any part of the Solid Minerals Academy if they choose to do so in the future, as case law is constantly updated.

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS: Requests for interpreters or other special requirements must be received at the NTC no later than 45 days prior to the start of the class. Form can be accessed at: https://www.ntc.blm.gov/krc/uploads/982/Reasonable_Accommodation_Request_Form.pdf

Keyword: 3800-20, ??

TARGET AUDIENCE: Hydrologists, geologists, mining engineers, petroleum engineers and other resource professionals who deal with ground water issues

This is a technical short course providing instruction in a wide range of topics including basic concepts of hydrogeology, techniques of evaluating the occurrence and movement of ground water, contaminant transport in ground water flow systems, geochemistry, and surface water/ground water interactions. Hydrogeologic principles will be applied to practical problems in water resource evaluations, stock water supply drilling locations, water quality, and riparian ground water issues.

OBJECTIVES:  Upon completion of this class, student will be able to: 

	* Determine groundwater environment and interpret data for resource actions plans 

	* Review composition and principles of groundwater characteristics

	* Recognize impacts on groundwater of energy sources, minerals, hazardous materials

	* Use groundwater prediction models

	* Design and construction of water wells

	* Identify groundwater issues

	* Calculate groundwater flow

	* Predict groundwater occurrence, movement and geochemistry 

	* Identify well drilling methods, water sampling and monitoring techniques 

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS: Requests for interpreters or other special requirements must be received at the NTC no later than 45 days prior to the start of the class. Form can be accessed at: https://www.ntc.blm.gov/krc/uploads/982/Reasonable_Accommodation_Request_Form.pdf 

Keyword: 3700-08; 7000-18, ground water

course title: Introduction to the Soil, Water, and Air Program
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE:  BLM field staff with responsibility for the SWA program in their office with less than 5 years experience in the program

This course will enable the student to identify the major legislation, regulations, policies, and processes that apply to soil, water, and air issues facing BLM decision-makers in their management of the public lands. The student will learn how to acquire and analyze soil, water, and air resource data for input to the decision making process. The student will also learn how to communicate this information in a variety of settings ranging from interdisciplinary teams to top-level agency officials, as well as interested publics and staff from other state and federal agencies. Finally, this course is foundational to new staff in this program in that it will communicate training paths and opportunities for additional development as technical subject-matter specialists. Course is intended for BLM employees only, therefore, no tuition will be charged. 

OBJECTIVES:  Following completion of this course, students will be able to develop, manage, and implement a SWA program that responds to the legal, technical, social, and political circumstances that influence management decisions.

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS: Requests for interpreters or other special requirements must be received at the NTC no later than 45 days prior to the start of the class. Form can be accessed at: https://www.ntc.blm.gov/krc/uploads/982/Reasonable_Accommodation_Request_Form.pdf 

Keyword: 7000-01, swa, introduction to soil, introduction to air, introduction to water

TARGET AUDIENCE:  This entry level course is for anyone who wants to become more familiar with the Act and the regulations. It is also for anyone working with proposals requiring NEPA analysis and documentation.
DESCRIPTION:  Welcome to the NEPA Concepts course! It includes an overview of the National Environmental Policy Act (Module 1) and an introduction to the Council on Environmental Quality (CEQ) regulations to implement NEPA (Module 2).

Module 1 includes the background of NEPA, vision and intent of NEPA, and NEPA's marching orders. Module 2 includes the background of the CEQ regulations, public involvement, producing better decisions, and tools and documents.

course title: Hazard Management and Resource Restoration (HMRR) and Abandoned Mine Land (AML) Programs: Project Management
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE:   This course is intended for BLM employees, especially the project manager or others in a management role, who conduct environmental cleanup, natural resource restoration, and physical safety hazard remediation, of medium to long-term or complex projects.

DESCRIPTION:  Through an introduction, overview, and detailed description of what a project life cycle entails, including the four stages of project management, the student will learn the purpose and goals of project management

By identifying and describing responsibilities for BLM project managers, this course will help ensure projects are completed in an efficient and cost-effective manner, and that they comply with all appropriate laws, regulations, and policies.

TARGET AUDIENCE: BLM Managers responsible to manage oil and gas resources in their area.

COURSE IS FOR BLM EMPLOYEES ONLY. It is not a public course.

DESCRIPTION: This course provides upper level management with the knowledge and skills necessary to effectively manage and conduct oversight of BLM’s oil and gas program.

The course consists of multiple modules and links to existing distance learning courses related to the oil and gas program. These modules are built to be taken in sequential order.

	*
Introduction to Oil and Gas
	*
Adventures in Energy (Course 3100-12)
	*
Planning for Oil and Gas
	*
Leasing 101
	*
American Indian Issues (currently under development)
	*
Oil and Gas Operations (currently under development)
	*
Inspection and Enforcement (currently under development)
	*
Resource Conflicts (currently under development)

During the online segments, the user should follow along with the supplemental Participant Guide that may be downloaded at the beginning of each module. There are review questions built into the course modules in order for you to gauge your learning.

There are also Student OJT assignments at the end of each topic module that will assist you in gaining the information necessary for you to provide oversight and effectively manage the oil and gas program in your area.

COURSE OBJECTIVES:

	*
Make effective management decisions based on the laws, regulations, and policies which apply to oil and gas operational approvals on Federal lands.
	* Discuss mission critical considerations used in analyzing Federal oil and gas operational requests.
	* Describing effective management practices.
	* Become familiar with the oil and gas industry and scientific use of cutting-edge technologies and environmental practices.
	* Gain a broad knowledge base of oil and gas operations to facilitate effective management of these resources.
	* Be able to conduct program oversight on how and which lands should be eligible for oil and gas leasing.
	*
Be able to identify authorities & policies covering leasing, explain how to review, post and conduct lease sales, and manage awarding of leases and non-competitive lease offerings.

COMPETENCIES ADDRESSED ARE:
Develop & Issue Federal Fluid Mineral Leases
Manage Enforcement Actions
Safety Management
Resource Conflict Management
Manage Lease Operations
rank 5 competency: Grants Management Laws, Regulations, and Guidelines

description:
TARGET AUDIENCE:  BLM Managers responsible to manage oil and gas resources in their area.

COURSE IS FOR BLM EMPLOYEES ONLY.  It is not a public course.

DESCRIPTION:  This course provides upper level management with the knowledge and skills necessary to effectively manage and conduct oversight of BLM’s oil and gas program.

The course consists of multiple modules and links to existing distance learning courses related to the oil and gas program. These modules are built to be taken in sequential order.

	*
 Native American Issues (approximately 1 hr.)
	*
Oil and Gas Operations (approximately 4-5 hrs.)
	*
Inspection and Enforcement Oversight (approximately 6-8 hrs.)
	*
Resource Conflicts (approximately 1 hr.)

There are review questions built into the course modules in order for you to gauge your learning. Additionally, in order to get credit for completing the each module you will need to open the “test” and indicate that you have completed the material before moving on to the next module.

COURSE OBJECTIVES:

By the end of this module each manager will be able to define Indian trust and describe BLM’s obligations as a trustee;

	*
Differentiate between the management of Indian oil and gas from Federal oil and gas.
	*
Explain the main aspects of Self-Determination Act contracting.
	*
Given a scenario involving oil and gas lease operations, determine if the process for assessing and administering the approval of proposed oil and gas developments is being followed based on the requirements outlined in the Onshore Orders and 43 CFR 3160.
	*
Given a case study involving oversight of I & E actions at a field office, determine if national policy is being followed in accordance with the regulations and National I&E policy.
	*
Given a case study involving the development of an I&E matrix (and the matrix itself), determine if pertinent developmental actions were followed and if the matrix is accurate based the variables and data contained in the case study.
	*
Given a resource conflict case study, determine which management questions must be asked in order to obtain the required information needed to resolve the conflict based on BLM policies affecting the resource(s) and standardized managerial questions taught in this Module.

Competencies addressed are:

Manage Indian Trust Operations
Manage Lease Operations
Manage Enforcement Actions
Safety Management
Resource Conflict Management

course title: Writing and Issuing Written Orders and Incidents of Noncompliance for Environmental/Surface
description:
Techniques and Business Practices for properly writing and issuing Written Orders and Incidents of Noncompliance for surface management of Oil and Gas exploration and development activities. Successful completion of this course requires that participants complete all distance learning, as PASS A FINAL TEST WITH AT LEAST A 80% AT THE END OF THE COURSE.

DURATION: This is a self-paced distance learning course that should take approximately 6-8 hour to complete.

COURSE GOAL: Upon successful completion of this course each participant should be able to: 

Write an Incident of Non-Compliance (INC) or Order of the Authorized Officer to implement an enforcement action.

OBJECTIVES: In order to reach the course goal, each participant should be able to:

	* cite applicable authorities and regulatory requirements,
	* select appropriate enforcement tool(s) and implement enforcement action(s), and
	* properly document the inspection and enforcement action(s).

COURSEWORK: This course consists of three distance learning modules(estimated 6-8 hours total) and the students must pass the post-test with an 80% or higher score to attend the field based course.
rank 3 competency: Grants Management Laws, Regulations, and Guidelines

course title: Oil and Gas Reservoir Drainage Analysis
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE:  Petroleum Engineers and Geologists who are conducting reservoir drainage analysis

Reservoir Drainage Analysis utilizing IHS PowerTools and the BLM Handbook MS-3160 - Drainage Protection Manual

OBJECTIVES:  Resolve potential oil and gas reservoir drainage situations.
1. Identify BLM’s authority to resolve drainage situations.
2. Determine resources available to resolve drainage situations
3. Recognize potential drainage situations.
4. Determine if an administrative, geologic, engineering, and/or economic review are required.
5. Calculate drainage to determine if physical draining is occurring across a spacing unit boundary.
6. Review drainage documentation to determine if it will resolve the drainage situation.

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS: Requests for interpreters or other special requirements must be received at the NTC no later than 45 days prior to the start of the class.  Form can be accessed at:  https://www.ntc.blm.gov/krc/uploads/982/Reasonable_Accommodation_Request_Form.pdf

Keyword: 3100-07

TO ATTEND THIS COURSE, YOU MUST BE A CERTIFIED PET IN THE GS-0802 SERIES WORKING FOR BLM OR AS A TRIBAL INSPECTOR UNDER A 638 OR COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT.  

SELF-ENROLLMENT IS NOT ALLOWED.  Enrollment into classes is completed by the NTC contact person shown for this course, below.  Certified personnel will be contacted when refresher courses are available.  The topic of the refresher course will be indicated in the class title for course 3100-11.

TARGET AUDIENCE:  Certified PETs who have not had formal training within the last five years. NTC is paying for student attendance, supervisor permission is not necessary for travel approval.This is a refresher training class for certified Petroleum Engineering Technicians that must complete training on a specified time frame to maintain their certification.  

This 2-1/2 to 3-day course covers topics related to inspection and enforcement of oil and gas operations on federal and Indian leases that are required for certification maintenance every five years as outlined in the Certification Handbook for Oil and Gas Inspection and Enforcement Personnel.   Each class will be specific to one topic, i.e., drilling, plugging, or oil and gas production measurement operations. 

The course will cover a variety of topics, including:

	* PET job responsibilities during oil and gas operations

	* Independently determine operational compliance with regulatory requirements and API standards. 

	* Correctly calculate volumes and proper methods of measurement during operations per approvals

	* Correctly document the witnessing of operations as required using mandatory and supplemental forms

	* Determine the correct types of enforcement actions to use during operations.

There will be a pre-course assessment at the beginning of the course. Course participants will also be administered a post-course assessment to validate basic certification competency standards as required by policy.

OBJECTIVES: By the end of this course, each student will be able to witness and ensure oil and gas operations are in compliance with applicable oil and gas regulations and API standards.

Upon completion of the course, the student will be able to:

	* Discuss an overview of PET’s responsibilities for the applicable operation

	* Correctly calculate volumes and proper methods of measurement during operations per approvals

	* Correctly document the witnessing of operations as required using mandatory and supplemental forms

	* Determine the correct types of enforcement actions to use during operations.

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS: Requests for interpreters or other special requirements must be received at the NTC no later than 45 days prior to the start of the class.  Form can be accessed at:  https://www.ntc.blm.gov/krc/uploads/982/Reasonable_Accommodation_Request_Form.pdf

Keyword: 3100-11, Oil and Gas, Natural Resource Management

course title: Inspection and Enforcement Certification School-Module 4 Oil
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE: THIS MODULE IS LIMITED TO NEWLY HIRED PET POSITIONS ONLY.

SUCCESSFUL COMPLETION OF MODULE 1 IS MANDATORY BEFORE ACCEPTANCE INTO THIS MODULE. 

Module 4 - Oil Measurement of the I&E Certification School provides instruction on various oil measurement techniques, regulatory requirements regarding oil production, handling, and sales, as well as site security requirements. Applicable enforcement applications and inspection documentation requirements will also be covered. Successful completion of this segment of the Certification School fulfills a portion of the requirement PET training in order to gain Inspection Certification. The Certification School provides a full suite of knowledge, skills, and abilities to perform inspections of petroleum operations on Federal and Indian lands to ensure health, safety, environmental and royalty payment standards are maintained by industry.

This course requires attendance and inspection work of ongoing field operations for more than 1/2 the class. You will be required to attend field inspections wearing the proper personnel protective equipment (PPE) during all field trips. Field trips will occur at odd hours throughout the weeks and on weekends. A list of PPE requirements is provided to students prior to each module and includes, but is not limited to: hard hat, hard toed shoes, safety glasses, fire retardant 2112 compliant clothing, and hearing protection. Students must supply their own PPE and must be physically capable of carrying their inspection equipment while bending, stooping, crawling over lines, climbing catwalks, stairwells, etc. Students must be able to perform these tasks in all types of inclement weather.

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS: Requests for interpreters or other special requirements must be received at the NTC no later than 45 days prior to the start of the class. Form can be accessed at: https://www.ntc.blm.gov/krc/uploads/982/Reasonable_Accommodation_Request_Form.pdf

Keyword: 3100-01M4, Oil and Gas, Natural Resource Management

course title: BLM IHS Basic PowerTools for Drainage Analysis
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE:  Petroleum Engineers and Geologists performing reservoir drainage analysis.

IHS will demonstrate their powertool software and its use in performing drainage calculations.  This is webinar-delivered training.

OBJECTIVES:  To perform basic drainage calculations utilizing the Powertools software

This course is a prerequisite for Oil and Gas Reservoir Drainage Analysis course, 3100-07 but may be attended by those not attending 3100-07.

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS: Requests for interpreters or other special requirements must be received at the NTC no later than 45 days prior to the start of the class.  Form can be accessed at:  https://www.ntc.blm.gov/krc/uploads/982/Reasonable_Accommodation_Request_Form.pdf

Keyword: 3100-03

TARGET AUDIENCE:   

· Resource specialists including water, range, wildlife, fisheries, realty, minerals, wilderness, recreation, and planning

· BLM District and Field managers; State Office program managers

· Forest Supervisors and District Rangers

· Other Bureau of Land Management and U.S. Forest Service staff with an interest in water rights are welcome.

COURSE NOTE:  Please refer to course flyer.

The course goal is to review and discuss approaches for securing, maintaining, managing and protecting water rights associated with public land management. Based on a review of case studies as well as specific instruction in California and federal water law, participants will review, discuss, and apply alternatives for securing water rights that will protect a diversity of water-dependent values.

OBJECTIVES:

To meet federal land management objectives, discuss and apply alternatives for securing and maintaining water rights including:

	* Identify when you need to file for a water right to support land management and project objectives.
	* If a water right is needed, identify which process is most appropriate to rely upon – filing under California water law procedures or reliance on a claim for a federal reserved right. Options include riparian right, pre-1914 right, post-1914 state appropriative right, exempt use or federal reserved water right.
	* Understand processes used to administer existing water rights including water use reporting, seeking enforcement against other users, avoiding forfeiture and reviewing public notices of water rights filed by other parties.
	* Identify the steps and processes necessary to address water rights in federal land management actions. These actions may include development and use of water (from    wells, springs, reservoirs, etc), administrative uses (fire-fighting, road maintenance, etc.), land exchanges, acquisitions/disposals, rights-of-way/special use permits and authorizing mineral/energy developments.
	* Identify the types of qualitative and quantitative inventory information of water sources necessary to secure, amend, maintain, and protect a water right.
	* Develop collaborative strategies for maintaining instream flow and flow-dependent habitat values.
	* Understand when and how to participate in processes established by the California Sustainable Groundwater Act to protect groundwater resources.

ADDITIONAL NOTES:

	* The Regional Solicitor’s Office and Office of General Counsel will participate as part of the instructor cadre.
	* The training sessions will include field work on two half-days. Participants are to wear appropriate clothing and to bring a lunch.
	* Managers are encouraged to attend at least the first 2½ days of this training.

PREREQUISITES:

1.  Complete the METED course: Understanding the Hydrologic Cycle– “Groundwater” module.

You must create an account at https://www.meted.ucar.edu/sign_in.php  Under Supervisor/Instructor Email, please enter Jolene Robertson’s email address:  JTROBERT@BLM.GOV Your results will be emailed to her, indicating you have completed the prerequisite.

Once you have an account, go to the groundwater module at: https://www.meted.ucar.edu/hydro/basic_int/hydrologic_cycle/navmenu.php?tab=1&page=5.0.0 

2.  Complete a Pre-Assessment which will provide instructors your concerns/issues and measure of your knowledge. You will be sent a link to the Pre-Assessment by the class instructor.

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS: Requests for interpreters or other special requirements must be received at the NTC no later than 45 days prior to the start of the class.  Form can be accessed at:  https://www.ntc.blm.gov/krc/uploads/982/Reasonable_Accommodation_Request_Form.pdf

Keyword: 1730-26,  water right, water law

﻿TARGET AUDIENCE: ﻿ Experienced GIS users who wish expand their knowledge of working with imagery and remote sensing data

Learn best practices and workflows to enhance visualization and extract meaningful information from satellite imagery, Lidar, and other remotely sensed data. This course covers dynamic raster processing options available in ArcGIS and takes you on an in-depth exploration of image classification.

﻿PRE-REQUISITES:  ﻿Completion of ArcGIS 2: Essential Workflows or Using ArcGIS for Geospatial Intelligence or equivalent knowledge.

course title: Configuring Web Apps Using Web AppBuilder
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE:  experienced GIS users who wish to learn more about building web-based applications using Esri's Web Appbuilder platform.

Learn how to easily create intuitive, focused web apps that are accessible on desktop and mobile devices—without writing any code.

This course shows how to take advantage of existing web maps, themes, and widgets to build apps that feature your organization's branding and deliver the functionality your users require.

REQUIRED PRE-REQUISITE:  Completion of Creating and Sharing GIS Content with ArcGIS Online or equivalent knowledge.

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS: Requests for interpreters or other special requirements must be received at the NTC no later than 45 days prior to the start of the class.  Form can be accessed at:  https://www.ntc.blm.gov/krc/uploads/982/Reasonable_Accommodation_Request_Form.pdf

For additional details on the course as provided by ESRI, please visit the following link:  https://www.esri.com/training/catalog/57f4505e362fd58367ab5302/configuring-web-apps-using-web-appbuilder-for-arcgis/

course title: Deploying and Maintaining a Multiuser Geodatabase
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE:  Highly experienced GIS users who will be performing enterprise database administration, such as Database Owners (DBO) and/or Database Administrators (DBA).

Prepare to successfully create a multiuser geodatabase to store and manage your organization's geographic data. Learn about the multiuser geodatabase architecture, configuration options, and techniques to efficiently load data, assign user privileges, and maintain performance over time. Course concepts apply to ArcGIS 10.3, 10.4, and 10.5. Esri will provide ArcGIS 10.5 software for use during class. During course exercises, you may work with the RDBMS product that is relevant for your organization (Oracle Database 11g Express Edition, Microsoft SQL Server, or PostgreSQL).

REQUIRED PRE-REQUISITES:  Completion of ArcGIS 2: Essential Workflows or equivalent knowledge and experience managing a relational database management system.

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS: Requests for interpreters or other special requirements must be received at the NTC no later than 45 days prior to the start of the class.  Form can be accessed at:  https://www.ntc.blm.gov/krc/uploads/982/Reasonable_Accommodation_Request_Form.pdf

For additional details on the course as provided by Esri, please visit the following link:  https://www.esri.com/training/catalog/57630436851d31e02a43f104/deploying-and-maintaining-a-multiuser-geodatabase/

course title: Transitioning from ArcMap to ArcGIS Pro: Introduction to ArcGIS Pro 2.x
description:
PREREQUISITES / INTENDED AUDIENCE:  At a bare minimum students should have a working knowledge of GIS concepts and spatial data. The course is primarily intended for ArcMap practitioners who have been using ArcMap in some capacity for at least a year. This hands-on course is intended for environmental professionals involved in the collection, interpretation, and presentation of spatially related data. Attendees will learn the uses and capabilities of ARCGIS PRO by working first-hand on a variety of sample scenarios.

This 2-day, hands-on class introduces participants to ESRI's new ARCGIS PRO software. The course is aimed primarily at experienced ArcMap users but provides sufficient background (particularly in the printed manual) for both novice and experienced GIS users. The course provides a brief discussion of general concepts and vocabulary as a foundation for a comprehensive overview of ArcGIS Pro’s functions and uses. Each participant will have their own computer workstation to create, edit, display and analyze real world environmental data during numerous hands-on exercises. Course exercises build from foundation concepts to increasingly complex spatial analysis and in-depth projects, highlighting both the similarities and the differences between ArcMap and ArcGIS Pro.

_CLICK THE COURSE NAME FOR LIST OF OBJECTIVES_

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS: Requests for interpreters or other special requirements must be received at the NTC no later than 45 days prior to the start of the class.  Form can be accessed at:  https://www.ntc.blm.gov/krc/uploads/982/Reasonable_Accommodation_Request_Form.pdf

TARGET AUDIENCE:  Experienced ArcMap users that want to learn more about performing analysis using GIS.

Learn a standard workflow you can apply to any spatial analysis project. You will perform different types of analyses to efficiently create reliable results that support informed decision making. This course uses ArcGIS for Desktop Advanced (ArcMap) and some exercises use tools in the ArcGIS Spatial Analyst extension.

_Note: _Course concepts apply to ArcGIS Desktop 10.4, 10.5, and 10.6. Esri will provide ArcGIS 10.6 software for use during class.

OBJECTIVES:  

	* AUTOMATE analysis tasks using geoprocessing models.

	* CREATE a weighted suitability model to select the optimal location for a new site.

	* APPLY spatial statistics to examine distribution patterns and identify hot spots.

	* MODEL temporal data to analyze and visualize change over time.

For additional details on the course as provided by Esri, please visit the provided URL:  https://www.esri.com/training/catalog/57630435851d31e02a43efbb/arcgis-3:-performing-analysis/

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS: Requests for interpreters or other special requirements must be received at the NTC no later than 45 days prior to the start of the class.  Form can be accessed at:  https://www.ntc.blm.gov/krc/uploads/982/Reasonable_Accommodation_Request_Form.pdf

course title: Migrating from ArcMap to ArcGIS Pro
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE:  Highly experienced ArcMap users who are planning to transition to ArcGIS Pro.

With faster tools and integrated 2D and 3D capabilities, ArcGIS Pro will streamline your GIS projects. This course prepares experienced ArcMap users to be productive right away. Learn essential ArcGIS Pro terminology and concepts and how to efficiently complete a variety of tasks related to mapping, editing, analyzing, and sharing geospatial data and resources.

OBJECTIVES:  

	* CREATE an ArcGIS Pro project and import map documents and 3D scenes.

	* CREATE and modify map symbology and layouts.

	* IMPORT a geoprocessing model and identify potential migration issues.

	* SHARE geospatial resources to an ArcGIS Online organizational site or on-premises ArcGIS portal.

For additional details on the course as provided by Esri, please visit the provided URL:  https://www.esri.com/training/catalog/59161f89dfcdee7bac39d5b3/migrating-from-arcmap-to-arcgis-pro/

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS: Requests for interpreters or other special requirements must be received at the NTC no later than 45 days prior to the start of the class.  Form can be accessed at:  https://www.ntc.blm.gov/krc/uploads/982/Reasonable_Accommodation_Request_Form.pdf

TARGET AUDIENCE:  Participants for this training generally include resource specialists, team leaders, decisionmakers, writers and editors, and other agency professionals who already have some NEPA experience and must understand the existing and changing law, policies, procedures and guidance related to efforts to improve the efficiency of the NEPA process to fully execute their responsibilities.

Participants in this intermediate-advanced level workshop will learn techniques to improve their efficiency in implementing the NEPA process. As NEPA practitioners are aware, a long-standing and frequent criticism of NEPA is that it, “takes too long, and costs too much.” Measures to address these concerns have included new administration and internal agency policies, and legislative proposals to expedite the NEPA process. The two main focuses of these efforts are implementing timelines to substantially shortening completion of NEPA reviews; and, setting maximum page limits for Environmental Assessments (EAs) and Environmental Impact Statements (EISs). This workshop begins with a comprehensive review of NEPA basics, followed by techniques and best practices to improve agencies’ efficiency in completing the NEPA process. A range of best practices includes improving project management, scoping, decision making, defining proposal scope and scale, adaptive management, interagency coordination processes, and writing, will be discussed.  We will draw on information from CEQ Regulations and guidance, NEPA case law, and federal agency case studies. Agency-specific tailored workshops will concentrate on the agency’s NEPA policies and procedures and specific techniques to improve efficiencies tied to them.

OBJECTIVES:  

	* Understand the existing statutory and regulatory policies regarding page limits, time limits, and other relevant aspects of NEPA document preparation.
	* Apply approaches and techniques for improving the efficiency of the NEPA process.
	* Use lessons from recent case law to prepare NEPA documents in a more efficient manner.
	* Use the scoping process and improved interagency cooperation to improve the efficiency of NEPA reviews.
	* Use writing and document organization techniques to prepare more useful and compliant NEPA analyses and documents.
rank 3 competency: Grants Management Laws, Regulations, and Guidelines

description:
TARGET AUDIENCE:  Participants for this training generally include resource specialists, external and/or contracted resource specialists, team leaders, decisionmakers, and other agency professionals who must understand the NEPA process to fully execute their responsibilities.

To prepare resource specialists (e.g. range specialists, hydrologists, cultural resource specialists) to actively and meaningfully participate in the NEPA process from inception through completion. 

OBJECTIVES:  Upon completion of this workshop, participants will be able:

	* To understand how to actively and meaningfully participate in the NEPA process from inception through completion.
	* To integrate resource information and impact analyses from specialists into the NEPA process and NEPA documents.
	* To identify team and agency expectations for resource information in NEPA documents: Categorical Exclusions, EAs, or EISs, along with their associated decision documents.
	* To match a resource specialist’s tasks to the scope and timeline for a NEPA process.
	* To coordinate information from a resource specialist with project details: for example, purpose and need language, issue identification, and design decisions about a range of reasonable alternatives.
	* To develop quality criteria for adequate baseline conditions and parallel impact projections of future conditions.
	* To identify techniques for recording both baseline conditions and impact projections (especially the comparison information in the traditional NEPA Chapter 2).
	* To plan for specialists to contribute to project scoping and ongoing scoping information, especially suggestions from the public dealing with potential impact questions.
	* To coordinate information from overlapping or related resources so that the NEPA process moves along efficiently.
	* To set quality expectations as to the extent of the literature review, both from a resource perspective and from the role of such information in an efficient NEPA analysis process.
	* To link a resource specialist’s responsibilities in regard to the legal tests of a “hard look” at possible impacts and a “good faith” effort to contribute to a legally adequate NEPA analysis.
	* To assess the differences between a single resource specialist’s information and the necessary team decisions relating to the overall NEPA analysis process.
	* To survey practices and procedures for collaborative review of all specialist reports and then to identify quality criteria for assessing each specialist’s contributions to the overall process.
	* To discuss feedback strategies for assessing the overall team success in making NEPA an efficient process and in creating a quality NEPA document.

course title: ArcGIS 4: Sharing Content on the Web
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE:  Experienced GIS users who want to learn more about accessing and publishing web-based data in Esri's online platform.

COURSE DESCRIPTION:  Learn to share geographic content, making it accessible to everyone who needs it, when and how they want to access it. This course teaches how to publish your organization's authoritative GIS data, maps, and tools as services that can be discovered on your organization's public or private ArcGIS portal, easily accessed from desktop and online applications, and featured in web and mobile apps.

For additional details on the course as provided by Esri, please visit the provided URL:  https://www.esri.com/training/catalog/57630434851d31e02a43ef31/arcgis-4:-sharing-content-on-the-web/

COURSE OBJECTIVES: 

	* DETERMINE which sharing option is appropriate for your needs.
	* AUTHOR and publish map, feature, geoprocessing, and image services.
	* SHARE GIS resources as stand-alone services and in web maps and apps.

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS: Requests for interpreters or other special requirements must be received at the NTC no later than 45 days prior to the start of the class.  Form can be accessed at:  https://www.ntc.blm.gov/krc/uploads/982/Reasonable_Accommodation_Request_Form.pdf

course title: Implementing Versioned Workflows in a Multiuser Geodatabase
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE:  Highly experienced GIS users who will be performing enterprise database administration, such as Database Owners (DBO) and/or Database Administrators (DBA).

COURSE DESCRIPTION:  Learn a sound versioning workflow that minimizes disruption to editors, ensures the integrity of your organization's GIS data, and integrates well with existing business workflows. This course explores a variety of versioned editing workflows and examines how versioning decisions impact data accuracy and database performance.

For additional details on the course as provided by Esri, please visit the provided URL: https://www.esri.com/training/catalog/57630435851d31e02a43ef9c/implementing-versioned-workflows-in-a-multiuser-geodatabase/

COURSE OBJECTIVES:  

	* DESIGN a versioning workflow that meets your organization's needs.
	* LOAD DATA into a versioned feature class.
	* MANAGE multiple geodatabase versions.
	* MONITOR and MAINTAIN database performance in a versioned editing environment.

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS: Requests for interpreters or other special requirements must be received at the NTC no later than 45 days prior to the start of the class.  Form can be accessed at:  https://www.ntc.blm.gov/krc/uploads/982/Reasonable_Accommodation_Request_Form.pdf

TARGET AUDIENCE:  Highly experienced GIS users who will be performing enterprise database administration, such as Database Owners (DBO) and/or Database Administrators (DBA)

COURSE DESCRIPTION:  This course teaches best practices to plan and implement geodatabase replication to support multiuser editing workflows and data-sharing initiatives. Learn how to protect the integrity and performance of your production database while meeting the needs of desktop, mobile, and online users. This course is taught using ArcMap. 

For additional details on the course as provided by Esri, please visit the provided URL:  https://www.esri.com/training/catalog/57630435851d31e02a43ef90/distributing-data-using-geodatabase-replication/

COURSE OBJECTIVES:

	* DETERMINE the number and type of replicas needed to support your organization's GIS workflows.
	* PLAN a synchronization strategy for replicated data.

	* MANAGE schema changes between replicas.

	* USE a geodata service in a web application to create a replica and synchronize edits.

 SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS: Requests for interpreters or other special requirements must be received at the NTC no later than 45 days prior to the start of the class.  Form can be accessed at:  https://www.ntc.blm.gov/krc/uploads/982/Reasonable_Accommodation_Request_Form.pdf

course title: User Workflows for ArcGIS Online Organizations
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE:  Experienced GIS users who want to learn more about accessing and manipulating web-based data in Esri's online platform.

COURSE DESCRIPTION:  This workshop introduces web maps, apps, and other authoritative content that may be available through your ArcGIS Online organizational site. You will see how this content helps you infuse your projects with geographic context, additional business intelligence, and visual impact. The instructor shows how to create and share web maps on an organizational site and from within Microsoft Excel. Concepts also apply to an ArcGIS Enterprise organizational portal.

The instructor will present conceptual information and demonstrate realistic scenarios and typical workflows to discover, use, create, and share web maps and apps. Interactive question and answer sessions will be held throughout the workshop, and you are encouraged to ask the instructor about the topics covered and related questions. The workshop includes a downloadable reference document (PDF) and certificate of completion.

For additional details on the course as provided by Esri, please visit the provided URL:  https://www.esri.com/training/catalog/57630435851d31e02a43f01f/user-workflows-for-arcgis-online-organizations

COURSE OBJECTIVES:

	* CREATE and style a web map.
	* USE TEMPLATES to style and configure a web app.
	* USE WEB MAPS in Microsoft Office applications.
	* SHARE maps and other content on your ArcGIS Online organizational site.

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS: Requests for interpreters or other special requirements must be received at the NTC no later than 45 days prior to the start of the class.  Form can be accessed at:  https://www.ntc.blm.gov/krc/uploads/982/Reasonable_Accommodation_Request_Form.pdf

course title: Introduction to Geoprocessing Scripts Using Python
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE:  Experienced GIS users wanting to learn advanced Python techniques to help automate their workflows for geoprocessing and to expand their data analysis capabilities.

COURSE DESCRIPTION:  Reduce the time spent on complex and repetitive workflows, so you can focus on GIS work that can't be automated. This course teaches how to create Python scripts for key ArcGIS workflows and share them so they are accessible to others.

For additional details on the course as provided by Esri, please visit the provided URL:  https://www.esri.com/training/catalog/57630435851d31e02a43f054/introduction-to-geoprocessing-scripts-using-python/
COURSE OBJECTIVES: 

	* MANAGE and update attribute data and features with cursors and objects.
	* AUTOMATE geoprocessing and map production operations.

	* ENSURE your script syntax is valid and errors are properly handled.
	* SHARE scripts using custom script tools and geoprocessing packages.

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS: Requests for interpreters or other special requirements must be received at the NTC no later than 45 days prior to the start of the class.  Form can be accessed at:  https://www.ntc.blm.gov/krc/uploads/982/Reasonable_Accommodation_Request_Form.pdf

TARGET AUDIENCE:  Familiarity with ArcGIS Online will be helpful but is not required.

RECOMMENDED PREREQUISITES:  Familiarity with ArcGIS Online will be helpful but is not required.

COURSE DESCRIPTION:  Thanks to their engaging user experience, story maps have achieved mass appeal as a vehicle to inform the public, engage stakeholders, and inspire an audience. This course—for anyone that wants to communicate with maps—teaches the concepts, best practices, and decisions that need to be made when creating and sharing a story map.

For additional details on the course as provided by Esri, please visit the provided URL:  https://www.esri.com/training/catalog/5887d359378ef44b34da22b2/creating-story-maps-with-arcgis/

COURSE OBJECTIVES:

	* CHOOSE an appropriate story map app for your purpose and audience.
	* ADD web maps, images, multimedia, and text to create an engaging story map.

	* APPLY best practices to share and promote your story maps.

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS: Requests for interpreters or other special requirements must be received at the NTC no later than 45 days prior to the start of the class.  Form can be accessed at:  https://www.ntc.blm.gov/krc/uploads/982/Reasonable_Accommodation_Request_Form.pdf

TARGET AUDIENCE: Mineral examiners and candidates that have completed 3800-04. This course is open to target personnel from BLM, USFS, and NPS. Students must be federal employees, in GS-880 (Mining Engineer) or GS-1350 (Geologist) jobs. Exceptions made if appropriate.

REQUIRED PREREQUISITES:  Must have completed seminar course Placer Examination Techniques, BLM-TC3-800-04.
