NOTE: ALL PROSPECTIVE PARTICIPANTS IN THE CLASS ARE PLACED ON A “WAIT LIST” UPON SUPERVISOR APPROVAL. NOTIFICATION OF ENROLLMENT OCCURS APPROXIMATELY 2 MONTHS PRIOR TO THE COURSE START DATE.

COURSE DESCRIPTION:  This advanced level course is conducted in Fairbanks, Alaska, with field exercises in active placer mining areas in Alaska, which will include observation, mapping, and evaluating placer mining operations, and operating earth-moving equipment.

COURSE OBJECTIVES:

	* Identify the placer categories through observations and prepare maps.
	* Determine equipment cycle times and prepare flow diagrams of operations.
	* Evaluate small placer gold mining operations.
	* Estimate material removed at a modern hydraulic mine and evaluate reclamation.
	* Make stream relocation plans.
	* Operate placer sample equipment in various sizes
	* Evaluate underground placer mines in permafrost.
	* Make cost estimates in small operations where normal cost estimation protocols will fail.
	* Match equipment sizes in a mining plan.
	* Evaluate resources through sampling.

NTC will pay travel and per diem costs for BLM employees in the target group at a rate determined by NTC.

Participants should be prepared for shared lodging and long travel days. Weather and insect conditions will be unpredictable.

ONCE YOU ENROLL IN THIS COURSE, PLEASE SEE ADDITIONAL INFORMATION ON THE SEMINAR ACTIVITIES SCREEN.

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS: Requests for interpreters or other special requirements must be received at the NTC no later than 45 days prior to the start of the class. Form can be accessed at: https://www.ntc.blm.gov/krc/uploads/982/Reasonable_Accommodation_Request_Form.pdf

Keyword: 3800-14, Solid Minerals, Certified Mineral Examiner, Alaska Placers, Mining, Cost Estimation, Field Work, Mineral Report, Mapping, Sampling

TARGET AUDIENCE:  Users that are new to GIS technology and/or need a refresher with ArcGIS.

PREREQUISITES:  Completion of Introduction to GIS Using ArcGIS and Referencing Data to Real-World Locations Using ArcGIS or equivalent knowledge. Alternatively, completion of ArcGIS 1: Introduction to GIS or equivalent knowledge.

COURSE DESCRIPTION:  In this course, you will acquire the skills to perform the most common ArcGIS workflows. Primarily using ArcMap, you will explore, manage, and analyze geographic data and create informative maps. Learn techniques to effectively share your ArcGIS work with decision makers, colleagues, and the public.

NOTE:   COURSE CONCEPTS APPLY TO ARCGIS 10.5, 10.6, AND 10.7. Esri will provide ArcGIS 10.7 software for use during class.

For additional details on the course as provided by Esri, please visit the provided URL:  https://www.esri.com/training/catalog/57630436851d31e02a43f119/arcgis-2%3A-essential-workflows/

COURSE OBJECTIVES:  

	* Organize, create, and edit geographic data.
	* Manage, symbolize, and label map layers.
	* Analyze GIS data and solve spatial problems.
	* Share maps and analysis results.

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS: Requests for interpreters or other special requirements must be received at the NTC no later than 45 days prior to the start of the class.  Form can be accessed at:  https://www.ntc.blm.gov/krc/uploads/982/Reasonable_Accommodation_Request_Form.pdf

course title: Editing Data with ArcGIS for Desktop
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE:  Users that are new to editing in ArcGIS and those who need a refresher with ArcMap editing.

REQUIRED PREREQUISITE:  Completion of ArcGIS 2: Essential Workflows (BLM-TC-1730-92) or equivalent knowledge.

COURSE DESCRIPTION:   This course teaches methods for accurately creating and maintaining data stored in a geodatabase. You will learn a recommended workflow for data automation and practice with tools and techniques that help ensure data integrity during editing.

_NOTE: _COURSE CONCEPTS APPLY TO ARCGIS DESKTOP 10.4, 10.5, AND 10.6 (ARCMAP). Esri will provide ArcGIS 10.6 software for use during class.

For additional details on the course as provided by Esri, please visit the provided URL:  https://www.esri.com/training/catalog/57630437851d31e02a43f225/editing-data-with-arcgis-for-desktop/

COURSE OBJECTIVES:  

	* Manage updates to your GIS database.
	* Create and edit feature geometry and attributes.
	* Solve common data alignment issues.
	* Maintain spatial relationships among features using topology.

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS: Requests for interpreters or other special requirements must be received at the NTC no later than 45 days prior to the start of the class.  Form can be accessed at:  https://www.ntc.blm.gov/krc/uploads/982/Reasonable_Accommodation_Request_Form.pdf

TARGET AUDIENCE:   Experienced ArcMap users that want to learn more effective data management practices.

REQUIRED PREREQUISITE:  Completion of ArcGIS 2: Essential Workflows (BLM-TC-1730-92) or equivalent knowledge.

COURSE DESCRIPTION:  Master essential geodatabase concepts and acquire the skills you need to create a geodatabase, add data to it, and model the real-world spatial relationships inherent to your data. You will learn how to take advantage of geodatabase features that ensure the integrity of your GIS data over time.

NOTE;  THIS COURSE IS TAUGHT USING ARCGIS DESKTOP ADVANCED (ARCMAP). Course concepts apply to file-based and multiuser geodatabases and to ArcGIS 10.4, 10.5, and 10.6. Esri will provide ArcGIS 10.6 software for use during class.

For additional details on the course as provided by Esri, please visit the provided URL:  https://www.esri.com/training/catalog/57630436851d31e02a43f1d5/building-geodatabases/

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS: Requests for interpreters or other special requirements must be received at the NTC no later than 45 days prior to the start of the class.  Form can be accessed at:  https://www.ntc.blm.gov/krc/uploads/982/Reasonable_Accommodation_Request_Form.pdf

TARGET AUDIENCE:  Managers and other organizational leaders who are modernizing GIS-supported workflows, planning a new ArcGIS deployment, or expanding ArcGIS access outside the current user base will benefit from this course.​

DIGITAL TRANSFORMATION STARTS WITH HUMAN TRANSFORMATION.

As organizations deploy modern geospatial capabilities to improve their operations, common challenges are identifying the impacted workforce and preparing them to quickly adopt new workflows. Leaders who focus on supporting the workforce through a time of change will be rewarded with a smoother transition, faster technology adoption, and a more confident and productive workforce.

Facilitated by a Prosci-certified Esri change practitioner, this interactive, hands-on course guides attendees through foundational steps to conduct a successful change management initiative using the popular Prosci ADKAR model of change management. Class time is devoted to open discussion on change management best practices and focused planning time. ​

OBJECTIVES:  

	* Document the strategic implications of ArcGIS adoption at all levels of the organization and all impacted stakeholders.
	* Establish a support and sponsorship framework to ensure long-term, successful adoption.
	* Communicate effectively by understanding the organizational impacts of new technology from the perspective of executives, managers, and employees.

PRE-REQUISITES:  Attendees should identify a specific ArcGIS project that is in the planning or implementation stages prior to class. Course materials include templates that attendees can use to jump start change management efforts immediately after class.

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS: Requests for interpreters or other special requirements must be received at the NTC no later than 45 days prior to the start of the class.  Form can be accessed at:  https://www.ntc.blm.gov/krc/uploads/982/Reasonable_Accommodation_Request_Form.pdf

course title: Working with Lidar Data in ArcGIS
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE:  Beginning to intermediate ArcGIS users new to Lidar analysis​ with some familiarity with ArcGIS Pro.​

This course introduces light detection and ranging (lidar) data concepts, collection methods, quality-control considerations, and common applications. Techniques to manage, edit, visualize, and share lidar-derived 2D and 3D information products using ArcGIS Pro are covered

PRE-REQUISITES:  Completion of ArcGIS Pro: Essential Workflows or Migrating from ArcMap to ArcGIS Pro or equivalent knowledge.

OBJECTIVES:

	* Validate the quality and accuracy of lidar data.
	* Edit lidar data to correct errors.
	* Organize, process, visualize, and share lidar data using ArcGIS LAS datasets, mosaic datasets, and point cloud scene layers.
	* Derive useful information products from lidar data, including raster surfaces, building footprints, and vegetation estimates.

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS: Requests for interpreters or other special requirements must be received at the NTC no later than 45 days prior to the start of the class.  Form can be accessed at:  https://www.ntc.blm.gov/krc/uploads/982/Reasonable_Accommodation_Request_Form.pdf

TARGET AUDIENCE: Intermediate and advanced GIS users who intend to publish and share data via the web.​

ENABLE LOCATION-BASED INSIGHTS AND DATA-DRIVEN DECISIONS ACROSS YOUR ORGANIZATION.

Learn how to efficiently share a variety of geospatial resources to an ArcGIS Online organizational site or ArcGIS Enterprise portal website. This course teaches how to publish high-performing services that extend ArcGIS mapping and analytics capabilities across your organization. Course attendees receive a free e-Book copy of Getting to Know Web GIS, third edition.​

OBJECTIVES:

	* Share content between ArcGIS portals.
	* Devise a sharing strategy that supports your organization's workflows and business goals.
	* Share map layers, web maps, data, imagery, custom analysis tools, and ArcGIS Pro project packages.
	* Create map and vector tile caches to enable fast display performance.

REQUIRED PRE-REQUISITES:  Completion of ArcGIS Pro: Essential Workflows or Migrating from ArcMap to ArcGIS Pro or equivalent knowledge.

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS: Requests for interpreters or other special requirements must be received at the NTC no later than 45 days prior to the start of the class.  Form can be accessed at:  https://www.ntc.blm.gov/krc/uploads/982/Reasonable_Accommodation_Request_Form.pdf

course title: Photogrammetry for UAS using Agisoft Metashape 1.5.5
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE:  BLM remote pilots, data processors, or anyone who has an interest in processing UAS collected stereo-imagery for resource management projects using _Agisoft Metashape_.    ​

The Bureau of Land Management (BLM) National Operations Center (NOC) in cooperation with the BLM National Training Center (NTC) is hosting a training course for processing photogrammetric data collected with unmanned aircraft systems (UAS). This course will teach participants the fundamental concepts of photogrammetry and the skills required to process stereo-imagery collected using UAS to produce various geospatial imagery products using _Agisoft Metashape_.  ​

OBJECTIVES:

	* Understand the principals of photogrammetry and stereo-image acquisition as it relates to unmanned aircraft systems (UAS).
	* Learn the principals of mission planning for UAS photogrammetry and how to properly set up a use a digital camera for stereo-image acquisitions.
	* Learn how to use the software Agisoft Metashape to process UAS acquired stereo-imagery to produce various geospatial products.
	* Understand the data lifecycle of UAS photogrammetry and how to properly plan, collect, process, and archive UAS acquired imagery.

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS: Requests for interpreters or other special requirements must be received at the NTC no later than 45 days prior to the start of the class.  Form can be accessed at:  https://www.ntc.blm.gov/krc/uploads/982/Reasonable_Accommodation_Request_Form.pdf

TARGET AUDIENCE:  Experienced GIS users who want to enhance their skills ​with automation and programming with Python. 

Time is valuable. Learn how to create scripts that will streamline your GIS work. This course teaches how to access the Python environment in ArcGIS Pro, script common data management tasks, and automate geoprocessing workflows. You'll learn techniques to share your scripts so they are easily accessible both inside and outside ArcGIS Pro.​​​​

PRE-REQUISITES:  Completion of ArcGIS Pro: Essential Workflows or Migrating from ArcMap to ArcGIS Pro or equivalent knowledge is required.

Some familiarity with Python and basic programming concepts is assumed. Those new to Python should complete the free web course "Python for Everyone" prior to class.

OBJECTIVES: 

	*
Apply Python syntax rules, error-handling techniques, and tool validation to create robust scripts in ArcGIS Pro.
	* Use lists and loops to repeat geoprocessing tasks within a script to create an efficient, repeatable analysis workflow.
	* Use cursors to access geospatial data, edit attributes, and create and modify features.
	* Create geoprocessing packages and custom script tools to share your Python scripts with other ArcGIS users.

To view additional information about the course, please visit Esri's website - https://www.esri.com/training/catalog/5b0431e067b46f2fe61b082f/creating-python-scripts-for-arcgis/.

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS: Requests for interpreters or other special requirements must be received at the NTC no later than 45 days prior to the start of the class.  Form can be accessed at:  https://www.ntc.blm.gov/krc/uploads/982/Reasonable_Accommodation_Request_Form.pdf

course title: Creating and Editing Data with ArcGIS Pro
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE:  BLM employees that are new to GIS and want to learn more about editing data in ArcGIS Pro.

​REQUIRED PREREQUISITE: Completion of ArcGIS Pro: Essential Workflows or equivalent knowledge.

Maintain the accuracy of your authoritative GIS data!  This course teaches best practices to create accurate geographic data and maintain it over time. You will get ample hands-on practice with a variety of ArcGIS Pro tools that streamline the editing process and decrease the potential for errors when updating your GIS database. 

​COURSE OBJECTIVES: 

	*  Apply a standard editing workflow to manage updates to geographic data.
	* Configure ArcGIS Pro application and project settings to support efficient editing.
	* Create, modify, and delete 2D and 3D features and attributes.
	* Solve common data alignment issues and maintain spatial relationships among features when editing.

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS: Requests for interpreters or other special requirements must be received at the NTC no later than 45 days prior to the start of the class.  Form can be accessed at:  https://www.ntc.blm.gov/krc/uploads/982/Reasonable_Accommodation_Request_Form.pdf

TARGET AUDIENCE:  Students who are new to GIS

REQUIRED PREREQUISITE:  Experience with Windows-based software for basic file management and browsing.

Discover the power of spatial.

Learn fundamental concepts that underlie GIS technology and geographic data. In this course, you will gain experience using GIS maps to visualize and explore real-world features; analyze data to answer questions and create new information; and share maps, data, and other resources so they can be easily accessed throughout your organization.​

COURSE OBJECTIVES:

	* Identify appropriate data to support a mapping project.
	* Create a map, add data to it, and symbolize map features to support the map's purpose.
	* Share data, maps, and other content to an organizational portal.
	* Perform spatial analysis to obtain information about map features within an area of interest.

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS: Requests for interpreters or other special requirements must be received at the NTC no later than 45 days prior to the start of the class.  Form can be accessed at:  https://www.ntc.blm.gov/krc/uploads/982/Reasonable_Accommodation_Request_Form.pdf

TARGET AUDIENCE:  New or existing Realty Specialists with little to no prior experience with GIS.

This BLM-developed course is designed to introduce Realty Specialists to GIS technology, including ArcMap and/or ArcGIS Pro, ArcGIS Online, web applications, and mobile data collection​. Students will learn the basics of GIS as it relates to Realty workflows and will see current examples of how GIS is being used to support Realty staff​ in the field. ​

COURSE OBJECTIVES: 

	*
In ArcMap/ArcGIS Pro, practice and learn:

	*
Navigation
	*
Editing
	*
Printing/layouts

	* Navigate and print in ArcGIS Online
	* Introduction to web maps and applications
	* Mobile data collection

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS: Requests for interpreters or other special requirements must be received at the NTC no later than 45 days prior to the start of the class.  Form can be accessed at:  https://www.ntc.blm.gov/krc/uploads/982/Reasonable_Accommodation_Request_Form.pdf

TARGET AUDIENCE:  BLM GIS professionals and imagery analysts who need to extract meaningful information from satellite imagery, unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV)-collected data, and other imagery formats. ​

REQUIRED PREREQUISITE:   Completion of ArcGIS Pro: Essential Workflows or Migrating from ArcMap to ArcGIS Pro or equivalent knowledge.

Transform pixels into information:  ​Best practices to display, process, and create derived raster products are covered. You'll work with ArcGIS Pro and ArcGIS Image Analyst tools to explore common imagery applications, including disaster recovery, damage assessment, and forest canopy assessment.​

COURSE OBJECTIVES:   

	* Apply dynamic raster functions to enhance imagery display and perform change detection.
	* Perform supervised, object-based image classification and assess the accuracy of results.
	* Post-process classified thematic rasters to support analysis needs.
	* Work with derived information products including digital elevation models.

Special Requirements: Requests for interpreters or other special requirements must be received at the NTC no later than 45 days prior to the start of the class.  Form can be accessed at:  https://www.ntc.blm.gov/krc/uploads/982/Reasonable_Accommodation_Request_Form.pdf

course title: Working with Parcel Data in ArcGIS Pro
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE:  BLM employees tasked with editing and maintaining​ parcel data.

This course helps modernize land records data management.  It teaches how to maintain accurate, up-to-date, and authoritative parcel data using the parcel fabric in ArcGIS Pro. You will learn a standard workflow to create a parcel fabric in a file geodatabase, add parcel data to the fabric, and edit parcels to reflect real-world changes. This course assumes familiarity with land-records terminology.​​

COURSE OBJECTIVES:  

	* Configure the parcel fabric environment.
	* Edit parcel geometry, measurements, attributes, and labels in a branch versioning environment.
	* Track parcel history and lineage to represent land record changes over time.
	* Publish a parcel fabric as a feature service to ArcGIS Enterprise so that up-to-date parcel data is available to everyone in your organization who needs it.

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS: Requests for interpreters or other special requirements must be received at the NTC no later than 45 days prior to the start of the class.  Form can be accessed at:  https://www.ntc.blm.gov/krc/uploads/982/Reasonable_Accommodation_Request_Form.pdf

course title: Migrating from ArcMap to ArcGIS Pro 4.0
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE:  ArcMap users will transition to ArcGIS Pro.

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES:  This course prepares experienced ArcMap users to be productive right away. Learn essential ArcGIS Pro terminology and concepts and how to efficiently complete a variety of tasks related to mapping, editing, analyzing, and sharing geospatial data and resources.  ArcGIS Pro contains 2D and 3D capabilities which will assist in streamlining GIS projects.

By the end of this course, learners will be able to

	* CREATE an ArcGIS Pro project and import map documents and 3D scenes.

	* CREATE and modify map symbology and layouts.

	* IMPORT a geoprocessing model and identify potential migration issues.

	* SHARE geospatial resources to an ArcGIS Online organizational site or on-premises ArcGIS portal.

course title: Essential Petroleum Economics and Decision Making
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE:  BOEM/OSR employees

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES:  Petroleum Economics and Decision Making You will learn why the following are important to petroleum economics: Optimal Choice; Decline Curves; Reserves; Cash Flows; Before and After Tax Economics; Discount Rate; Incremental, Acquisition, and Exploration Economics; Value of Information, Monte Carlo Methods; and an understanding of Oil and Gas.

By the end of this course, learners will be able to:

	* Organize and frame economic problems in the oil and gas industry.
	* Apply and compute basic economic criteria.
	* Build and evaluate cash flows. Increase your knowledge in basic petroleum

COURSE NOT COMPLETE - DO NOT ASSIGN TO USERS

Reclamation is required by executive order, Department Manual 515DM4 and Reclamation Directive and Standards to implement Environmental Management Systems (EMS) to systematically address the environmental impacts of its operations and achieve key government-wide sustainability goals. This EMS training will help Reclamation employees understand the Federal Government's EMS requirements, what an EMS is and how it is implemented, and actions Reclamation employees can take through an EMS framework to meet Reclamation's environmental objectives and fulfill its Environmental Stewardship Policy.

COURSE SUMMARY: Training by Fish and Wildlife Service on Rio Grande Silvery Minnow Tagging techniques. Required by USFWS prior to employees tagging Silvery Minnows.

AUDIENCE: Bureau of Reclamation employees involved in Rio Grande Silvery Minnow Sampling

course title: LCR Sustainability and Environmental Management System

description:
COURSE SUMMARY: NEPA Analysis for EAs encourages staff to shift award from resource-based EAs and prepare issue-based EAs

OBJECTIVE:  To pull out the issues that truly require EA analysis for several proposed projects to determine whether there is the potential for significant impacts, and to develop issue-based outlines for those current EAs on which DOI is working.

AUDIENCE:  All DOI Employees

COURSE SUMMARY:  Water/WasteWater Conference

OBJECTIVE:  Gain traditional design-build knowledge & lessons learned from other owners in planning for SJWTP DM

AUDIENCE:  Bureau of Reclamation employees

﻿DESCRIPTION: ﻿Two day training conference on Geographic Information System tools, methodologies, procedures and techniques.  Network and collaborate with peers in executive positions to learn best practices. Discover new, focused solutions that will help your organization unlock the full potential of data.

To improve GIS skills and gain better understanding of new software products that will benefit BOR

course title: Basic NEPA: The Law, Logic and Language of the National Environmental Policy Act
description:
DESCRIPTION: Attendees will learn the basic and fundamental principles of NEPA practice in this 2-day course all the way from what NEPA is and where it came from, through how it works and when it applies, all the way through scoping NEPA documents and techniques to review the adequacy of NEPA documents.  All NEPA processes are explained: Categorical Exclusion, Environmental Assessment/Finding of No Significant Impact (EA/FONSI), and Environmental Impact Statement (EIS). Included is a substantial handout with graphic models, updated case lists that support the models, and sample documents. All materials are based on statutes, regulations, and NEPA case law. Attendees may

wish to keep the course material to serve as a reference in the workplace.

OBJECTIVES:  

	*
How to make the findings required by law; 
	*
How to make the finding of no significant impact in particular; 
	*
The giving of reasons; 
	*
Timing the NEPA process to the decision making process; 
	*
All good legal reasons not to prepare an EIS; 
	*
Scoping a reasonable range of alternatives; and A
	*
n approach to the cumulative impacts analysis that complies literally with the regulatory definition of cumulative impacts.
rank 4 competency: Grants Management Laws, Regulations, and Guidelines

course title: Geospatial Data Management and Visualization Workshop
description:
DESCRIPTION: Improving Reclamation's use of GIS through geospatial data management and visualization.

OBJECTIVES:

	* To train Reclamation staff in geospatial data management practices in order to be able to access, maintain and edit Reclamation enterprise geospatial data.  A geospatial data manager certification will also be offered to qualified employees. 
	* To train Reclamation staff in geospatial data visualization practices, including mapping, in order to better use GIS to meet Reclamation needs.
	*  To train Reclamation staff on methods to improve workflow and work process using GIS.
DESCRIPTION: The Science of Spills course analyzes oil spills as case studies to understand impacts from past incidences.

course title: BSEET SEMS II Awareness Training for Oil Field Employees
description:
Online training course for the New Safety and Environmental Management System (SEMS) regulation, 30 CFR 250 Subpart S.

TRAINING OBJECTIVES: ?To be able to describe what a SEMS (Safety & Environmental Management System) is. To be aware of the regulatory requirements for SEMS. To know what SEMS requires of the employee and be prepared to answer questions if asked by a representative of the lessee or governmental agency. To interpret how SEMS requirements can be put into practice to foster increased safety and environmental work practices.
This course will provide basic EMS annual training for BOEM and BSEE employees.

TARGET AUDIENCE:  Engineers

OBJECTIVES: 

	* Understand the fundamental concepts of on-stream repairs to a wide range of static equipment.
	* Understand the safety, quality & reliability considerations when planing, implementing and managing repairs.
	* Gain an appreciation for practical installation of repairs and what quality checks can be made to ensure compliance with original design

course title: BSEET Bureau Interim Directive Guidance Regarding Safe Drilling Margin and Drilling with Losses
description:
PURPOSE AND OBJECTIVES

This directive provides standard operating procedures regarding regulatory requirements for drilling a well using the safe drilling margin and in potential loss zones.  The planned safe drilling margin is between the Estimated Static Downhole mud weight to the lesser of estimated fracture gradients of the open hole or pressure integrity test (FIT or LOT). It is based on a risk assessment consistent with expected well conditions and operations.  

You are expected to complete this activity WITHIN 30 DAYS OF ASSIGNMENT.

After downloading and reading this directive, you will be marked complete, and no further action is required on your part.  Check your Record of Learning for verification of completion.  

Completion of this activity acknowledges the following statement:  "I HAVE READ AND ACKNOWLEDGE THAT I UNDERSTAND AND WILL IMPLEMENT THE GUIDANCE AS STATED."

course title: BSEET IM COVID-19-05 Guidelines Update Training
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE:  BSEE Technical Personnel

SUMMARY: This training provides information on the current guidelines (Revision 3) for BSEE employees to follow when performing their duties offshore during the COVID-19 pandemic.
rank 3 competency: Grants Management Laws, Regulations, and Guidelines

course title: Resources Stewardship and Science Training Workshop for Intermountain Region Parks
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE: Park- and Regional-based Natural and Cultural Resources Staff 

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES:  This training workshop is geared to provide park-and region-based resource staff the latest in science/scholarship, law and policy, and planning and management of park resources. This information is couched in a framework of strategically managing resources under rapidly changing climatic conditions.  Individual training sessions are structured for both the resource specialist and/or resource managers. Other training sessions will emphasize better communication and brokering of assets among parks and between parks and the regional office - in particular, sessions on the CESU program and the Resource Stewardship Advisory Team and its interface with both park and regional resource programs. Upon completion of the module, employees will be able to: 1) strategically navigate among several lesser known resource topics and how they can be used to address external issues to parks in the region; 2) implement strategic resource planning and understand what success means under rapidly changing climatic conditions; 3) understand how natural and cultural resources should integrate and work together in the management of a park; 4) understand and implement a variety of management actions involving such topics as natural sounds, night skies, visual resources, wildlife-human interactions, fire management, water rights, wilderness resources, to name a few; 5) understand resource law and policy updates and move forward with the management of resources and the implementation of management actions. 

PREREQUISITES: None

TARGET AUDIENCE: All employees

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: This is a formal NPS-developed introduction to the ArcGIS Geographic Information Systems software package. It has been recently refreshed for ArcGIS Version 10 with funding from the Southeast and Midwest Regional Geospatial Support Centers. The course will guide participants through the functionality and use of the two primary ArcGIS Desktop modules ArcCatalog and ArcMap. Participants will learn about the basics of GIS data types, data organization, and data sources before working through the complete workflow of data creation, editing, query and analysis, metadata and mapping.

	* Upon completion of the course, participants will be able to:
	* Use the ArcGIS Desktop modules ArcCatalog and ArcMap.
	* Identify basic GIS data types, data organization, and data sources.
	* Use workflows (including data creation, editing, query and analysis, metadata and mapping) to accurately track and use data in the ArcGIS 

PREREQUISITES: None

The Climate Strategies Forum is a 3-day training workshop presented by the Association of Climate Change Officers (ACCO). The Climate Strategies Forum is the ACCO's premier training event, featuring formal climate change preparedness for credit applicable to credentials issued under the CCO Certification program. The Forum also features a suite of keynote conversations, a Women's Climate Collaborative speed mentoring session, CCO Roundtable sessions, networking events, a tools and methodologies showcase and a tabletop exhibition.
Each Climate Strategies Forum features 20+ half-day bootcamps across a variety of climate change topicss. Participants select up to 4 or 5 courses to tailor their own training experience. Available bootcamp topicss include:

	* Climate Science, Risk & Adaptation Planning
	* GHG Management, Reporting & Reduction Strategies
	* Energy Strategies, Commodities & Markets
	* Supply Chain Management
	* Governance, Engagement & Behavior Change
	* Project Finance & Economic Analysis
	* Enterprise Strategy

Note: The ACCO generally offers two Climate Strategies Forums every year. In 2016, Climate Strategies Forums are expected to be held in Washington DC and San Diego. OBJECTIVES: Forum participants will be able to:

	* Describe implications of climate change with an added regional focus
	* Implement climate risk & adaptation planning strategies
	* Articulate energy management fundamentals and implications for management
	* Describe governance, policy & behavior change associated with different strategies

TARGET AUDIENCE: Senior Park Executives and Managers, Natural and Cultural Resource Managers, Facilities Personnel, Park Planners, Communicators, Educators PREREQUISITES: None

course title: Exploring Facilitated Dialogue as a Civic Engagement Tool in Natural Resource Planning
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE:  Environmental compliance coordinators, planners, interpreters and educators, and resource management staff addressing critical or controversial issues
SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: During this class, participants will learn facilitated dialogue as a technique to conduct civic engagement activities. Facilitated dialogue is an intentional, structured process that invites people with varied experiences and often differing perspectives to engage in an open-ended conversation. It requires participants to move beyond surface assumptions that inform their beliefs. The set of questions creates an environment where participants can freely exchange perspectives in a respectful manner and lets participants draw their own conclusions.   Facilitated dialogue has potential for enhancing public involvement in planning and the decision-making processes. Some parks have been employing these techniques at "pop up" events where interpretive staff share traditional "public meeting" information and materials with park visitors. It also has potential as a technique to provide insight during a National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA) process when a project's purpose, scope, and need are still being determined.  Through interactive and hands-on sessions, participants will: 

	* Understand the role and value of facilitated dialogue as a civic engagement tool

	* Explore the role of facilitated dialogue in natural resource planning

	* Explore the role of interpreters in using facilitated dialogue to engage with the public on planning topicss

	* Clarify assumptions and characteristics of effective dialogue

	* Explore and practice specific techniques to engage people in dialogue

	* Leave the class with new confidence in your facilitation skills, a new community of learning, and access to new resources and avenues of support.

PREREQUISITES: None.

course title: Introduction to Climate Change in National Parks
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE: Natural resource professionals at the entry/developmental level; natural resource professionals at any level who are new to the National Park Service; employees in any field who are interested in how climate change impacts resources managed by the National Park Service.

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: This course is one of a series of on-line learning opportunities designed to provide National Park Service employees with an introduction to specific natural resources and natural resource issues. Students will learn the basic science of climate change; become familiar with policies, programs and partnerships that guide and support climate change response and science; and explore case studies highlighting ways that the changing climate is impacting park resources. The course will also introduce the principles park managers are using to assess, adapt to and plan for changing conditions. It will provide learners with sources for more in-depth information and assistance in dealing with specific problems.

Learners will be able to:

	* Explain the basic science of climate change and how climate change impacts park resources
	* Characterize how the National Park Service responds to climate change and approaches climate adaptation
	* Describe policies and programs for responding to climate change 
	* Identify sources of additional information, expertise and assistance in responding to climate change

PREREQUISITES: None.

TARGET AUDIENCE: Those who wish to learn about using drones and GIS mapping and gain hands-on experience.

DESCRIPTION AND OBJECTIVES: Hands-on workshop to get introductory drone experience and learn how to use drones to collect imagery and create GIS products with images taken from drones. Includes an afternoon GIS lab session on importing data into ESRI's Drone2Map enterprise drone processing software, georeferencing images and creating orthophotos, elevation models, and 3D models.  The workshop will focus on using multi-rotor aircraft for data collection and using ESRI's Drone2Map for processing.  Students will learn how to create 2D orthophotos, surface elevation models and terrain models as well as 3D mapping products such as point clouds and meshes. This course will also introduce GPS technology to further enhance the students understanding of applying these data to create accurate models for consumption in GIS and other workflows.

NOTE: This course will use University drones. 

SME: William J. Shuart, M.S. VCU Rice Rivers Center Instructor, Center for Environmental Studies Virginia Commonwealth University 1000 West Cary Street Room 103, Box 843050 Richmond, Virginia 23284 804.827.0150 Land http://www.vcu.edu/rice  Will Shuart is the Environmental Technology Coordinator for CES-VCU and has 8 years experience using GIS.  He has been an ESRI Authorized instructor since 2001. 

Time: 8am - 10am introduction

10:15-12pm - flight demonstrations

12pm - 1pm - lunch

1-2pm, data collection

2-4pm, data processing

4-5pm, map creation and web application

Participants will:

1.  Gain an understanding of safe UAS [drone] operations including flight planning and current federal requirements for drone operations.

2. Gain experience in field data collection using multi-rotor platforms and understand the use of GPS for ground control and creating accurate mapping products. 

3. Have an introductory understanding of creating mapping products (orthophotos and elevation models) and 3D models using ESRI's Drone2Map software from drone flights and publishing those products to the cloud for consumption

https://www.river-management.org/2020-river-management-training-symposium

course title: ArcGIS Online and NPS Geospatial Portal Acceptable Use Policy
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE: All Users of NPS AGOL and NPS Portal

DESCRIPTION AND OBJECTIVES: This course describes the Acceptable Use Policy (AUP) for the National Park Service Geospatial Portal for ArcGIS (NPS Portal, https://gisportal.nps.gov/) and the National Park Service ArcGIS Online Organizational Account (NPS AGOL, http://nps.maps.arcgis.com/) only. It documents the requirements, what is and is not allowed, and associated practices for users of both NPS GIS (Geographic Information System) web platforms.

The actions and decisions of each user can affect the utility of these systems for other National Park Service (NPS) users as well as the content and functionality available to the public. These rules and requirements assure that NPS users and content adhere to law, policy and licensing constraints and that content is suitably robust for its audience as well as shared to the appropriate extent.

Reading this document and checking the boxes next to the phrases for acknowledgment that you understand and will comply is required in order to obtain the elevated privileges of Publisher.  A Publisher account is needed in order to collect data, publish layers, access premium content, and more. 

Once you have read this document, checked the boxes next to the statements to acknowledge that you have read them, understand them, and will abide by them, then send the certificate to your regional GIS support or program administrator in order to obtain elevated Publisher privileges.

	* The objective is to educate the reader that the actions and decisions of each user can affect the utility of NPS AGOL and NPS Portal for other NPS users as well as the content and functionality available to the public.  In order to receive elevated publisher privileges, the user must understand these rules and requirements and acknowledge that they have read them before being granted additional access to the platforms.

TARGET AUDIENCE: Regulatory and AML staff.

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: This course will demonstrate how easy it is to use AqQA for water analysis, consistency checking, and plotting. Participants will be able to create Piper diagram, Stiff diagram, Ternary and eight other plot types, check water analysis for internal consistency, and manage water data in a spreadsheet.

TARGET AUDIENCE: Regulatory or AML scientist with degrees in geology, ecology, soil science, hydrology, civil or mining engineering, or related natural sciences who desire to learn more advanced skills in the use of the Esri Collector App.

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: This course will expand on training provided in the "Mobile Devices for SMCRA" course. Students will learn more advanced capabilities of the Esri Collector App, as well as administrative and user settings in ArcGIS Online that affect web map and feature layer functionality. We will focus on techniques to optimize the end user experience in the field, including creation of domains, tile packages, and 3D metadata.

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS: Students must have take the "Mobile Devices for SMCRA" class or equivalent coursework to qualify for this class.

course title: OSM-TIPS-Global Mapper for Mining and Reclamation
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE: All disciplines that work with geospatial data.

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: This course will provide users instruction on basic and advanced usage of Global Mapper as it pertains to mining and reclamation. Students will be introduced to the GIS, CAD, mobile computing and remote sensing functionality of Global Mapper, as well as basic understanding of each discipline to assist them in analysis. Students will work with various forms of geospatial data to generate end products.

course title: OSM-TIPS-ProXRT Workshop: High Accuracy GPS for GIS
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE: GIS practitioners experienced with GPS data collection who have a need to collect high-accuracy GPS data for georeferencing, precision navigation, mapping of minesite or AML features with a small spatial footprint, elevation mapping or geologic units such as coalbeds, or water elevations in hydrologic structures.

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: This class features high accuracy collection and analysis of spatial and attribute data for GIS using the Trimble ProXRT hardware, and TerraSync and PROffice software. Participants will perform extensive hands-on use of the GPS hardward and software both in field and office settings. This class will serve as a prerequisite for use of the OSMRE Trimble ProXRT system.

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS: Knowledge of and use of GPS hardward and software for GIS data collection, especially TerraSync and PFOffice and ArcGIS or ArcView software.

course title: OSM-TIPS-ARCGIS Spatial Analyst: For Mining & Reclamation
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE: All course spaces are filled by State, Tribal, and OSMRE coal mining regulatory and reclamation personnel. 

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: This course explores how the ArcGIS Spatial Analyst extension uses raster and vector data in an integrated environment. This course teaches the basic raster concepts and shows how to create, run and edit spatial models. It focuses on problems that are best solved in a raster environment such as Approximate Original Contour topographic analysis, view-shed modeling, and reclaimed slopes hydrologic analysis.

	* Basic Concepts of Raster Concepts, Spatial Analyst Interface, & Querying Raster Themes. 
	* Raster Structure Themes - Creating Raster Datasets and Raster Storage & Management. 
	* Aligning Themes - Raster Registration, Raster Georeferencing, & Raster Projection. 
	* Importing and Exporting Raster Datasets; Surface Analyses - Calculating Density, Interpolation Methods, Interpolating, Contours and Hill shading, & Visibility Analysis.  
	* Map Algebra Functions - Writing Expressions & Expression Syntax. 
	* Distance Measurements - Euclidean Distance & Cost Distance. 
	* Surface Hydrology - Identifying Watershed Basins & Surface Runoff Characteristics.

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS: Students must have taken the TIPS "Introduction to ArcGIS for Mining and Reclamation" class and be very familiar with GIS concepts.

TARGET AUDIENCE: Prospective students should be regulatory or AML scientists with college credit or equivalent experience modeling hydrologic, geochemical, and/or geologic conditions for mine permitting and reclamation.

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVE: An introduction to EarthVision based on actual data from a pre-Law (SMCRA) acid mine drainage site in north-central Pennsylvania. The class uses 2D and 3D data and grids as components in building 3D structure and acid-base accounting property models. Class topics include: data import, visualization, and validation; data editing in 3D; building stratigraphic sequences; and constructing the final 3D volume model. The extraction of 2D maps and cross sections from the finished model completes the sequence of activities. Other topics include the calculation of precise volumes, Formula Processor operations for file manipulation, and exploring the program's powerful new 3D Viewer/Editor. Upon completion of the course, students will have a solid introduction to building three-dimensional models and will be comfortable using the 3D visualization tools.

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS: Experience in Regulatory/AML fields and/or education with geologic, geochemical, soil, materials volumes, or hydrologic conditions that affect mining and reclamation. Familiarity with spreadsheets, mapping, and GIS software will enhance the learning experience.

TARGET AUDIENCE: State, Tribal and OSMRE staff.

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: This course covers the most common uses of HEC-RAS such as water surface profiles, floodplain delineation, and the effects of various obstructions such as bridges, and culverts in the floodplain. The hands on exercises allow students to enter/edit flow and geometric data, perform flow simulations, develop water surface profiles and generate reports and graphics. The students will learn how to use the model as a permitting/evaluation tool in flooding investigations.

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS: Undergraduate degree in physical sciences or engineering (or equivalent experience) and basic computer skills are highly recommended.

course title: OSM-TIPS-Modeling and Analysis with Groundwater Vistas

description:
TARGET AUDIENCE: Regulatory or AML scientist with degrees or college credit in hydrology, or current experience in ground-water hydrology.

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: Join us for a 3-day hands-on training workshop using Geochemist Workbench software. Learn how to construct speciation and reaction path models, in addition to learning how to construct Eh/pH, Stiff, and Piper diagrams. The examples used in constructing these models include mine drainage treatment and cost estimating, water quality investigations, and watershed restoration. 

	* Demonstrate correct use of the Geochemist's Workbench software.

	* Provide a comparison and overview of the three Geochemist's Workbench software tiers: Essentials, Standard and Professional.

	* Provide a detailed comparison to related computer codes, specifically PHREEQC.

	* Provide relevant lectures on theory and application, as well as hands-on computer engaged learning.

	* Describe and demonstrate the common pitfalls of using the software.

	* Address the software's application to coal mining related concerns.

	* Address questions and projects of the attendees during the training course.

	* Provide specific coal mining examples and applications of the GWB software. 

	* Introduce new features available in software version 8. 

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS: Students should have an understanding of geochemistry and prior experience with mine drainage is desired, but not necessary.

course title: OSM-TIPS-SEDCAD Applications and Extensions for Mine Permitting and Reclamation

description:
TARGET AUDIENCE: AML personnel (designers, project managers, engineers, and inspectors) who have designed or inspected a minimum of two AML projects.

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES:

	* Evaluate when commitment of expenditures for drilling is appropriate in response to mine subsistence complaints and 

	* Evaluate situations where commitment of expenditures for grouting is appropriate in response to mine subsistence complaints.

Link to https://www.osmre.gov/programs/training/NTTPTraining.shtm

course title: OSM-NTTP-Coalfield Communications: How to Get It Right
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE: Staff who has frequent contact with the public and the news media. 

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: The purpose of this course is to enhance the skills of staff who have frequent contact with the public. topics covered include: 1) effective communications for building trust; 2) effective public meetings; 3) pro-active and re-active interaction with news media and 4) educational outreach. Class exercises are designed to maximize opportunities for student practice as communication skills are best learned through doing.

Link to https://www.osmre.gov/programs/training/NTTPTraining.shtm

course title: OSM-NTTP-SMCRA/ESA: Implementation of the 1996 Biological Opinion (OSM)
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE: State and Federal program staff, permitting specialists and inspectors and State and Federal personnel responsible for commenting on the fish and wildlife aspects of SMCRA permits. Almost all course spaces are filled by State, Tribal, and OSMRE coal mining regulatory and reclamation personnel. Students from other DOI bureaus, other governmental agencies, or other interested parties will be accepted on a space available basis.

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: This course provides participants with a fuller understanding of the 1996 Biological Opinion and Conference Report (BO) issued to the Office of Surface Mining Reclamation and Enforcement by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service on surface coal mining and reclamation operations, the underlying statutory and regulatory requirements, and how the BO is intended to operate.

Link to https://www.osmre.gov/programs/training/NTTPTraining.shtm

TARGET AUDIENCE: Geologists and Hydrologists and Inspectors who conduct hydrologic investigations on problems related to surface and underground mines, coal refuse disposal facilities and other coal mining related activities.

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: This course provides training on how to conduct a hydrologic autopsy relating to mine problems including but not limited to: dewatering or contamination of aquifers, wells, streams, springs, pond/lakes, problems associated with increased amount of water from mine flooding, hydrologic aspect of landslides and other hydrologic problems associated with mining activities.

Link to https://www.osmre.gov/programs/training/NTTPTraining.shtm

course title: OSM-NTTP-Geology and Geochemistry of Acid-Forming Materials
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE: Permitting Specialists, Inspectors, and AML Specialists. This course is designed for individuals who have had advanced high school chemistry or a basic college chemistry course. At least 6 months experience on a regulatory or reclamation program staff is recommended.

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: This course is designed to provide participants with specific information presented in a highly interactive manner on analyzing and examining how geology/mineralogical influences water quality. A detailed discussion is presented on acid and alkaline weathering processes. Participants will be introduced to overburden drilling, sampling and characterization. Participants will be given a variety of strategy and implementation lab methods and interpretation for overburden: static and leaching tests. Participants will use inquiry, problem solving and feedback methodologies for previous mining as a prediction tool, mine drainage prevention and treatment techniques.

Link to https://www.osmre.gov/programs/training/NTTPTraining.shtm

course title: OSM-NTTP-Mine Gas Safety and Investigation Course
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE: Individuals with duties that involve field visits where dangerous gases may be encountered on active or abandoned mine sites.

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: This course will provide information on gases commonly produced from active and abandoned mines that may pose a threat to the safety, health and well being of government personnel and the public. Discussions will focus on the terms, characteristics, techniques, tools and equipment available to identify gases. The physiological impacts of each gas will be presented so that personnel may identify, at the earliest possible moment, the potential for dangerous environments. We will identify the mining and non-mining sources of stray gases and explore the natural and man-made pathways that lead to spaces that may be occupied by people. We will discuss case studies and encourage participants to bring their own cases to discuss and share with the class the problems with investigations and mitigations in this complex subject. The course will include a short field exercise to demonstrate equipment and investigation techniques.

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS: Students should bring a calculator, and clothing appropriate for the field exercise.

TARGET AUDIENCE: AML staff or permit review staff who have at least 6 months of experience with National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA) procedures or OSMRE/State regulatory staff who work directly with NEPA implementation on Federal permits. Comments: Please indicate on the nomination form if you are not an AML program employee and why you feel this course is necessary. Almost all course spaces are filled by State, Tribal, and OSMRE coal mining regulatory and reclamation personnel. Students from other DOI bureaus, other governmental agencies, or other interested parties will be accepted on a space available basis.

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: This course provides training for State and Federal staff involved in AML projects or Federal mine plan and Federal permit review in the procedures for complying with and drafting environmental documents required by NEPA and other appropriate environmental laws, regulations, and executive orders.

Link to https://www.osmre.gov/programs/training/NTTPTraining.shtm

TARGET AUDIENCE: Permitting Specialists and Inspectors; AML Project Designers and Inspectors; Persons developing, designing, reviewing, or evaluating mine drainage passive treatment systems.

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: This course provides information and exercises that are highly interactive and can be used to evaluate the application of passive treatment in clean streams, abandoned mine lands, and active mining projects; estimation of treatment costs; development of actual treatment designs; and assessment of existing passive treatment projects.

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS: We recommend completion of the Acid-Forming Materials: Fundamentals and Applications course and an AMDTreat course as a pre-requisite. A basic understanding of chemistry is very helpful.

TARGET AUDIENCE: This is a basic course for AML and regulatory field personnel with a natural sciences background who are involved in mine site inspection and permit review. No previous knowledge of wetlands is necessary. Almost all course spaces are filled by State, Tribal, and OSMRE coal mining regulatory and reclamation personnel. Students from other DOI bureaus, other governmental agencies, or other interested parties will be accepted on a space available basis.

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: This course familiarizes regulatory and AML field personnel with identification of wetlands, along with requirements and procedures for wetland protection.

Link to https://www.osmre.gov/programs/training/NTTPTraining.shtm

course title: OSM-TIPS-AMD Treat for Acid Mine Drainage Treatment Cost Estimation
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE: Hydrologist, geologist or engineers.

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: AMD Treat software offers users a method to predict and model water treatment costs for mine drainage problems. Students will leave the class with a basic understanding of active and passive mine drainage water treatment methods, strategies, and cost-estimation procedures using the AMD Treat software. This course includes modules on Geo-Chemistry, Passive Treatment, and Active Treatment. There are also two design exercises, one for passive treatment and one for active treatment.

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS: Familiarity with active and passive AMD treatment systems and treatment cost bonding estimation are desirable.

TARGET AUDIENCE: Students with basic CAD experience.

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: The fluvial geomorphic approach to designing landforms that are stable against erosion and promote sustainable land development, requires that essential landform characteristics are incorporated into the landform and that the characteristics are correctly inter-related for proper function. The GeoFluv approach to landform design uses measurements of these essential landform characteristics of upland areas and ephemeral, intermittent, and perennial stream channels as input values and integrates them to design a functioning landform. The students will learn how to develop landform designs for erosion resistance and long-tern sustainable land use.

course title: OSM-TIPS-Introduction to GIS for Mining and Reclamation I
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE: Regulatory or AML staff with degrees in geology, soil science hydrology, civil or mining engineering, or related natural sciences with little or no experience with GIS.

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: The course is an introduction to the basics of ArcGIS Desktop software. This course is designed around mining and reclamation examples and exercises. The various types of GIS data and how they are used in Desktop will be covered. Techniques for using the features of this software to generate high quality maps and analyzing selected data sets are taught. Specific training areas will be ArcCatalog, ArcMap & ArcToolbox.

	* A basic understanding of various ArcGIS screens and functions 

	* A basic understanding of coordinate systems, datums, and projections 

	* Locating and adding baseline data from online sources (e.g., imagery, topography) 

	* Importing external data (Excel tables, CAD drawings, GPS points) 

	* Digitizing and georeferencing spatial data 

	* Performing basic data analysis using ArcGIS tools (editing, clip, buffer, selection) 

	* Properly displaying the data through the use of symbology, transparency, etc. 

	* Designing and printing maps for publication

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS: Familiarity with GIS or Mapping concepts is helpful.

TARGET AUDIENCE: Inspectors, Hydrologists, Soil Scientists, Biologists, Mining Engineers, Reclamation Specialist, Geospatial Staff and Other Field Staff.

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: Android/iOS/Windows based devices loaded with a tool set of applications (APPs) that can be used to navigate, take notes/pictures, and utilize geospatial data in the field. This course provides an introduction to Android, iOS, and Windows devices as a utility for SMCRA related business practices. Through lectures and classroom/field exercises, students learn about tools, menus, GPS, and geospatial data capabilities that come with Android/iOS/Windows devices. The course emphasizes best practice principles and considerations for common field tasks utilizing a number of Android/iOS/Windows APPs. 

	* Provide an introduction to Android/iOS/Windows devices as a utility for SMCRA related tasks. 
	* Explore tools, menus, GPS, and geospatial data capabilities that come with Android/iOS/Windows devices. 
	* Recommend best practice principles and considerations for common field tasks utilizing a number of apps for Android/iOS/Windows. 

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS: Familiarity with Android, iOS, and/or Windows tablets and/or smart phones.

course title: OSM-TIPS-AMD Treat for Acid Mine Drainage Treatment Cost Calculation - Virtual Classroom
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE: Hydrologist, geologist or engineers.

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: AMD Treat software offers users a method to predict and model water treatment costs for mine drainage problems. Students taking this class will have a basic understanding of active and passive mine drainage water treatment methods, strategies, and cost-estimation procedures using the AMD Treat software. This course includes modules on Geo-Chemistry, Passive Treatment, and Active Treatment. There are also two design exercises, one for passive treatment and one for active treatment. Note: This online course should not be taken in conjunction with any other TIPS or NTTP courses.  
DURATION: Each student will spend an average of 4-6 hours per week working on the course lessons, assignments and online collaboration during a 6-7 week period. The online course access and orientation session information will be available to students prior to the start date. 

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS: Familiarity with active and passive AMD treatment systems and treatment cost bonding estimation are desirable.

course title: OSM-TIPS-Introduction to GIS for Mining and Reclamation I - Virtual Classroom
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE: Regulatory or AML staff with degrees in geology, soil science, hydrology, civil or mining engineering, or related natural sciences with little or no experience with GIS. 

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: This course is an introduction to the basics of the ArcGIS Desktop software. It is designed around mining and reclamation examples and exercises. You will learn worthwhile techniques to generate and analyze high-quality maps and selected data sets by using ArcCatalog, ArcMap and ArcToolbox software. You will learn to recognize various file types and differences between formats, e.g. Raster vs. Vector, Shapefile, Aerial photos/Satellite images, DRG's, DOQQ's, GPS and CAD layers. You will learn what coordinate systems, datum's, and projections are and why understanding them is vital to working with spatial data. Extraction of CAD layers into the GIS, modifying attributes of shapefiles, geo-rectification and scanning will be covered. Introduction to various mobile computing software and hardware that TIPS supports and how it relates to the permitting process workflow will be examined. 

DURATION: You should expect to spend as much time on an online course as you do in a face-to-face course. The actual amount of time will vary from individual to individual. It is estimated that each student will spend an average of 30-40 hours course completing this course during a 28-day period. This estimate includes the time spent in reading, discussions, and exercises.

TARGET AUDIENCE: Regulatory or AML scientist with degrees or college credit in hydrology, or current experience in ground-water hydrology.

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: This 6 week online course is aimed at providing attendees with an understanding of how to use Geochemist Workbench to model mine drainage chemistry and treatment. The workshop is focused on the practical application of modeling and will use data collected from various coal mine discharges and treatment systems.  

	* Demonstrate correct use of the Geochemist's Workbench software.

	* Provide a comparison and overview of the three Geochemist's Workbench software tiers: Essentials, Standard and Professional.

	* Provide a detailed comparison to related computer codes, specifically PHREEQC.

	* Provide relevant lectures on theory and application, as well as hands-on computer engaged learning.

	* Describe and demonstrate the common pitfalls of using the software.

	* Address the software's application to coal mining related concerns.

	* Address questions and projects of the attendees during the training course.

	* Provide specific coal mining examples and applications of the GWB software. 

	* Introduce new features available in software version 8. 

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS: Students should have an understanding of geochemistry and prior experience with mine drainage is desired, but not necessary.

course title: OSM-TIPS-ArcPAD 10.0: Mobile GIS for Reclamation Mapping and Analysis
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE: All course spaces are filled by State, Tribal, and OSMRE coal mining regulatory and reclamation personnel.

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: ArcPad is a mobile GIS software package developed by ESRI that is used to capture, display, analyze, and edit geographic information in the field. This focused course provides an introduction to ArcPad 7 and demonstrates some of its powerful capabilities that can be applied in the coal mining environment. Through a series of lectures, classroom, and field exercises students learn about the wide range of tools, menus, and style sheets that come with ArcPad and how ArcPad is used to gather and edit field data. The course emphasizes best practice principles and considerations for common field tasks. Those completing this course will be able to: Open a map in ArcPad and add layers to it; Explain the different data types used in ArcPad; Understand ArcPad tools and menus;  Prepare and get data for ArcPad using desktop ArcGIS applications; Gain a basic understanding of GPS, coordinate systems, and map projections; Understand the functionality of GPS preferences in ArcPad; Change layer symbology and map displays; Find and edit features in ArcPad; Edit and add feature attributes; Create a new shapefile in ArcPad; Add and import fields to new shapefiles; Create customized data collection forms in ArcPad; and Select the appropriate type of GPS and hardware unit for specific applications. 

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS: Prospective students should have experience with GIS and GPS. Knowledge of ArcGIS software products is highly recommended.

TARGET AUDIENCE: Regulatory or AML personnel involved in State or Federal UAV programs for overflight, site investigations, surveying, area and volume calculations. 

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES:  This workshop brings together States, Tribes, and OSMRE to discuss the current status of their UAV programs.  We will focus on FAA part 107 certification, safe UAV operation, and conduct live flying demos on our sterile site.  

Lecture topics include:

	*  Image processing to produce orthorectified imagery, point clouds, and surface models.
	* Volumetric calculations in Global Mapper using UAV data.
	* USGS UAV naming conventions and cloud data storage.
	* Autonomous flight planning

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS:  By invitation only.

This introductory module focuses on the basic gift rule, gift exclusions and exceptions, and disposition of prohibited gifts. With the approval of your agency ethics official, you may use this module toward satisfying your annual ethics training requirement.
OBJECTIVES:

TARGET AUDIENCE:

This course introduces the field of environmental conflict resolution (ECR), assessment of environmental disputes, and essentials of conflict management, including what ECR is, how and when to use it, central concepts of collaborative, interest-based problem solving, and essential communication skills.

Target Audience:
Summary and Objectives: This course lays the groundwork for key concepts of government-to-government consultation including creating and sustaining valuable relations to foster trust between sovereigns. Participants build awareness of different ways to manage information, communication, decision making, roles, and responsibilities. They will also deepen their appreciation for and understanding of tribal preferences, the value of cultural and sacred sites, and of how historic events and federal Indian policies have shaped government-to-government relationships.

Target Audience:
Summary and Objectives: The future estimated costs associated with studies and cleanups of environmental and disposal liability (EDL) sites are reported in the Agency Financial Report (AFR). Current directive from the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) requires the Department and other federal agencies to prepare annual audited financial statements in accordance with federal law and applicable standards and guidance. Additionally, OMB requires quarterly unaudited financial statements in accordance with OMB Circular A-136, Financial Reporting Requirements. Persons responsible for navigating these statutes, standards and guidance; comprehending EDL terminology; and understanding why it is necessary to report, what to report, when to report, and how to report often find themselves more than challenged!

course title: Life of a Lease Federal Onshore at ONRR
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE:  ONRR Employees and States and Tribes under Sec 202/205 of FOGRMA.  This course is also open to OS, OIG and Office of the Solicitor.

GAGAS CPE:   This class is approved for 8 CPE toward the 24/80 hour requirement. 

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: Overview of all the ONRR processes a Federal Onshore Oil and Gas lease goes through from birth to grave.  The objective is to educate employees on the processes that a lease goes through to include how each group within ONRR interacts with each other. 

DURATION: 8 hours

COST:  Please see Class Announcement for tuition information.

TARGET AUDIENCE:  ONRR Employees and States and Tribes under Sec 202/205 of FOGRMA.  This course is also open to OS, OIG and Office of the Solicitor.

GAGAS CPE:   This class is approved for 3.5 CPE toward the 24/80 hour requirement. 

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES:  Indian oil Valuation Rule Training. This training will show our auditors in Oklahoma City and Tulsa how to apply the new Indian oil valuation rule to their audits and compliance reviews. The rule went into effect on July 1, 2015.

 In this course, you will learn:

	* How the index based major portion (IBMP) price is calculated under the new Indian oil rule
	* How the IBMP price is adjusted each month based on the Location and Crude Type Differential (LCTD) calculation
	* Other major changes to the Indian Oil Valuation Rule

DURATION: 3.5 hours

COST:  Please see Class Announcement for tuition information.

TARGET AUDIENCE:  ONRR Employees and States and Tribes under Sec 202/205 of FOGRMA.  This course is also open to OS, OIG and Office of the Solicitor.

GAGAS CPE:  This class is approved for 4 CPE to apply toward the 80 and 24 hour requirements. 

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES:  Fundamentals of physical and financial crude oil markets and pricing in the United States.

 In this workshop, you will learn to:

	* Getting familiar with how crude oil is priced (Basis, Basin, and Market Differentials).
	* Understanding how crude oil gets to market.
	* Types of contracts used in crude oil trading.

DURATION: 4 hours

COST:  Please see Class Announcement for tuition information.

course title: Beginner Level Oil and Gas Training
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE:  ONRR Employees and States and Tribes under Sec 202/205 of FOGRMA.  This course is also open to OS, OIG and Office of the Solicitor.

GAGAS CPE:   This class is approved for 1.5 CPE toward the 24/80 hour requirement. 

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES:  This is a beginning level oil and gas training designed for analysts within ONRR's WAC Denver C teams 1-3..  A subject matter expert within ONRR, will cover the reporting process required of companies as well as valuation of both oil and gas commodities. 
In this workshop, you will learn to:

	* Experience the reporter training given to industry
	* Learn about gas plant commodities and where they are found throughout the production process
	* Learn how to properly determine the oil and gas prices they should use when reviewing a property

DURATION:  1.5 hours

COST:  See announcement for tuition details

TARGET AUDIENCE:  ONRR Employees and States and Tribes under Sec 202/205 of FOGRMA.  This course is also open to OS, OIG and Office of the Solicitor.

GAGAS CPE:  This class is approved for 2 CPE toward the 24/80 hour requirement. 
SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES:  An overview of the natural gas industry from wellhead to marketplace, with emphasis on gas plant operations. Step-by-step introduction to the overall process flow diagram is used to illustrate how individual plant operations are integrated to create gas plants capable of handling feeds from gas fields throughout the nation. Processing contracts, plant settlement statements, and NGL economics are also touched upon.

Participants will gain a working knowledge of the major processes for: 

	* Gas compression

	* Dehydration

	* Acid gas removal and tail-gas cleanup

	* Sulfur recovery

	* Cryogenic extraction of natural gas liquids (NGLs)

	* Process economics

DURATION: 2 hours

COST:  Please see Class Announcement for tuition information.

course title: Natural Gas Pipeline Fuel and Loss
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE:  ONRR Employees and States and Tribes under Sec 202/205 of FOGRMA.  This course is also open to OS, OIG and Office of the Solicitor.

GAGAS CPE:    This class is approved for 2 CPE toward the 24/80 hour requirement. 

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: The course will train ONRR employees to implement the guidance in the August 8 Reporter Letter on gas used or lost along a pipeline (field fuel). The course will cover the regulatory basis for royalty on gas used or lost, how to identify if gas is being used or lost, how to value gas used or lost, how to determine if some of fuel may be included in the transportation allowance, and how companies should be reporting and paying royalty on gas used or lost. The course solidify these concepts using pertinent examples and exercises. 
Upon completion of this course, the participant will:  

	* understand why and when gas is used or lost along a pipeline

	* identify gas used or lost; properly value and report gas used or lost

	* understand if and when gas used or lost may be deducted as a transportation allowance

DURATION: 2 hours

COST:  None

course title: Natural Gas Percentage of Proceeds (POP) Contracts
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE:  ONRR Employees and States and Tribes under Sec 202/205 of FOGRMA.  This course is also open to OS, OIG and Office of the Solicitor.

GAGAS CPE:   This class is approved for 2 CPE toward the 24/80 hour requirement. 

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES:  You will learn how to identify POP contracts, understand how they are valued and reported for royalty purposes, and properly calculate royalties.
The objectives for this course are to train employees to understand what a POP contract is, how to calculate royalties, and understand the requirements for arm's-length POP contracts

DURATION: 2 hours

COST:  None.

TARGET AUDIENCE:  ONRR Employees and States and Tribes under Sec 202/205 of FOGRMA.  This course is also open to OS, OIG and Office of the Solicitor.

GAGAS CPE:  This class is approved for 3 CPE toward the 24/80 hour requirement. 

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES:  Hedging and financial transactions and their relationship to physical natural gas and how producers utilize these tools. 
In this workshop, you will learn Natural Gas Pricing Methods:

	* Hedging concepts and methods
	* Financial derivatives
	* Futures; Options/Swaps; relationship of physical and financial transactions

DURATION: 3 hours

COST:  Please see Class Announcement for tuition information.

TARGET AUDIENCE:  ONRR Employees and States and Tribes under Sec 202/205 of FOGRMA.  This course is also open to OS, OIG and Office of the Solicitor.

GAGAS CPE:   This class is approved for 3 CPE toward the 24/80 hour requirement. 

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES:  This class will include a high level overview of the steps involved in removing, treating and processing natural gas prior to sale. Descriptions of all major transportation and processing functions are included, as well as how these might affect audit. 
 In this workshop, you will learn a basic knowledge of how natural gas is transported and processed.

DURATION: 3 hours

COST:  None.

TARGET AUDIENCE:  ONRR Employees and States and Tribes under Sec 202/205 of FOGRMA.  This course is also open to OS, OIG and Office of the Solicitor.

GAGAS CPE:  This class is approved for 3 CPE toward the 24/80 hour requirement. 

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES:   This class will include a high level over view of the steps involved in removing, treating and processing natural gas prior to sale.  Descriptions of all major transportation and processing functions are included, as well as how these might affect audit.   By the end of the class, the participants will have a basic knowledge in how natural gas is transported and processed.

DURATION: 3 hours

COST:  Please see Class Announcement for tuition information.

TARGET AUDIENCE:  ONRR Employees and States and Tribes under Sec 202/205 of FOGRMA.  This course is also open to OS, OIG and Office of the Solicitor.

GAGAS CPE:  This class is approved for 2 CPE toward the 24/80 hour requirement. 

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: This course will include a high level overview of current regulations and case law, including IBLA decisions relating to marketable condition and its application to extractive minerals. Examples and exercises applying the marketable condition rule will be included as part of this course.  By the end of this course, the participants will have a working knowledge of marketable condition and how it applies to commodities.

DURATION: 8 hours

COST:  None.

TARGET AUDIENCE:  ONRR Employees and States and Tribes under Sec 202/205 of FOGRMA.  This course is also open to OS, OIG and Office of the Solicitor.

GAGAS CPE:  This class is approved for 1.5 CPE toward the 24/80 hour requirement. 

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES:  You will learn an overview of what unbundling is, what allowances are, transportation allowances versus processing allowances, how to use ONRR UCAs, and reviewing industry methods. 
In this course, you will learn about:

	* What is unbundling? 

	* Why is it necessary? 

	* What are allowed and disallowed costs? 

	* How do you use ONRR UCAs? 

	* When industry submits a method for review, what do we look for?

DURATION: 1.5 hours

COST:  None.

	*

TARGET AUDIENCE:  ONRR Employees and States and Tribes under Sec 202/205 of FOGRMA.  This course is also open to OS, OIG and Office of the Solicitor.
GAGAS CPE: This class is approved for 1 1/2 CPE to apply toward the 80 and 24 hour requirements. 

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES:  You will learn how to determine the royalty value of Federal and Indian coal. You will be instructed on major royalty valuation concepts including gross proceeds and marketable condition. You will also learn how to properly determine washing and transportation allowances.

You will receive training on how the following topicss apply to coal valuation: 

	* Gross Proceeds
	* Marketable Condition

	* Arm's-Length Valuation

	* Non-Arm's-Length Valuation

	* Transportation Allowances

	* Washing Allowances

	* Non-Arm's-Length Allowance Calculations

DURATION: 1.5 hours

COST: See announcement for tuition details

TARGET AUDIENCE:  ONRR Employees and States and Tribes under Sec 202/205 of FOGRMA.  This course is also open to OS, OIG and Office of the Solicitor.

GAGAS CPE:  This class is approved for 8 CPE toward the 24/80 hour requirement. 

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES:  Once a well has been drilled and completed, producing hydrocarbon in the most efficient and effective manner is nearly as complex as drilling the well. This program explores the physical, volumetric and financial principles of Production Operations with just a touch of Engineering, for those who would benefit from greater understanding but don't have a background in Oil & Gas Technology or Operations .

In this workshop, you will learn:

	* How Gas and Oil are handled when they leave the ground
	* Fundamentals of Hydrocarbons
	* The Roles at the Production Site
	* Fundamentals of Reserves and Decline Curves
	* The AFE/WBS and a little Procurement
	* A Day in the Life in the Field
	* Allocation & Transportation

DURATION: 8 hours

COST:  Please see Class Announcement for tuition information.

TARGET AUDIENCE:  ONRR Employees and States and Tribes under Sec 202/205 of FOGRMA.  This course is also open to OS, OIG and Office of the Solicitor.

GAGAS CPE:  This class is approved for 16.5 CPE toward the 24/80 hour requirement.
