SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES:   This is an Intermediate Level Course.  The training provides an insight into the background and how to review non-arm's-length transportation allowance claimed on Federal Offshore Deepwater properties. There will be hands-on exercise throughout the course to help reinforce the materials covered. 

Course coverage includes: 

	* General terminologies
	* Impact of the pre- and post- 2017 Federal regulations as well as other criteria
	* Resources
	* Deepwater transportation segments
	* Determination of allowable/non-allowable costs
	* Review steps of the planning and analysis phases of the costs claimed

In this workshop, you will learn to:

	* General understanding of deepwater transportation allowance
	* Why deepwater transportation allowance differs from other types of transportation allowances
	* Criteria and sources for the review
	* Review steps entailed in conducting the survey, planning, and analysis of the audit
	* Walk-through of how to determine and compute the different costs

DURATION:  16 hours

COST:  Please see Class Announcement for tuition information.

TARGET AUDIENCE:  ONRR Employees and States and Tribes under Sec 202/205 of FOGRMA.  This course is also open to OS, OIG and Office of the Solicitor.

GAGAS CPE:   This class is approved for 8.5 CPE toward the 24/80 hour requirement. 

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: This course will entail an overview of solid mineral geology, WAC/Den C and solid mineral industry statistics , and the assignments that Denver C completes. We will look in depth at some current issues that are faced during the course of audits and compliance reviews. In addition, we will discuss coal valuation and how it applies to our assignments.

DURATION: 8 hours

COST:  Please see Class Announcement for tuition information.

TARGET AUDIENCE:  ONRR Employees and States and Tribes under Sec 202/205 of FOGRMA.  This course is also open to OS, OIG and Office of the Solicitor.

GAGAS CPE:    This class is approved for 2.5 CPE toward the 24/80 hour requirement. 

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: Subject matter experts from BLM will discuss trending topicss, items of interest for ONRR employees, and issues requested by STRAC partners. 
In this workshop, you will better understand:

	* Royalty measurement points
	* Oil commingling agreements

DURATION: 2.5 hours

COST:  Please see Class Announcement for tuition information.

course title: DOI General Environmental Management System Awareness Training
description:
SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: The course is designed to introduce awareness to Executive Order 13423, "Strengthening Federal Environmental, Energy, and Transportation Management," dated January 26, 2007; define and illustrate environmental management systems (EMS); describe the benefits and importance of EMS; and, being a good environmental steward in our day-to-day work activities as Department of the Interior employees.

TARGET AUDIENCE: All employees

course title: ONRR Oil & Gas Laws, Regulations, and Policies
description:
This course will help the auditor/analyst become familiar with the laws, regulations, and policies that govern the production, sales, and royalty payments impacting oil, gas, and natural gas liquid products produced and sold from Federal and Indian Lands.

﻿TARGET AUDIENCE﻿: ONRR employees and States and Tribes under Sec 202/205 of FOGRMA. This course is also open to OS, OIG and Office of Solicitor.

﻿GAGAS CPE:﻿ This class is approved for 4 CPE toward the 24/80 hour requirement.

﻿COURSE OBJECTIVES:﻿ The participant will learn how to apply the appropriate regulation to different audit situations. In this course, you will learn to:

	* ﻿Determine how to calculate value based on regulations and ONRR policies.
	* Determine if the auditee is valuing production and calculating royalties based on current laws and policies.

﻿DURATION:﻿ 4 hours

﻿COST:﻿ Please see class announcement for tuition information.
rank 1 competency: Grants Management Laws, Regulations, and Guidelines

description:
﻿TARGET AUDIENCE:﻿ ONRR employees and States and Tribes under Sec 202/205 of FOGRMA. This course is also open to OS, OIG and Office of Solicitor. This class does not apply toward GAGAS CPE.

﻿COURSE SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES:﻿ Do you create content for a DOI Website? Do you contribute to documents, text, or images that end up on a website? Do you wish you could write more effective and accessible emails? If the answer is yes, this workshop is for you. This workshop offers tools and techniques to ensure your content meets best practices for the web, including:

	* ﻿creating user-centered content
	* using plain language
	* designing content
	* considering voice and tone
	* creating accessible and Section 508-compliant content

This is a hands-on workshop. We'll use content evaluation techniques and tools, including a free online app that helps you simplify your writing, avoid jargon, and write active sentences. We'll use real-world content examples to ensure the workshop is relevant to each participant. In this special edition of the workshop, we'll focus more time on writing for accessibility, demonstrating how our writing choices can sometimes create barriers for others. You'll leave the workshop with resources that will help you improve your web writing, align your content with the expectations and needs of your audience, and create content that everyone can access and use.

﻿DURATION﻿: 4 hours

﻿COST:﻿ $0

TARGET AUDIENCE: ONRR employees and States and Tribes under Sec 202/205 of FOGRMA. This course is also open to OS, OIG and Office of Solicitor.

GAGAS CPE: This class is approved for 3.5 CPE toward the 24/80 hour requirement.

COURSE SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: This course will dive into the more complex topics around Indian gas valuation, such as dedicated contracts, the minimum value provision for NGLs, dual accounting elections, etc. This course is geared toward ONRR/STRAC employees who work on audits or compliance reviews. This course is best taken after an employee has taken the 6-hour Indian Oil & Gas Valuation course. In this course, you will learn:

	*
 The objective of this course is to train employees to understand and properly apply these complex elements when reviewing royalty calculations and reporting.

DURATION: 3.5 hours

COST: Please see class announcement for tuition information.

TARGET AUDIENCE: ONRR employees and States and Tribes under Sec 202/205 of FOGRMA. This course is also open to OS, OIG and Office of Solicitor.

GAGAS CPE: This class is approved for 10.5 CPE toward the 80 hour requirement.

COURSE SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: The NIOGEMS 4 Introductory course is designed for tribal and government NIOGEM user to learn about map and data viewer menus, buttons and tools. Nearly all subjects are covered except for User Parcels, Supplemental Data, Renewable, or Solid Minerals. In this course, you will learn:

	*
 Mapping - Reports

DURATION: 11 hours

COST: Please see class announcement for tuition information.

TARGET AUDIENCE:  Current employees and new hires within DOI, especially those with bureau and office responsibilities for identifying, tracking, evaluating, and reporting on EDLs.

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES:  Environmental and Disposal Liability is a self-paced course with five modules that will walk participants through information contained in the newest version of the EDL handbook. A brief test is included at the conclusion of the course. The expected average time to complete this EDL learning course is two hours. You can exit the course at any time and pick up where you left off when you return, just by closing your web browser.

By the end of this course, you will be able to:

	* Describe the types of environmental liabilities managed by the DOI and its bureaus and offices.
	* Define EDL terminology and the accounting basis for the responsible management of EDLs.
	* Perform procedures and protocols developed by the DOI for EDL identification, tracking, evaluating, and reporting.
	* Identify where and how asbestos liabilities are tracked.
	* Identify key EDL resources, especially the DOI EDL Handbook and the EDL database.

 

THIS COURSE WILL NOT WORK IN INTERNET EXPLORER. YOU MAY USE CHROME, EDGE.

TARGET AUDIENCE: All employees.

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: This course is designed to familiarize you with a number of the basic terms and concepts used in the field of conservation genetics. It can serve either as an introductory genetics class or as a basic genetics refresher for those with previous genetic training. During the course, you will have many opportunities to explore the basics of conservation genetics as you work through a series of real-life case studies. 

Upon completion of this course, you will be able to explain basic concepts in genetics, applicable to conservation science.

course title: Inland Oil Spill Response for DOI
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE: Department of Interior personnel whose responsibilities include overseeing, planning,or participating in an inland spill response. 

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: The purpose of the training is to prepare agencies within the Department of the Interior to plan for and respond to inland oil spills. Participants learn agency roles in inland oil spills affecting resources under the trusteeship of the Department of the Interior. Response procedures are described for inland and freshwater environments. Emphasis is placed on planning for an emergency response and coordinating the multi agency response within the Incident Command System as led by EPA.

Topics covered include: regulations under OPA 90; Area Contingency Plans; NRDA response coordination; science of oil spills; shoreline cleanup assessment technique (SCAT); health and safety requirements for spill response; wildlife rescue and rehabilitation operations; and emerging risks. An in-depth Incident Command System (ICS) spill drill exercise will expose participants to several roles in all aspects of coordination, communication, and decision making using guidelines and authorities of ICS. Working effectively with Tribes and State partners will be emphasized. Participants with current HAZWOPER certification can obtain their required OSHA 8-hour refresher training for hazardous waste workers during this course. 

Upon completion of this course, participants will be able to: 

	* Describe spill response, oil behavior, and cleanup techniques.

	* Learn OSHA training and safety requirements for spill response workers.

	* Understand the roles and responsibilities of DOI Bureau personnel in spill response and how DOI coordinates during an incident.

	* Operate effectively within a SCAT team.

	* Demonstrate spill-response reporting procedures required by the Department of the Interior.

	* Demonstrate all knowledge skills necessary to be performed by DOI Bureau personnel before, during and after an inland spill incident.

course title: An Overview of Structured Decision Making

description:
TARGET AUDIENCE: The class is directed at those interested in learning methods and tools to incorporate climate information into their existing and future conservation planning and management efforts.  The target audience includes conservation practitioners, planners, resource and facility managers, and natural resource managers working at multiple scales to ensure the ongoing effectiveness of their work in an era of climate change.

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: This 3.5-day class provides participants with the skills and tools needed to demystify climate adaptation for application to on-the ground conservation.  This course will provide participants with guidance on how to act with intentionality while managing for change, not just persistence.  Individuals will work in teams on regionally-focused projects to apply the climate-smart conservation cycle.  Activities will include the development of climate-informed goals and objectives, scenarios to address uncertainty, the evaluation of vulnerability of targets/focal resources in multiple potential futures, and the development/evaluation of adaptation actions to address identified vulnerabilities.  A real world case study will be used throughout the course to practice provided frameworks and summarize planning results.

Upon completion of this course, participants will be able to:

	* Evaluate conservation goals from a climate change perspective, and align adaptation strategies with climate-informed goals.
	* Explain how climate change vulnerability and climate projections inform adaptation actions.
	* Complete the basic steps of scenario planning to explore uncertainty by constructing situation-appropriate scenarios for future climatic, social, and ecological conditions.
	* Identify possible adaptation options based on vulnerability information and other management considerations across one or more possible future conditions.
	* Integrate climate adaptation into existing planning and decision-making processes.
	* Tell a clear and compelling story of how a conservation project is designed, or can be modified, to increase the potential for climate adaptation.

course title: Design and Analysis of Biological Monitoring

description:
Target Audience:
Current users of ArcMap and new users to ArcGIS Pro.

Summary and Objectives:
This 4 hour on-line FWS instructor lead/hosted course utilizes four short exercises which will guide existing ArcMap users through the fundamentals of migrating to ArcGIS Pro.

Using a format similar to classroom instruction, students will attend virtually using a live WebEx account with instructors leading students through a series of demonstrations and exercises.

Students will work through the exercise on their own with the instructor(s) available for questions and live WebEx demonstrations when requested. Each individual exercise will take 20-30 minutes to complete. When finished, instructors will review the exercise, solicit questions, then move onto the next exercise in the series.

Upon completion of this course, participants will be able to:

	* Describe the capabilities and functionality of ArcGIS Pro

	* Transition from ArcMap to ArcGIS Pro

	* Define and create an ArcGIS Project (.aprx)

	* Create a Map

	* Add data to an existing project

	* Edit and symbolize layers

Requirements:
Students should have a good internet connection and the latest version of ArcGIS Pro installed prior to attending. The minimum computer requirements for using ArcGIS Pro are: http://pro.arcgis.com/en/pro-app/get-started/arcgis-pro-system-requirements.htm

TARGET AUDIENCE: Intermediate to advanced geospatial practitioners

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: This event is an opportunity for intermediate to advanced geospatial practitioners to receive focused, hands-on training clinics that would not otherwise be offered at NCTC. In addition to the training modules, the Workshop  will incorporate plenary lectures, lightning rounds, and “What’s New” software demonstrations. Lecture topics range from geospatial data management updates to FWS briefings on Regional and National program efforts.

The Workshop will also include agency program breakout meetings and mapping/poster sessions hosted within the NCTC gymnasium.
Upon completion of this course, participants will be able to:

	*

	* Cultivate professional and collaborative relationships;
	* Discover new program initiatives within FWS;
	* Share knowledge, expertise and perspectives among your contemporaries and subject matter experts; and
	* Receive training on the latest geospatial software, equipment, and technology applications.

course title: Management of Oil and Gas Activities On National Wildlife Refuge System Lands
Migratory Bird Conservation for Federal Partners
rank 10 competency: Grants Management Laws, Regulations, and Guidelines

course title: Evaluating Acoustic Bat Surveys for ESA Compliance
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE: Natural resource professionals monitoring wild bat populations or interpreting acoustic monitoring data coming in from the field.

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: This course will cover the basics of how to properly evaluate acoustic study plans, data and reports for presence/probable absence surveys of bats with a primary focus on the federally endangered Indiana bat (_Myotis sodalis_) and other bat species within its range. Participants will get hands-on experience interpreting acoustic bat data and critically evaluating reports received for federal and/or state regulatory review. Field exercises also will provide hands-on experience with proper calibration and set-up of acoustic detectors in the field, data collection and analysis, species identification, and reporting.

Upon completion of this course, participants will be able to:

	* follow the most recent Range-wide Indiana Bat Summer Survey Guidelines for acoustically assessing presence/probable absence of bats

	* critically evaluate bat acoustic surveys and reports for scientific integrity and compliance

	* describe the advantages and disadvantages of sampling bats using acoustics

	* properly set up and utilize bat detectors to maximize detectability

	* process and analyze acoustic data using each of the FWS-approved software programs

course title: Endangered Species Listing and Candidate Assessment
Habitat Conservation Planning For Endangered Species
rank 9 competency: Grants Management Laws, Regulations, and Guidelines

description:
TARGET AUDIENCE:
SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: Participants will learn when and how to apply the National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA) to their regular Fish and Wildlife Service activities. The course will cover the purpose of NEPA and its substantive and procedural requirements; how NEPA informs the decision-making process for federal policies, planning, and proposals; how to effectively engage in the NEPA process, including the review of NEPA documents; how to focus efficient NEPA reviews on important issues; and, how other laws and regulations are supplemented by NEPA. Instructors will present the course content, guide individual and team exercises, and provide feedback. Exercises will walk participants through the NEPA process to build the framework of an environmental assessment.

Upon completion of this course, participants will be able to:

course title: Federal Activities and the Fish & Wildlife Coordination Act - (FWCA)
rank 4 competency: Grants Management Laws, Regulations, and Guidelines

description:
TARGET AUDIENCE: Field staff involved in the development and review of stream restoration designs using the natural channel design methodology.

Summary and Objectives: This course teaches participants how to effectively review stream restoration designs developed using the NCD methodology. A combination of lecture, field sessions, and classroom exercises will provide practical experiences in the review of NCD stream restoration projects. 

Upon completion of this course, participants will be able to:

	* Provide a general overview of fluvial principles and processes including hydrology and hydraulics; sediment transport; hydrology, hydraulics, and sediment models; and topics in geomorphology, such as watershed/landscape processes, stream stability, bankfull discharge, and physical habitat;

	* Provide a general overview of restoration objectives and methods, including objective setting, watershed restoration and management, NCD methodology, restoration and stabilization techniques and structures, and monitoring;

	* Provide instruction on the use of an assessment and design review checklist, including a classroom exercise with an example of an NCD stream restoration; and

	* Visit completed stream restoration projects to discuss the application of the NCD methodology.

TARGET AUDIENCE:

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: This unique one day course offering, instructed by ESRI, is designed to get FWS/NPS students up and running with ESRI's newest desktop application - ArcGIS Pro. Students will become acquainted the new ribbon interface, render 2D and 3D maps from ESRI's extensive base map layers, discover it's new editing and analysis capabilities. In addition, students will experience how this application integrates with ArcGIS Online and the FWS Map Portal. Seating is limited (FWS and NPS only) and participants must sign-up advance to attend.

Upon completion of this course, participants will be able to:

	* Access and migrate content and maps to ArcGIS Online

	* View and manipulate existing ArcMap .mxds

	* Explore the new ribbon interface and tools

	* Generate multiple views in your project

TARGET AUDIENCE: Field biologists interested in using a mobile device to capture field data and locations for use with ArcGIS.

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: Use current technology to learn methods for capturing field-based observations on a mobile device and exporting the data for use in other applications. This 3-day intermediate level course provides hands-on experience with multiple GIS applications (ArcGIS Pro, ArcGIS Online, Collector, Survey123) and covers the entire field data collection workflow, from geodatabase design to compilation of outputs. Mobile hardware will be provided for use in class.

Upon completion of this course, participants will be able to:
• Design and create a geodatabase based on your project’s objectives;
• Build a web map and data entry form for point, line and polygon features;
• Use a mobile device to capture feature location and attributes; and
• Use resulting data in ArcGIS Online, or download for use in additional applications.

PREREQUISITES: FWS-CSP7102 GIS Introduction - ArcGIS Pro; or FWS-CSP7103 Transitioning to ArcGIS Pro; or the equivalent. (Contact clarissa_mathews@fws.gov)

This course serves in lieu of GIS prerequisite courses which may be required for attending certain NCTC courses within the GIS curriculum.

Any persons granted a prerequisite waiver on the grounds of professional experience or prior training completed will be added to this course to satisfy the system requirements of DOI Talent.

Completion in this course does not imply that the learner has completed the actual prerequisite course(s).

TARGET AUDIENCE: Teams who are transitioning for the SSA analytical phase to the report-writing phase, Species Assessment Team (SAT) project managers, Field office managers 

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: This primary goal of this course is to help SSA teams transition from analyzing the species to writing the report. We expect this course to benefit both Species Assessment Teams (SAT) and Field Office (FO) team leaders as well as team members, and we anticipate the benefits to be immediate and long term. As teams learn how to transition from the analytical to the report-writing phase, team leaders will learn how to help team members capitalize on their strengths to complete the report efficiently and how to build Fish and Wildlife Service capacity for future Species Status Assessments (SSAs) and report-writing work. The course’s collaborative writing material has implications both for and beyond SSAs, helping teams identify and set objectives for themselves as individuals and working groups as well as for species conservation broadly speaking. By introducing report-writing teams to the Prompt Book, the course also helps writers understand the objectives of the SSA report and briefly overviews some of the more important tools available to help teams accomplish these. Specifically, the course focuses on the most of these important of these objectives: creating a document with a clear logical chain that remains focused on species viability.

Upon completion of this course, participants will be able to:

	* Identify when the team is ready to move from analysis to writing
	* Implement the collaborative writing process and adopt the team roles that are best suited to the project and the personnel
	* Establish the SSA team’s report-writing objectives.
	* Identify team-writing pitfalls and have a strategy for resolving them
	* Identify the SSA report’s objectives and know how to access tools and resources to achieve them
	* Create a document with a clear logical chain that is focused on species viability

course title: Effect Pathway Manager (EPM): Building a Decision Support Tool for Consultation
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE: Endangered species biologists.

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: This course is intended for FWS biologists who work with the Effect Pathway Manger (EPM) within the services IPaC system.  Participants will work with EPM practitioners to learn the different tools within the system and practice the development of pathways within a learning environment.  This class will prepare participants for the growing use of the EPM in FWS offices.

Upon Completion of this course, participants will be able to:

	* Identify what a Resource Needs (RN) is, the different components that constitute a RN, and be able to create Resource Needs for a species of your choice.
	* Identify the EPM definition of an exposure path and be able to build activity specific stressors for a species of your choice.
	* Identify the EPM definition of consequences and be able to create species responses and individual effects to an exposure path for a species of your choice.
	* Identify the two parts that constitute a Conservation Measure (CM) in EPM and be able to apply CMs to an Effect Pathway.
	* Be able to cite specific data elements in EPM.
	* Be able to publish species specific data in EPM.

This course serves in lieu of ESA prerequisite courses which may be required for attending certain NCTC courses within the ESA curriculum.

Any persons granted a prerequisite waiver on the grounds of professional experience or prior training completed will be added to this course to satisfy the system requirements of DOI Talent.

Completion in this course does not imply that the learner has completed the actual prerequisite course(s).

TARGET AUDIENCE:  Anyone that needs to collect suspended-sediment data.

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES:  This is the self-certification for tracking purposes.  The course was originally on a CD-ROM. For your convenience, we have created a zip file to download.  This course presents an introduction to methods currently used by the USGS to sample suspended-sediment concentrations and particle-size distribution in streams. By the end of this course, the student will be able to: sample suspended-sediment concentrations and particle size distribution in streams

DURATION:  2 hrs

course title: Aquifer characterization using multi-scale hydrogeophysical techniques
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE: If space is limited, priority will be given to USGS employees in the Central Region, but employees from other parts of the country are welcome and encouraged to attend. Cooperators may attend on a space available basis.  

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES:  The subject workshop is sponsored by the Office of Groundwater Branch of Geophysics and the Central Region Water Sciences Centers. This workshop is one of a rotating regional series that presents principles and techniques for collection and analysis of geophysical data for hydrogeologic characterization through lectures, classroom exercises, and field demonstrations in selected aquifer settings across the United States.  

To provide instruction and hands-on experience in collection and analysis of geophysical data, with application to monitoring of hydrogeologic processes.

course title: Applied Environmental Modeling Data Assimilation and Uncertainty Analysis, with a Primer on Management Optimization
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE: Scientists performing hydrologic data analyses using complex numerical models.

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: The class will have dual foci: theory and application of model calibration and uncertainty analysis.  The theory part of the course is necessary so that participants will have clear understanding of the capabilities as well as the limitations of techniques being taught.  The application will lead participants through the use of state-of-the-practice tools needed to implement data assimilation (e.g. calibration) and uncertainty analysis in robust ways. There will also be a brief section on management optimization under uncertainty and its link to data assimilation/uncertainty analysis. 

The course will be designed to be a ``hands-on'' experience for participants and will rely on the use of the interactive IPython notebook for instruction. These notebooks will be organized to follow the course syllabus and will be structured to also serve as self-guided tutorials for participants to rely on as reference materials after the class. All software used in the course will be free and open-source and will leverage prior USGS software investments such as in PEST++ and pyEMU. 

PRE-REQUISITES:  Applications will be groundwater focused and basic familiarity with MODFLOW will be necessary for students attending the class. Prior experience with python will be helpful but not required.

TARGET AUDIENCE: This class is for technical staff that work in water resource management. In addition, to USGS personnel, the class is open to all federal, state, local, and private agencies.

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: MODSIM is a network flow optimization model used to simulate river basins, water allocation and storage operations under administrative and legal constraints in a decision support context. MODSIM can be customized to link with other models such as the USGS MODFLOW model to provide analysis on the conjunctive use of groundwater and on groundwater and surface water exchange.

Participants who complete this class will learn the following: MODSIM Basics, Use of the MODSIM user interface and out-of-the-box capabilities, MODSIM GIS interface, the Setup of a MODSIM example problem, MODSIM customization, and how to link MODSIM with other models/modules (such as MODFLOW).

course title: Acoustic Index Method for Estimating Fluvial Suspended Sediment
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE: The target audience is USGS Hydrologic Technicians, Biologists, Ecologists, Geologists, and Hydrologists engaged in collecting and analyzing fluvial sediment data, but USGS cooperators such as the Bureau of Reclamation, U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, and state agencies also are welcome.

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES:  This course teaches the fundamentals of estimating suspended sediment concentrations in rivers using backscatter from in-situ acoustic Doppler velocity meters, following procedures in U.S. Geological Survey Techniques and Methods Report 3-C5, Sediment Acoustic Index Method for Computing Continuous Suspended-Sediment Concentrations https://pubs.er.usgs.gov/publication/tm3C5. The course consists of a combination of classroom lectures, hands-on exercises, and field site visits.

COURSE PREREQUISITES: "Sound Sediment Science" Online Distant Learning Course (must be taken online, and the final assessment must be passed before attending the in-class portion of Acoustic Index Method for Estimating Fluvial Suspended Sediment.

COURSE CONTACT: Molly S Wood (208) 387-1320 mswood@usgs.gov

TARGET AUDIENCE: This basic course is intended for District field personnel with 0-5 years experience. Supervisor Approval is required.  

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES:  This course covers basic electronic theory. In addition, specific items of study will include the electronics of direct current power systems, test equipment, grounding & lightning protection, troubleshooting data collection platforms, data loggers, RF troubleshooting and soldering and de-soldering. Training will consist of classroom lectures & "hands-on" experience in troubleshooting & servicing electronic instrumentation sold by or rented from the HIF.  

It should assist any employees who perform general hydrologic field work and will be of particular value to those collecting continuous records at fixed-site stations.

COURSE CONTACT: Richard W Pardee (228) 688-2111 rwpardee@usgs.gov

course title: Applied Multivariate Methods for Ecological and Environmental Data
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE:  COURSE IS OPEN TO ALL DOI EMPLOYEES.  

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES:  This course will present an overview of multivariate methods relevant to ecological and environmental analysis, including topics related to water resources. Emphasis will be on applications over theory although we will cover enough material to make multivariate papers interpret able. The methods covered include basic matrix algebra, principal components analysis, factor analysis, cluster analysis, multivariate analysis of variance, discriminant analysis, classification trees, analysis of repeated measures and other topics as time and interest warrants.  

Describe a variety of statistical methods for visualizing multivariate data Describe multivariate methods for testing and prediction using multivariate data.  Develop skill in using the R statistical package for analysis of multivariate data Understand some of the multivariate matrix calculations.  Understand the assumptions and methods for checking assumptions.  

PRE-REQUISITES: 

	* Completion of an introductory statistics course that covers topics such as regression and analysis of variance.  

	* A basic familiarity and at least some experience working with the R statistical software program.  

	* Students must bring their own laptop with the most current versions of R and RStudio pre-installed.

TARGET AUDIENCE: Supervisors of field employees. 

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: This course provides concise information to supervisors on how to accomplish field activities without violating the spirit and intent of the National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA). This is not an introductory course (as is available online in DOI LEARN in the online course entitled--National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA) Overview). Instead this course is focused upon real world activities that occur within the USGS that may be impacted by NEPA. 

Upon completion of this course, the supervisor will be able to: 

	* Understand how field activities may be regulated under NEPA. 
	* Determine alternative strategies to align with NEPA and yet meet mission goals. 
	* Know whom to contact within USGS to discuss NEPA compliance and any issues that may arise. 

COURSE CONTACT: Aaron Stern (703) 648-7570 astern@usgs.gov

course title: Ecological Relations with Water Quality Workshop
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE: District scientists and managers

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: Central Region is sponsoring a 3-day training class to share technical information, case studies, and to discuss program development opportunities for stream and river quality studies. The training will include invited speakers, panel discussions, and a poster session. topics to be covered include (1) Traditional and innovative approaches to biological water-quality assessment, (2) Defining and classifying stream quality using biological and chemical indicators, (3) Ecological responses to water chemistry, (4) Ecological responses to hydrology and fluvial geomorphology, (5) Ecological training, QA/QC, data bases, and other project needs, and (6) Integrating biological components into existing or proposed District projects--Program development opportunities.

To obtain knowledge in stream and river studies and those who plan to develop proposals and projects relative to this topics.

TARGET AUDIENCE: Hydrologists, soil scientists, botanist, wildlife biologists, foresters, geologists, and other disciplines.

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES:  This field-oriented training focuses on the structural and functional relationships between biological and physical components of an ecosystem. The session includes in-depth analysis of the subtle and complex relationships among geology, soils, water, climate, vegetation, wildlife, and people. Upon successful completion of the training, participants will be able to: identify at least 3 specific relationships among geology, geological processes, soils, water, vegetation, and other ecosystem components based on integrated field analyses, observations, and interdisciplinary discussions; identify and describe at least 3 geological factors which can influence and/or control the overall nature of an ecosystem at 2 different scales; demonstrate more effective communication with specialist of different disciplines through direct involvement in integrated group discussions focusing on specific sites and land management issues. The course stresses interdisciplinary interactions and we encourage anyone interested to participate in this training, especially line officers and resource advisors who will find the course of value in their roles in managing ecosystems, providing staff support, and developing policy. A wide range of disciplines provides a more effective interdisciplinary working environment.

TARGET AUDIENCE: This course is recommended for any staff involved in collection of groundwater level data.

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: 

The 4-day course combines lectures and field exercises on data collection at groundwater sites for water-level monitoring and aquifer hydraulic tests. Topics include: field inventory and sitefile preparation (GWSI) for well sites, differential leveling for surveying altitude of measuring points, land surface datum and other reference marks, use of handheld GPS for location only and short overview lecture on GNSS systems, measuring water-levels, setup and servicing continuous recorder groundwater sites, well integrity, slug and aquifer tests.

Major objectives are to ensure high quality groundwater water-levels and metadata are collected at any type of well for discrete measurements or continuous measurements, for routine groundwater networks or investigative studies by staff within the data program or investigative studies program. The course introduces technical procedures of the USGS for basic data collection and is updated regularly to incorporate technological advances in instrumentation.  The audience is any staff involved in collection of water-level data at groundwater sites.

COURSE PREREQUISITES:

Prerequisites are required to attend this class. Approximately 3-4 hours viewing overview materials (pdf files and videos)
In addition, bring your field computer or tablet with SVMobile-AQ and provided test files preloaded. Be prepared to perform field activities. Proper attire required (rain or shine). No open toe shoes (sandals).

course title: Advanced GW Field Methods in Karst Terrain
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE: Hydrologists and advanced field technicians involved in collection of groundwater and surface-water data in karst terrain.

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES:  The 5-day (36 hour) course combines lectures and field exercises on data collection in karst and fractured rock terrain. topics include: streamflow measurement / seepage run to determine net groundwater contributions to streamflow, thermal infrared (TIR) cameras to locate groundwater discharge locations, fiber-optic distributed temperature sensing (FO-DTS) measurements, high-resolution vertical FO-DTS measurements beneath stream (HRTS), point-to-point tracer testing, introduction to borehole and surface geophysics usage in karst and fractured rock systems, and introduction to geochemistry tools in karst terrain.

The primary objective of this course is to provide an introduction to and hands-on experience with conventional and advanced techniques for groundwater field investigations in karst terrain. The course provides technical procedures of the USGS for data collection including recent technological advances in instrumentation.

PRE-REQUISITES: Students should have a strong basic understanding of groundwater hydrology. Bring a notebook computer (for classroom analyses) plus field clothing including a rain suit, hat, waterproof boots, bug repellent, and sunscreen.

TARGET AUDIENCE: The course is intended for USGS professionals who are already proficient in ground-water flow modeling & who will be applying models to study ground-water tracers, contamination, or saline intrusion. 

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: This 1-week course gives students practical expertise in theory, techniques, & application of numerical simulation of ground-water solute transport. 

The course emphasizes hands-on modeling of multidimensional transport of conservative & reactive solutes by ground-water of constant or varying density.
Students will become proficient in the use of two newly updated USGS models: MODFLOW-GWT (a transport process for MODFLOW) & SUTRA (a new version that does both 2D & 3D simulation). 

Students will learn to run models with a graphical-user interface that links the models, a grid/mesh generator, & graphical pre- & post-processing of data, all within a GIS-like framework. Students are strongly encouraged to also enroll in GW2081TC, a 3-day workshop that immediately follows this course.

NOTE: Important: Use of MODFLOW-GWT requires attendees to also run MODFLOW. Time constraints allow only a brief introduction to MODFLOW during the class. To achieve proficiency with MODFLOW-GWT during this course, students should have some knowledge of MODFLOW prior to attending this course. Knowledge of MODFLOW is not required to achieve proficiency with SUTRA.

course title: Modeling Transport of Ground-Water Solutes Workshop
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE: Personnel must: 

	* be experience in quantitative ground-water analysis 

	* be familiar with governing equations of ground-water flow and solute transport.

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: Gain experience in transport modeling and the ability to run either (1) MODFLOW_GWT/MOC3D or (2) SUTRA.
The purpose of this 3-day course is twofold: (1) to provide students taking the 1-week class (GW2080TC) which immediately precedes this class with a deeper knowledge of solute-transport modeling using MODFLOW_GWT & SUTRA, together with pre- & post-processors & to discuss advanced topicss in transport modeling, including inverse modeling (automatic calibration) network design & optimization. Emphasis will be on 3D modeling and use of related utilities. & (2) to provide students who have taken the course in previous years (or have equivalent experience in transport modeling & in running SUTRA or MODFLOW and MODFLOW_GWT [or earlier MOC3D code] with the opportunity of quickly learning to use graphical-user interfaces with MODFLOW-GWT or SUTRA, as well as learning the nuances of the new 3D versions of these codes.

TARGET AUDIENCE: This course is open to all USGS employees who meet the requirements described in the Course Prerequisites. Cooperators may attend if sponsored by a local USGS office. 

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: This 5-day course presents an introduction to groundwater flow simulation using MODFLOW.  The course will be taught using the newly released version of MODFLOW, MODFLOW-6.  In addition to discussing the feature and mechanics of using MODFLOW-6, this course provides a review of the basic concepts of ground-water flow and emphasizes the process of simulation analysis.  A series of problem sets are presented that are designed to illustrate concepts such as the development of conceptual models and strategies for model calibration.  This course is intended as an introduction to groundwater flow modeling.  Hydrologists with extensive modeling experience looking primarily for an introduction to the new features of MODFLOW-6 should not take this course.

﻿PREREQUISITES: ﻿ Completion of course GW2192 (Ground-Water Flow Systems Analysis & Modeling) or equivalent university courses is recommended but not required.  Familiarity with the Microsoft Windows computer operating system will be helpful.

NOTE: Students will use their own laptop computers during the class. Microsoft Windows 7 or later is required. Students will be notified about the class agenda, options for hotel accommodations, and specific classroom information at a later date.

﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿COURSE CONTACT: ﻿﻿Rod Sheets (614) 430-7710 rasheets@usgs.gov﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿

TARGET AUDIENCE: Hydrologists planning or interpreting aquifer hydraulic tests. The workshop is open to all USGS.  

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES:  This is a 3-day intermediate to advanced aquifer-test workshop. The focus will be less on the theoretical aspects of aquifer-hydraulic responses and more on the applied, practical aspects of analyzing and interpreting results. Expected ranges of aquifer properties will be presented. Field conditions and limitations will be considered for measuring water-level and discharge data. Both single-well tests will be analyzed. Theoretical responses from confined, leaky, dual-porosity and unconfined aquifers will be applied to estimate hydraulic properties related to the transmissive and storage properties of the aquifer systems. Hydraulic responses from complex aquifer systems will be analyzed with numerical models. Guidance for documenting and archiving aquifer tests, as outlined in OGW technical memorandum 94.02, will be provided.  

Emphasis will be placed on fundamental concepts of aquifer-system responses to imposed hydraulic stresses.

course title: Variably Saturated Zone Flow and Transport:  Experimental Design, Data Collection, and Modeling
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE: This course will benefit personnel that deal with problems associated with unsaturated-zone hydrology. These problems include but are not limited to: non-point source pollution effects on ground-water quality; evapotranspiration; rainfall and runoff; recharge estimation; effects of land-use and its changes on ground-water quality and recharge; effects of agricultural irrigation on water quality and quantity; fate of NAPL; spills; radionuclide distribution; and migration mechanisms,

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES:  The zone from the soil surface to the top of the ground-water table is called the unsaturated or vadose zone. It is inclusive of the rooting zone (typically about 1 meter thick) and all porous media and other geologic material to the water table. This course is a study in unsaturated-zone hydrology, which deals with the study and investigation of the physical state of soils and the transport of all forms of matter and energy within them. This will necessitate a familiarity with: a) a variety of soil and water sampling techniques and devices; b) a foundational knowledge of physical properties of soils; c) fluid-flow principles; d) contaminant-transport phenomena; and e) unsaturated-zone modeling of fluids, gases, and contaminants.

The main thrust of this course will be to instruct the student in proper field-site selection, experimental design, data collection, and modeling of contaminant transport through the unsaturated zone.

course title: Hydrofacies Modeling with TProGS: A Geostatistical Approach Based on Transition Probability & Markov
description:
TProGS is a geostatistical approach based on transition probability and Markov chains pioneered by the instructors. It is an approach to conceptualizing subsurface heterogeneity that integrates knowledge of geologic and spatial statistical properties of hydrofacies and provides an intuitive, quantitative framework for linking hydrogeologists with subsurface geologists who have expertise in sedimentology, structural geology, etc. The approach has fundamentally affected how we view the transport and persistence of ground-water contamination and has significant implications for interpretation of age-dating results and design of ground-water monitoring strategies. Transport models built upon hydrofacies-style heterogeneity can yield dramatically different results; displaying for example, very early breakthrough, more preferential flow, and very large dispersion of ground-water. PLEASE CALL ???OTHER CONTACT??? IF YOU HAVE QUESTIONS.

OBJECTIVES: To obtain knowledge in developing quantitative and geologically realistic subsurface models.

TARGET AUDIENCE: Geologists, hydrogeologists, or engineers interested in developing quantitative and geologically realistic subsurface models.

course title: Practical Modeling of Variable-Density Ground-Water Flow and Solute Transport
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE: Personnel with a general interest in using ground-water models to solve practical or theoretical problems, especially those involving solute on heat transport and variable-density fluid flow, or with a particular interest in learning to use the USGS SUTRA code and utilities, are encouraged to attend. The course is open to USGS employees. USGS cooperators, personnel from OFAs, university faculty, and students may attend.

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: This 5-day course is an introduction to modeling transport of ground-water solutes, with emphasis on variable-density fluid systems. Such modeling is a powerful tool for analyzing water-resource issues such as ground-water contamination, seawater intrusion in coastal aquifers, saline fluid intrusion, radioactive waste disposal, geothermal energy development, ground water-surface water interaction, and subsurface storage of materials, fluids, and energy. Daily activities will include lectures on course material; hands-on exercises that involve graphical design of two-and three-dimensional (2D and 3D), constant- and variable-density models and graphical post-processing of simulation results; and special presentations of real-life modeling applications. On the last day, students will have the opportunity to work on their own projects under the supervision of instructors on a project provided by the instructors.

Upon completing the course, participants will be able to (1) apply fundamental principles of ground-water flow and solute transport to analyze constant- and variable-density systems; and (2) set up, run, and interpret results from practical flow and transport simulations in 2D and 3 using the U.S. Geological Survey's SUTRA code and SutraSuite pre-and post-processing software. Participants will receive a C with SutraSuite software and files for the class examples, and a notebook containing lecture notes and step-by-step modeling exercise descriptions.

course title: Fluid Flow and Solute Transport in Fractured Rocks
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE: This course is designed for attendees who require knowledge and field methods to investigate water resources and contamination problems in fractured rock aquifers.

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: This 3-day course covers theory and field techniques needed for investigations of ground-water resources and contaminant transport in fractured rocks.  

To obtain required knowledge and field methods to investigate water resources and contamination problems in fractured rock aquifers.

TARGET AUDIENCE: Practicing hydrologists, within the USGS

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: This 4-1/2 day course begins with an introduction to the general field of optimization techniques as they can be applied to a variety of ground-water problems. For example, these techniques can be used for estimating ground-water-model parameters as well as for determining improved water-management practices. The bulk of the course focuses on teaching the techniques of linear programming and the response-matrix approach to solve progressively more difficult water-management problems. Initial problems involve a simple linear objective (maximize pumpage), subject to constraints on water-level altitudes. A single study area is used to demonstrate the usefulness of the techniques for increasingly complex problems. Attendees will learn how to formulate an optimization problem in words, as well as equations, and then solve the problem using constrained optimization computer codes, including the Ground-Water Management (GWM) package being developed for MODFLOW2000. Formal lecture and hands-on computer labs will be used about evenly to teach the concepts and application. An extensive set of handouts will be used to augment in-class learning. 

To learn how to use constrained optimization techniques to address various ground-water management problems.

TARGET AUDIENCE: This course is intended for personnel with some basic background or experience in well logging field operations & in the application of borehole geophysics to ground-water investigations. Previous training in earth sciences & ground-water hydrology is essential.  

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES:  Conventional logs that characterize properties of the fluid column & the surrounding formation will be discussed, such as resistively, temperature, natural gamma, porosity, & well bore-image data. The principles & techniques of additional down hole measurements such as packer tests, borehole radar & tomography will also be presented. Lectures will be interspersed with case histories & with hands-on computer exercises using the latest log processing software.

The emphasis of this 5-day course will be on the basic principles of geophysical log analysis & interpretation.

course title: Passive Samplers: Theory and Practical Uses
description:
SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: This course is intended to introduce scientists to the collection of organic chemical data using various types of passive samplers. The course will provide a background on how passive samplers work, suggested use in the field, QA/QC and data management, use of the water calculator, and examples of how passive samplers have been used to solve environmental issues. The course also will provide a short field exercise so that students can become confident deploying and retrieving the samplers. 

The objectives of the course is that scientists will be comfortable with the theory and practice of using passive samplers in surface water (semipermeable membrane devices, polar organic chemical integrative samplers and continuous low-level aquatic monitoring). Scientists will be able to plan and implement studies using passive samplers and be comfortable with field deployment and use of the water calculator for determining chemical concentrations for certain compounds. 

PRE-REQUISITES: An understanding of organic chemistry would be useful for this course but not required. 

COURSE CONTACT: Michael Rosen (775) 887-7683 mrosen@usgs.gov

TARGET AUDIENCE: CDEPCs; USGS only

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: _​_This training reviews selected topics pertinent to the role of the USGS Collateral Duty Environmental Program Coordinator (CDEPC). Attendees will be immersed in learning exercises focused on the core concepts of environmental compliance and management through discussions, demonstrations, and peer learning. Tuition is free, but your Center is responsible for your travel costs. 

COURSE CONTACT: Aaron Stern (703) 648-7570 astern@usgs.gov

TARGET AUDIENCE: Experienced hydrologists interested in developing skills to better understand and evaluate groundwater and surface-water interactions.

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: This course has two goals: (1) to introduce students to the theory and methods of analysis for groundwater/surface-water exchange fluxes and associated processes and (2) to make students aware of current research on groundwater/surface-water interactions. topics include: hydrograph separation, mass-balance models, analytical and numerical modeling, field techniques including hydrometric and tracer-based methods, quantification of chemical reactions affecting contaminants, and role of groundwater/surface-water interactions in supporting functional values of aquatic ecosystems. Please see agenda for further information. This Course complements course ID2015F "Field Techniques for Groundwater/Surface-Water Interactions."  

To be more knowledgeable in groundwater/surface-water interactions.

TUITION COST: $810 Please contact Staci Unruh (303) 236-9351 or sdunruh@usgs.gov to provide tuition payment information.

COURSE CONTACT: Paul Barlow (508) 490-5070 pbarlow@usgs.gov

TARGET AUDIENCE: This course is intended for hydrologists

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: This 5-day course will include an overview of the concepts of stable and radioactive isotopes and their application to solving practical problems. Investigations with isotopes of hydrogen, oxygen, carbon, nitrogen, sulfur, strontium and other elements will consider such topicss as determination of the sources of ground-water and surface-water, isotope hydrograph separations, recharge rate, ground-water dating, geochemical behavior of selected isotopes, verification of hydrologic flow models, sources of contaminants, and paleoclimatology. 

To become knowledgeable & engaged in environmental isotope hydrology studies.

course title: Microbial Geochemistry of Ground and Surface-Water Systems
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE: Personnel who are engaged in ground or surface-water quality projects but who have little background in microbiology, including personnel with significant experience, should benefit from attendance.

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: The course will focus on how microbially mediated transformations affect water chemistry in pristine and contaminated aquatic environments. Approximately one-half of the available time will be devoted to a lecture format in which the basic principles of microbial morphology, physiology, and ecology will be introduced, the biochemistry of pristine and contaminated environments discussed, and the principles of bioremediation examined. The remaining half of the time will be devoted to learning hands on laboratory techniques for studying microbial processes in aquatic and aquifer sediments. 

This 5-day course is designed to introduce concepts and techniques of microbiology and microbial ecology as they apply to studies of ground and surface-water geochemistry.

TARGET AUDIENCE: Anyone whose work involves or will involve the use of TOPMODEL will benefit from the background on the theoretical basis of the model combined with the practical hands-on approach to its use that are provided in this course.

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES:  This course will begin with an introduction and a description of the components of a catchment water balance, including a discussion of techniques for measuring precipitation and evapotranspiration. Catchment runoff processes and hydrograph separation techniques for elucidating the components of streamflow during high runoff events will then be discussed. The importance of multi-evidence approaches that combined tracer data with physical measurements will be emphasized. The next part of the course will be devoted to catchment modeling and to a discussion of TOPMODEL. Students will first learn about spatial databases and obtaining spatial parameters using the Weasel program and then will learn how to use XTOP_PRMS, a model that combines canopy interception and snowpack processes with TOPMODEL. On the third day a number of catchment hydrology studies will be discussed, including ones in which the instructors have been principal investigators. Examples from a variety of geological and climatic settings will be used. During the afternoon students will begin work on group problem sets in which they will be given some hydrologic data and asked to answer some questions to interpret runoff processes in a catchment. Data from catchments that are part of the USGS WEBB (Water Energy and Biogeochemical Budgets) program will be used in this exercise. There will be one more morning of discussions on catchment residence time and hydrology-biogeochemistry linkages, then the students will have additional time to complete their problem sets and prepare for a presentation of their results on the final morning. 

This course is designed for anyone who wants to gain a greater theoretical and practical understanding of the elements of a catchment water balance, the processes that control runoff, and the interaction of ground water and surface water, primarily in small to medium size catchments (1 km 2 - 500 km 2).

course title: Field Water-Quality Methods for Groundwater and Surface-Water
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE: The course is intended for all personnel involved in the collection & processing of water-quality samples. Other employees may attend the course depending upon their individual training needs.Two all-day field trips, requiring hands-on field work are required components of this class.

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: This 2-week course is designed to introduce employees to U.S. Geological Survey methodologies for (1) collecting and processing samples of groundwater and surface-water, for water-quality analyses and (2) completing common field water-quality measurements. Students will practice sample-collection and processing techniques for trace elements, organics, nutrients, major ions, and microorganisms. The theory, methodology, and equipment used to measure water temperature, specific conductance, dissolved oxygen, pH, alkalinity, turbidity and selected microorganisms will be covered.  

PREREQUISITE: The ideal candidate will have 1 year on the job field experience collecting water quality data and collecting and processing water quality samples

COURSE CONTACT: Stan Skrobialowski (703) 648-6902 sski@usgs.gov

THIS COURSE MAY BE OFFERED AGAIN DURING THE SUMMER IF THE FIRST OFFERING IS FULLY SUBSCRIBED.

course title: Statistical Methods for Environmental Data Analysis
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE: USGS Personnel responsible for analyzing hydrologic data or reviewing interpretive reports may attend. Non-USGS persons may attend on a space available basis. Please contact "Primary Contact" for further instructions.

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES:  This course will introduce statistical methods appropriate for analyzing and interpreting surface-water, groundwater, and water-quality data. The assumptions behind each statistical technique and the appropriate situations for their application will be stressed. Real-world hydrology examples will be used to illustrate statistical theory using the R statistical language. Topics include confidence intervals, hypothesis tests, correlation, ANOVA, simple and multiple linear regression, nonparametric alternatives to regression, ANCOVA, censored data methods, graphical presentation of results, considerations for writing, logistic regression, and trend analysis. The methods used are extendable to other types of environmental data.

NOTE: A laptop is required for this course.

PREREQUISITE: 

	* Students must bring their own laptop with the most current versions of R and RStudio pre-installed (https://owi.usgs.gov/R/resources.html#getting-started).
	* A basic familiarity with the statistical software program R. This prerequisite may be met through:

	*
Work or educational experience,

	*

Taking this USGS self-paced online R course https://owi.usgs.gov/R/training-curriculum/intro-curriculum/, or

	*

Taking an in-person R course through the USGS (https://doitalent.ibc.doi.gov/enrol/index.php?id=3630).

Some basic statistical knowledge. This prerequisite may be met through:

	*
Past completion of an introductory statistics course, or

	*

Studying this open textbook https://open.umn.edu/opentextbooks/BookDetail.aspx?bookId=135, or

	*
Completion of one of these online courses in Coursera: Introduction to Probability and Data, https://www.coursera.org/learn/probability-intro; or Statistical Inference,  https://www.coursera.org/learn/statistical-inference; or Basic Statistics, https://www.coursera.org/learn/basic-statistics.

Completion of pre-course readings, which will be sent out when registration closes.

COURSE CONTACT: Karen Ryberg (701) 250-7422 kryberg@usgs.gov

course title: Introduction to Field Water Quality Methods for Ground Water
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE: Personnel of the US Geological Survey

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: This 2.5 day course is designed to introduce the employee to U.S. Geological Survey methodologies for (1) collecting and processing samples of ground water for water-quality analyses and (2) completing commonly made field water-quality measurements. Sample-collection and field-handling techniques for trace elements, organics, nutrients, major ions, and bacteria will be described. The theory, methodology, and equipment used to measure water temperature, specific conductance, dissolved oxygen, pH, and alkalinity will be covered. 

To obtain general knowledge

course title: Introduction to Field Water Quality Methods for Surface Water
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE: Personnel of the US Geological Survey

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: This 2.5 day course is designed to introduce the employee to U.S. Geological Survey methodologies for (1) collecting and processing samples of surface water for water-quality analyses and (2) completing commonly made field water-quality measurements. Sample-collection and field-handling techniques for trace elements, organics, nutrients, major ions, and bacteria will be described. The theory, methodology, and equipment used to measure water temperature, specific conductance dissolved oxygen, pH, and alkalinity will be covered. 

To obtain general knowledge

course title: Introduction to Field Water Quality Methods for Surface-Water and Ground-Water
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE: US Geological Survey personnel

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: This 3.5 day course is designed to introduce the employee to U.S. Geological Survey methodologies for (1) collecting and processing samples of surface-water and ground-water for water-quality analyses and (2) completing commonly made field water-quality measurements. Sample-collection and field-handling techniques for trace elements, organics, nutrients, major ions and bacteria will be described. The theory, methodology, and equipment used to measure water temperature, specific conductance dissolved oxygen, pH, and alkalinity will be covered. 

To obtain general knowledge

TARGET AUDIENCE: Attendance is open to USGS employees who are currently involved in water quality studies of a nature related to the subject matter of the course or those who expect to become involved in such a study in the near future.  

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES:  This 5-day course will explore how biogeochemical processes affect the chemistry of ground water and surface water in small watersheds. The course will begin with a review of watershed hydrology concepts followed by a discussion of the watershed approach for studying terrestrial nutrient cycling processes. Results from the Hubbard Brook and Loch Vale Ecosystem Studies will be used to illustrate key concepts. Methodologies for developing watershed input-output budgets will then be introduced. Successive days will feature discussions of geochemical processes and modeling, physical transport processes in streams, wetlands biogeochemistry, nitrogen cycling in the hyporheic zone, and organic carbon cycling processes. Nutrient cycling processes in urban/suburban watersheds will be discussed on the third day. Throughout these discussions, the linkage of terrestrial and aquatic ecosystems will be emphasized. An important part of the course will be the problem sets, where groups of 3-4 students will be provided with water chemistry data to interpret. Groups will work on these problem sets throughout the week, and present a summary of their results on the last day of class.  

This 5-day course will explore how biogeochemical processes affect the chemistry of ground water and surface water in small watersheds.

TARGET AUDIENCE: Employees involved or interested in environmental processing of organic chemicals, primarily semi-volatile organic pollutants.

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: Participants will be introduced to the major chemical classes of organic pollutants and their important physical/ chemical properties. The dominant factors in environmental processing will also be discussed including sorption/ partitioning, air-water exchange, hydrolysis, oxidation, photolysis, bioaccumulation, and other fate and transport mechanisms, enabling students to develop a firm understanding of the movement of organic pollutants in geochemical cycles with particular reference to transport processes that influence water quality. 

Gain knowledge in environmental processing of organic chemicals.

TARGET AUDIENCE: The target audience is studies chiefs and project chiefs who are or would like to be actively engaged in lake and reservoir studies, and who plan to develop proposals and projects in this topics.

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: Central Region is sponsoring a 3-day training class to share technical information, case studies, and discuss program development opportunities for lake and reservoir studies that are impacted by nutrients eutrophication, and excessive algal growth. The training will involve lectures and panel discussions. Issues to be covered included - Nutrient and Sediment Transport/Loadings to Lakes and Reservoirs, TMDLs and Regulatory Needs, Load Estimation Uncertainty - Lake and Reservoir Processes - Concerns for Lakes and Reservoirs that are Sources of Drinking Water - Lake and Reservoir Modeling Capabilities - Program Development Opportunities. 

To learn technical information, case studies, and discuss program development opportunities for lake and reservoir studies that are impacted by nutrients eutrophication, and excessive algal growth.

TARGET AUDIENCE: Researches and water-resource mangers interested in using the output from existing calibrated SPARROW models or developing new models are encouraged to attend. Datasets will be provided for all exercises and problem sets; attendees are not expected to bring datasets to the class. 

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES:   The 4-day course will provide instruction in the use of SPARROW (SPAtially Referenced Regressions On Watershed attributes), a hybrid statistical/mechanistic technique for modeling the occurrence and transport of contaminants in surface waters. SPARROW models are statistically calibrated using nonlinear estimation methods with stream water-quality monitoring data and geographic information on watershed characteristics. The mechanistic components of the model include explicit surface water flow paths, non-conservative transport processes, and mass-balance constraints. The separation of land and water components in the model provides estimates of the rates of pollutant delivery to streams from point and diffuse sources and the rates of transport and loss in streams and reservoirs. Model predictions are reported for individual stream reaches and watersheds, and include estimates of mass flux, yield, concentration, the source contributions to water, and the uncertainties associated with these predictions. SPARROW has been applied to nutrients, pesticides, suspended sediment, and fecal bacteria, and is applicable to other measures of water quality, stream biology, and streamflow. The class provides a theoretical and practical introduction to SPARROW modeling techniques, including "hands-on" opportunities to use the new SAS-based SPARROW software. For additional information on SPARROW, including extensive documentation of the method and a user guide for the software, see http://water.usgs.gov/nawqa/sparrow.

TARGET AUDIENCE: The intended audience is field personnel who have attended the “Field Water-Quality Methods for Groundwater and Surface Water” course QW1028 training course three or more years ago, managers, project chief, and water-quality specialists.  

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: This course is designed to enhance skills and knowledge in water-quality field techniques for participants who attended the 2-week Field Water-Quality Methods for Groundwater and Surface-Water course QW1028 sometime in the past and to provide information on current technology and methods for participants who may be involved in program development (managers, project chief, science center quality specialists).  The course focuses on hands-on application of current protocols for groundwater and surface-water sample collection and processing.  Current and emerging microbiological methods and other topical water-quality sampling and processing methods will be discussed. 

PREREQUISITES: Attended course QW1028, Field Water-Quality Methods for Groundwater and Surface Water three years or more ago.

TUITION: $2560 Please contact Staci Unruh (303) 236-9351 or sdunruh@usgs.gov to provide tuition payment information.

COURSE CONTACT: Stan Skrobialowski  (703) 648-6902 sski@usgs.gov

TARGET AUDIENCE: Hydrologists or hydrologic technicians whose work involves application of hydraulics.  

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES:  This course combines an element of distance learning with onsite lectures and class problems in the study of basic open channel flow. Specifically, subject matter includes forces on submerged objects, conservation of energy, velocity profiles, resistance, the momentum principles, roughness coefficients, energy losses, backwater computation, flow through culverts, flow over dams, and flow through weirs. The in-class portion of the course has 18 2-hour instructional blocks. Each instructional block consists of a lecture followed by time for the students to work on problems to reinforce the material covered in the lecture. Prior to the course, participants will be sent a math refresher that is required to be completed before attending the in-class portion of the course. The math refresher will ensure that the student has the proper math skills to tackle the hydraulics problems presented in this course. Additionally, students will be required to review a few online lectures and complete a small subset of problems prior to the course in order to give participants early exposure to the material and hopefully increase the understanding and comprehension of the material presented in class.  

Provide instruction in basic hydraulic principles as applied to open channel hydraulics.  

PRE-REQUISITES: All attendees must have a working knowledge of algebra and some background in basic physics. In addition, the Office of Surface Water recommends that prior to taking this Course, attendees have done one of the following:

	* Completed the Hydrographer Hydraulics (USGS-OSW-WRD-SW1524-HydroHydraul) course, 

	* Have successfully completed a college-level physics class, 

	* Have had significant on-the-job experience with indirect measurement of discharge or step-backwater computations, or 

	* Have taken training courses which involve hydrology and hydraulic concepts. Potential attendees should contact the course developer Robert Holmes if they have questions about their preparation for this Course.  

NOTE: Please also note that this Course is a prerequisite for both Surface-Water Hydraulic Analysis courses (USGS-OED-SW2009A-HydraAnalFlowPartI and USGS-OED-SW2009B-HydraAnalFlowPartII)

COURSE CONTACT: Robert Holmes (573) 308-3581 bholmes@usgs.gov

TARGET AUDIENCE:  Personnel who are actively engaged in/plan on becoming involved in/or supervise individuals engaged in sediment or water-quality data-collection activities; those interested in sediment-surrogate technologies for suspended-sediment-bed-material and bedload-data collection; anyone who is or will be actively involved in the collection of data for a Surface-Water Toxic Waste, NAWQA or NASQAN Programs, coal hydrology studies, geomorphic assessments that require fluvial-sediment data, science-supported activities for stream restoration, and other monitoring or research endeavors involving fluvial sediment.

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: This training course is intended to provide instruction in basic sediment data-collection techniques with principal emphasis on: basic fluvial-sediment concepts; sampler characteristics; field techniques for sampling with suspended-sediment, bed material, and bedload samplers; laboratory analyses of sediment samplers; overview of computation of sediment-discharge records; selected methods for estimating sediment properties from surrogate technologies based on bulk-optic, digital-optic, laser, acoustic, and densimetric principles including selected demos; overview of a protocol using continuous turbidity and streamflow data to compute suspended-sediment discharge records; description of the characteristics of a suite of pressure-difference bedload samplers patterned after the Helley-Smith sampler; quality-assurance procedures; and other sediment-related subjects both centered on the Pacific Northwest and elsewhere.  To gain the basic sediment data-collection techniques. About half of the course period is devoted to "hands-on" field experience using a variety of samplers and techniques from bridges over and wading in west-central Washington streams including those draining the Mt. St. Helens region.

PREREQUISITES: Those taking this Course are encouraged to take (before or after) SW2096, Sediment Records Computation and Interpretation.

NOTE: Hand calculators are required for some classroom work. Paper tablets will be provided for notes but pre-printed lecture notes will not be distributed. In lieu of pre-printed lecture notes, an SW1091 course website containing all the presentations and a plethora of other information germane to sediment-data collection and -analysis techniques will be provided before the training session. Students will have the option of printing lecture notes to carry to the class if they wish. The website will also provide the agenda, maps, lodging details, and other links of interest.

TUITION COSTS: $2,390 Please contact Staci Unruh (303) 236-9351 or sdunruh@usgs.gov to provide tuition payment information.

COURSE CONTACT: Gary Johnson (217) 328-9720 gjohnson@usgs.gov

TARGET AUDIENCE: Open to all USGS Employees.

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: This course will describe the field and office procedures required to measure peak discharge using indirect methods, with emphasis on the slope-area method. Focus will be on data requirements, surveying procedures, high-water marks, selection of cross sections, plotting methods, and computational procedures. Field and office procedures will be covered. Students will survey a field site and compute the discharge from a recent peak flow using the slope-area technique.  

PREREQUISITES: Familiarity with basic surveying.

COURSE CONTACT: Terry Kenney (801) 908-5046 tkenney@usgs.gov

TARGET AUDIENCE: This class in intended for individuals proficient in the computation of streamflow records using the stage-discharge method, but have little experience or training developing stage-discharge rating curves using USGS methods. Students should have basic knowledge of AQUARIUS such as being able to navigate within Springboard, Field Data Editor (FDE), and Rating Development Toolbox (RDT).

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: This class will provide instruction on the development, computation, and use of simple stage-discharge ratings. This hands-on class will be taught using a field-based empirical approach to the development of stage-discharge rating curves following USGS methods. Topics will include hydraulic controls at gaging stations, plotting scales and offsets, single and multiple offset rating development, and the development of rating curve adjustments, commonly known as shifts. The course objective is to provide attendees with the necessary skills to develop and analyze stage discharge rating curves and variable shift diagrams required in the computation of streamflow records.  

COURSE CONTACT: Terry Kenney (801) 908-5046 tkenney@usgs.gov

TARGET AUDIENCE: The course will benefit personnel with problems involving unsaturated-zone hydrology. Such problems include the estimation of the quantity and quality of return flows from irrigation, the effects of land-use changes on ground-water recharge, the potential for contamination from disposal areas and mine tailings, the fate of nonaqueous-phase liquid spills, and the calculation of water-budgets including rainfall-runoff relations and evapotranspiration. The course assumes no prior knowledge of unsaturated-flow theory.

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES:  This course covers the application of basic principles that govern the occurrence and movement of fluids and energy in the unsaturated zone to hydrologic problems.
