Introductory concepts will be taught in a 12-week correspondence portion through assigned readings and exercises. The 1-week portion in a classroom will include hands-on laboratory exercises to illustrate concepts and demonstrate methods for determining (1) the status of unsaturated-zone fluids and (2) the hydraulic properties of unsaturated materials. The classroom portion will also explore emerging practices through case studies and provide familiarization with analytical and numerical techniques.  To gain the basic principles that govern the occurrence and movement of fluids and energy in the unsaturated zone to hydrologic problems. 
PLEASE NOTE: The correspondence portion of the course will require approximately 60 hours total (5 hours per week).

course title: A Tracer Runs Through It: Applications of the Tracer Injection Method to Streams and Small Rivers
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE: Course participants should have a general background in hydrology; detailed knowledge of chemistry is not required.

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: Over the past decade, tracer-injection techniques have been used extensively in the Western U.S. to characterize mining-impacted watersheds. These techniques are general in nature, however, and may be applicable to a variety of water quality problems. Two primary applications of the tracer-injection technique are presented: 

	* Use of tracers to estimate discharge for use in spatially intensive synoptic studies; and 

	* Use of tracers to characterize groundwater/surface water interaction. Emphasis will be placed on both field aspects (planning, equipment, sample collection) and data analysis (loading computations, solute transport modeling).

This 3-day course covers the theoretical, practical, and logistical details of conducting tracer-injection studies in streams and small rivers.

course title: Indirect Measurement of Peak Discharge using the Slope/Area Method
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE: This course is open to all USGS employees.

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: This course will describe the field and office procedures required to measure peak discharge using indirect methods, with emphasis on the slope-area method. Field and office procedures will be covered with emphasis on the slope-area method. 

Emphasis will be on data requirements, surveying procedures, high-water marks, selection of cross sections, plotting methods, and computational procedures.

course title: Techniques of Hydrologic Investigations for International Participants
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE: This training course is designed specifically for foreign scientists.

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: The program of study has been structured to meet the needs of practicing hydrologists. Teaching methods include data collection, lectures, discussions, workshops, films, written exercises, field trips and hands-on use of equipment including computer familiarization. The THIIP course curriculum offers specialization by either the surface-water or ground-water discipline for 2 weeks during the course.  The purpose of the course is to provide international hydrologists with an opportunity to learn the techniques and methods of data collection and analysis used by the U. S. Geological Survey for hydrologic investigations.

course title: Streamflow Record Computations using ADVMs and Index-velocity Methods

description:
TARGET AUDIENCE: Open to USGS Personnel and Cooperators.  This course is required by the Water Mission Area in order to use ADCPs.

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: This 5-day class provides an introduction to the use of ADCP's and ADP's for streamflow measurement. USGS employees are required to attend this class for routine operation of ADCPs. The class combines lectures and hand's-on use of ADCP's for collecting streamflow. The emphasis of this course will be on the practical aspects of using ADCP's for streamflow measurements. Some of the topics that will be covered during the course include:

	* Basic principles of ADCP operation, 
	* Configuration files, 
	* Basic procedures for streamflow measurement, 
	* Review ADCP measurements and compute discharge, and Trouble-shooting problems encountered in the field. Please see this url for further course offering information: http://hydroacoustics.usgs.gov/training/register.shtml 

The objective of this course is to train hydrographers in the application of ADCPs for discharge measurement. 

COURSE CONTACT: Mike Rehmel (317) 600-2758 msrehmel@usgs.gov

TARGET AUDIENCE:  USGS Only

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES:  To meet the training required by OSHA for entry to a potential contaminated site. USGS Annual OSHA 8 Hours Refresher as required by regulation 29 CFR 1910.120.   

PRE-REQUISITE: OSHA 24 or 40 hour hazardous waste operations or hazardous response training.

course title: USGS Procedures for Running Levels at Gaging Stations
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE:  Any Scientist who needs to run levels at gaging stations. 

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES:  This module also includes links to short videos and a fast Ethernet Connection (T1) is strongly suggested.  This training course has been designed to illustrate how methods presented in Techniques and Methods Report 3-A19, "Levels at Gaging Stations,” by T. A. Kenney can be implemented. This objective is met using graphics and notes and video clips showing how work is conducted in the field.  By the end of this course, the student will be able to describe:

	* Types of equipment used to run levels

	* How frequently levels should be run

	* Basic surveying concepts

	* Proper preparation to ensure successful field work

	* The procedures used to run levels at gaging stations.

DURATION: 2 hours

COURSE CONTACT: Terry Kenney (801) 908-5046 tkenney@usgs.gov

course title: USGS National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA) Overview
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE:  USGS Employees

COURSE SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES:  NEPA applies to Federal decisions for actions, including financing, assisting, conducting, or approving projects or programs. NEPA applies when the USGS has discretion to choose among one or more alternative means of accomplishing a particular goal. These sessions are intended for everyone who takes part in this decision-making process.

By the end of the presentation, the student will be able to:

	* List the NEPA requirements as outlined by the Council on Environmental Quality (CEQ) and the Interior.

	* Describe the types of documents that must be maintained in order to demonstrate that the USGS is properly following regulations.

DURATION:  1 hour

TARGET AUDIENCE:  Any scientists responsible for the study and collection of water-quality data.

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: This instructor-facilitated online course provides foundational training for staff who are (or will be) engaged in water-quality studies. It provides an undergraduate-level introduction to the scientific principles and practices that underlie the development and execution of water-quality studies. This course covers inorganic, organic, and isotope chemistry; ecology and microbiology; concepts of quality assurance and quality control in project work; approaches for evaluating the sources, fate, and transport of contaminants in the aqueous environment; and several methods of illustration and interpretation commonly used for water-quality data. 

The course begins with a live webinar on JANUARY 14, 2020 and is to be completed by FEBRUARY 25, 2020.  The course includes two more videos (approximately 1-hour each) on JANUARY 28, 2020 AND FEBRUARY 4, 2020. Although the course is self-paced within the constraints of the posted start and end dates and scheduled webinars, the workload is substantial, as it involves assigned readings, lesson exercises, and completion of a case-study project and presentation. On the basis of past student experiences, students should set aside at least 80 to 100 hours to complete the course within the allotted six-week period.

DURATION:  80 to 100 hours over a 6 week period

NEXT COURSE OPENING:  January 2021

TUITION: $400

COURSE CONTACT: Lisa Olsen (703) 648-5809 ldolsen@usgs.gov or Michael Rosen (775) 887-7683 mrosen@usgs.gov

TARGET AUDIENCE: Those interested in advanced modeling of coupled groundwater/surface-water systems should attend. Because GSFLOW combines PRMS and MODFLOW modeling, it is anticipated that in some cases, WSCs will want to enroll a team of two experienced modelers for the class: one with a background in watershed modeling using PRMS (or a similar watershed-modeling code), and one with a background in groundwater modeling using MODFLOW. Open to all DOI Personnel; however, priority will be given to USGS Employees.

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: Training will cover the procedures for applying GSFLOW to regional-scale basins (<10,000 km2) for water resources management. Topics will include theory and design, construction and calibration, and display and interpretation of model results. Emphasis will be placed on the construction of model input data files using ARC-GIS and python programs in Jupyter Notebooks that automate data file construction and display model results. Participants will work collaboratively through hands-on exercises, including discussion of previous instructor-led applications of GSFLOW, and current applications led by class participants. Introduciton to the new MODSIM-GSFLOW integration will be provided through example applications. Participants will leave the class with an array of resources for developing GSFLOW models, including software, tutorials, presentations, papers, and web addresses for geospatial and other data resources.

You can find a course overview at http://water.usgs.gov/nrp/gwsoftware/gsflow/gsflow.html

PREREQUISITES: Surface water and/or groundwater modeling experience 

COURSE CONTACT: Richard Niswonger, 775-297-1392, rniswon@usgs.gov

TARGET AUDIENCE: Open to USGS Hydrologists involved in current or future projects that require the application of one or more of the newer groundwater-modeling codes or application tools that have capabilities that extend beyond the core MODFLOW Packages and Processes. If space is available, this course may be open to a limited number of attendees from cooperating agencies.

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES: This course will cover many of the latest developments in groundwater-flow modeling in the following topical areas: new and enhanced capabilities for modeling groundwater flow and groundwater/watershed interactions with MODFLOW-2005, MODFLOW-USG (Un-Structured Grids), and MODFLOW-2015; solute transport with MT3D-USGS; capture maps; groundwater management with GWM and GWM-VI; and parameter estimation. In addition to lectures on the latest developments, most sessions will include in-class exercises to give attendees a better understanding of how to use the modeling tools.

PREREQUISITES:Attendees should have taken GW2096, "Modeling Groundwater Flow with MODFLOW," or have equivalent experience in applying MODFLOW-2000 or MODFLOW-2005. Attendees should also have familiarity with Microsoft Windows operating system and standard software for modifying text files and manipulating data sets.

TUITION COSTS: $850  Please contact Staci Unruh (303) 236-9351 or sdunruh@usgs.gov to provide tuition payment information.

COURSE CONTACT: Christian Langevin  (703) 648-4169 langevin@usgs.gov

INTENDED AUDIENCE:  USGS Hydrographers whose duties include establishing elevations of survey reference marks at streamgages and wells and others that work with geodetic control of spatial datas that requires Level II NAVD 88 elevations.

COURSE SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES:

	* This course has two online modules to complete.  Both must be completed before your transcript will show a "Complete" status.
	* After participating in the course, students should have a better understanding of the materials and methods used to
install geodetic bench marks that meet NGS standards.  Adherence to NGS standards will provide consistency in elevation information used in USGS products and save time and money.
	* The course will help the USGS to ensure that the vertical datum for projects mimics NAVD 88 with Level II accuracy (generally within 0.26 feet) (Office of Water Information Technical memorandum 2002.01).

DURATION:  1 hour

NOTE:  If you need to leave the course at any time, please Exit the course and open it again after the interruption.  DOI Talent will log you off after several minutes of inactivity and it will not log your completion status for the course.

AUDIENCE:  USGS employees who collect data at streamgages.

COURSE SUMMARY:  U.S. Geological Survey streamgages provide hydrologic information needed to define, use and manage the Nation’s water resources. The following presentation describes methods used to collect data at USGS gaging stations. These methods, along with the underlying philosophy of the streamgaging program have allowed the USGS to collect relevant streamflow data for over 100 years.  This presentation is based on WRIR 99-4120 by Michael Nolan and Jeff Phillips.  Some of the information in this presentation may be a bit outdated, but much of it is still relevant to collecting data at streamgages today.

DURATION: 1 hour

TARGET AUDIENCE:  Any Scientists that are responsible for completing field data collection for an indirect measurement.

COURSE SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES:  This course is comprised of several short instructional videos on collecting indirect measurements.  The learner will need to watch all videos to get credit for taking the course.  All videos are closed-captioned.

DURATION:  Approx. 1.5 hours

AUDIENCE:  This training  module is focused on providing water-use personnel with the information necessary to begin using the USGS NWIS Aggregate Water-Use Data System (AWUDS).

COURSE SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES:  By the end of this course, the learner will be able to:

	* List reasons why the USGS uses AWUDS to store water-use data,

	* Discuss how AWUDS stores aggregate water-use data,
	* List the types of data that can be stored in AWUDS,
	* Create a template, and

	* Describe the basic workflow for entering data into AWUDS.

DURATION:  1 hour

AUDIENCE:  This training module is focused on providing water-use personnel with the information necessary to begin using the USGS NWIS Site-Specific Water-Use Data System (SWUDS).

COURSE SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES:  By the end of this course, the learner will be able to:

	* List reasons why the USGS uses SWUDS to store water-use data,

	* Discuss how SWUDS stores site-specific water-use data,

	* List the types of data that can be stored in SWUDS,

	* Create a template, and

	* Describe the basic workflow for entering data into SWUDS.

DURATION:  1 hour

AUDIENCE:  This training module is focused on providing water-use personnel with the information necessary to collect and compile water-use data for the Aquaculture water-use category as part of a 5-year compilation.

COURSE SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES:  By the end of this course, the learner will be able to:

	* Define Aquaculture water use,
	* Identify key concepts, terms and definitions for the Aquaculture water-use category,
	* List the types of data that are collected for the Aquaculture water-use category and how the data are stored in USGS databases, and
	* Describe estimation methods for each of the types of Aquaculture water-use data that can be collected.

DURATION:  1 hour

AUDIENCE:  This training module is focused on providing water-use personnel with the information necessary to collect and compile data for the Domestic water-use category as part of a 5-year compilation.

COURSE SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES:  By the end of this course, the learner will be able to:

	* Define Domestic water use,
	* Identify key concepts, terms and definitions for the Domestic water-use category,
	* List the types of data that are collected for the Domestic water-use category and how the data are stored in USGS databases, and
	* Describe estimation methods for each of the types of Domestic water-use data that can be collected.

DURATION:  1 hour

AUDIENCE:  This training module is focused on providing water-use personnel with the information necessary to collect and compile data for the Industrial water-use category as part of a 5-year compilation.

COURSE SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES:  By the end of this course, the learner will be able to:

	* Define Industrial water use,
	* Identify key concepts, terms and definitions for the Industrial water-use category,
	* List the types of data that are collected for the Industrial water-use category and how the data are stored in USGS databases, and
	* Describe estimation methods for each of the types of Industrial water-use data that can be collected.

DURATION:  1 hour

AUDIENCE:  This training module is focused on providing water-use personnel with the information necessary to collect and compile data for the Livestock water-use category as part of a 5-year compilation.

COURSE SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES:  By the end of this course, the learner will be able to:

	* Define Livestock water use.
	* Identify key concepts, terms and definitions for the Livestock water-use category.
	* List the types of data that are collected for the Livestock water-use category and how the data are stored in USGS databases.
	* Describe estimation methods for each of the types of Livestock water-use data that can be collected.

DURATION:  1 hour

AUDIENCE:  This training module is focused on providing water-use personnel with the information necessary to collect and compile data for the Mining water-use category as part of a 5-year compilation.

COURSE SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES:  By the end of this course, the learner will be able to:

	* Define Mining water use,
	* Identify key concepts, terms, and definitions for the Mining water-use category.
	* List the types of data that are collected for the Mining water-use category and how the data are stored in USGS databases,
	* Describe estimation methods for each of the types of Mining water-use data that can be collected.

DURATION:  1 hour

TARGET AUDIENCE:  WSC, hydrographers

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES:  This course is designed to guide USGS hydrographers in the collection and publication of continuous groundwater data, emphasizing USGS policy and procedures for site establishment, instrumentation, field visits, data management, record editing, and data publication. Overviews of field operations, the NWIS system, and AQUARIUS are included.

PREREQUISITE: USGS AQUARIUS for all users (USGS-OED-C1871)

COURSE CONTACT: Charles Schalk (207)626-6611 cwschalk@usgs.gov

course title: Indirect Measurements of Peak Discharge (Flow though Structures)
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE:  USGS Employees

SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES:  This course will describe the field and office procedures required to measure peak discharge using indirect methods, with emphasis on flow through structures such as bridges and culverts. Focus will be on data requirements, surveying procedures, high-water marks, selection/survey of cross sections, plotting methods, and computational procedures. Field and office procedures will be covered. Students will survey a field site and compute discharge for a documented flood peak using an appropriate indirect method.

PRE-REQUISITES:  Familiarity with basic surveying techniques (total station and/or engineer’s level). Completion of one or more of the following courses: 

	* SW1004 Basic Hydraulic Principles 
	* SW1163 Indirect Measurement of Peak Discharge (slope-area method) 
	* SW2009A, Part I Surface-Water Hydraulic Analysis - Indirect Measurement of Open Channel Flow 

OR 

	* Have had significant formal training or on-the-job experience with indirect measurements of discharge or step-backwater computations

COURSE CONTACT: Mark Smith (303) 236-1469 mesmith@usgs.gov

course title: USGS General Environmental Management Awareness Training
description:
TARGET AUDIENCE:  Any USGS employee

COURSE SUMMARY AND OBJECTIVES:  After completing this course, employees will be able to:

	* Explain USGS’ environmental and cultural impacts

	* Describe the bureau’s environmental goals (objectives and targets)

	* Describe your responsibilities

	* Find contact information for support

DURATION:  1 hour
